user_texts:
['I underestimated how cold it was going to be. I would bring crampons if you have them.', 'December 31, New Year’s Eve Hike to end the year! 7.7 miles of uphill and downhill with snow, mud, and rocky road. We didn’t get a chance to see the view on Cuyamaca Peak due to fog and windy weather, but it was definitely the toughest hiking trail when it is snowy and muddy!', "31Dec2018, this is an awesome trail, it's actually a hard trail if your dealing with snow and sometimes a strong wind....challenging but doable... we didnt get any good views at the top due to foggy weather... i did get a picture of a frozen plants", 'Did this hike on December 30th and from the beginning there was lots of frost and patches of light snow. As we hike for about 1 hr we started seeing the trail covered in snow then it stayed all the way to the top. With the snow it made the hike harder, but also was really enjoyable. Be careful once you get to the fire road, my brother and I both fell on the way down. We were wearing hiking boots and using treking poles.

Azalea Glen Loop is what makes this hike enjoyable. As we went down the fire road on the way down we both thought we would be disappointed if that was the route to the top we took.

Parking at the bottom campground is $10 and the adventure pass is not accepted.', 'Beautiful hike this morning!  I loved this route via Azalea Glen and then through Conejos Trail.  Very peaceful, and great views throughout the hike.  A good amount of mud early along the trail today, and then snow as I got further along (dec 28).  Not too icy though—didn’t need microspikes or anything in today’s conditions.', 'Perfect hike to select on Christmas Eve!', 'Great hike . The view of the whole region from the top would be worth it. We went on Christmas Eve 2018 . So clear we could see Big Bear, Palomar, Salton Sea, Mt San Miguel, ... It’s painful to see how much was burned on the mountain a few years ago , but also good to see how the area is recovering. different areas had grasses, bushes and thousands of young pine trees.The trail is well maintained and fallen trees I had read about in reviews from a couple of weeks earlier were already cleared.', 'Awesome, Lots of great views!', "So much better than just taking the fire road. I'd actually suggest doing an out and back on the recommended start to the route so you only do the paved part at the end. Be prepared for some very narrow trails that get pretty rocky (loose in some areas).", 'I did the loop, and I really liked it! The first part was a rocky trail with lots of great foliage and views. There were a couple of downed trees but I was able to climb over them pretty easily. The top isn’t really that great because there is a bunch of construction equipment and I went pretty early so it was windy. I took the paved path back and it was really easy. I’d definitely recommend doing the loop because the first part had the best views, IMO. Enjoyable, and in the easy to moderate range.Note that there is a $10 state park day fee to park.', 'This was a fun and diverse trail!  We started up the fire road and about two thirds of the way up we were in the clouds.  It was magical!  A good handful of hikers complained about not having the right clothing as the weather from the base to the summit was drastically different.  We took the Azalea Glen Loop trail down.  I was looking forward to some trail running down but the trail was too rocky and unstable; I would go up Azalea Glen Loop and down the fire road if I were to do it again.', 'Dogs are only allowed on the fire road and it is an all uphill paved path this way. Awesome views at the top!', 'Awesome, Lots of great views!', 'Loved it. Amazing scenery and views over many of the California mountain ranges. Steep towards the end but doable. Unfortunately no resting area at the peak (we had lunch sitting on the trail). Views just breathtaking !', 'Awesome hike and amazing views at the top. It was out first time hiking and we would definitely recommend stopping at the ranger station for a map. During the hike, once you get to the fire road, turn right. Then, the sign for Conejos trail is a bit hidden and will be on your left after 10 min or so. Bring plenty of water; 2 of us brought 80 ounces and it was just enough.', 'Perhaps my favorite hike in San Diego. Challenging, especially the steep grade of the service road, and great views from the summit. Grab a map from the ranger if you’re not very familiar with this area, I had a little trouble finding my way around the loop to the summit the first time I did this hike.', 'Beautiful trail, recommend following the guidance here up Azalea to the right then down the paved road on the way back (not fun for the feet though).Note:  the entrance to Conejos is very difficult to spot, the trail sign is hidden if you’re travelling from Azalea.  Also, bring lots of water and sunscreen.  Park patches, cool gifts, and wildlife display at Cuyamaca Rancho visitor’s center before you get to the campground- worth a stop Sat and Sun 1000 to 1600.  Recommended soundtrack for the drive:  Tin Hat Trio: The Rodeo Eroded.', "Breath taking trail. The trail has a very sad slow rate of forest regeneration, which prompted a reforestation project to replant using donations. It breaks my heart when I saw such magnificent pines burnt to the core. Quick history: The fire took place in 2003, when a lost hunter lit a signal fire hoping to be found. That signal burned out of control and became the biggest wildfire in California's history, burning more than 300,000 acres, killed 15 people and burned 2400 homes.", 'Love it', 'Great trail I love it', 'Excellent trail, love the view', 'Great forest hike. Nice weather with a cool breeze! Park at the campground and pay the $10 parking fee. The azalea glen trail is south of the parking lot. Flat and gradual incline at the beginning. Steep as you reach the peak.', 'Love it!! Perfect for a birthday hike with friends!!', 'I was most surprised by a family that pushed a baby in. Baby stroller to the top of the this beautiful Peak. The 360 degree view was marred by mist or possibly smog to the west, so you couldn’t quite see the Pacific Ocean. Otherwise it was a sunny blue sky day with 15-20 mph winds. We met a couple dozen other hikers, including a group of Japanese teenagers coming up from the Paseo Pacheco Campground, where we parked for $10.', 'Great hike.  Conejos trail is definitely a challenge and it’s a good workout going up.  The views are spectacular.', 'Beautiful views all around and the frosty weather at the top was like the cherry on top. Enjoyed the cold and the icy winds on an other wise warm day in San Diego. We hiked with our dog so we stuck to the paved road (~5.4 mile out and back). Would definitely come back here soon!', 'Fun trail.  If you hike it counter-clockwise there is a stretch in the first half that is a fairly steep uphill climb.  The views at the top are the reward and they are pretty magnificent of the valley below and Lake Cuyamaca.  I’ll do this one again.', 'Amazing, the most beatiful', "3/3/18 Great hike! I definitely wasn't prepared for the cold weather and all the snow up there but the hike itself through the woods and meadows was gorgeous. I plan on going back soon to get some better views and hopefully better weather, a lot of fog rolled in on my way up so I didn't get to see any of the scenery from the summit.Pictures and snow slowed me down so I took a little under 4 hours to hike it. I took the Azalea Glen trail up to the Azalea springs road, then the cuyamaca peak fire road from there. Took conejos trail back down, which takes you back to azalea springs.", 'Did this trail right after a storm dumped around 6 inches of snow. There was snow all the way up and back, at least 12 inches deep in places.  It felt like 10 miles with the snow, but the landscape was epic.', "Male, 35 (and female companion, 29) 
6', 240 lbs 
Fitness level: average 
Hiking experience: intermediate 
Date of hike: 02/10/18 
Pace: easy/moderate 
Total time: A little under 3 hours (app clocked us at 2:35 movement time) 
Weather temp: Didn't track, it was probably around 60-70

Definitely do this counterclockwise, starting from the Azalea Glen Road trail and make your way up to Conejos and then to the Fire Road (paved road). 

Beautiful scenery, one of the very few hikes in San Diego where you can actually see trees and pines. Huge, beautiful pine trees!

The hike for the most part is easy until the climb at the end, it is quite demanding on your cardio, especially if you're not in optimal shape. But just take it easy and you'll be fine.

Highly recommend this hike, probably my favorite in SD.", 'Id give it a 3.5 star review only because we did an out & back up the paved fire road instead of the loop...super steep & hard on the lower body. Still doable, but so boring! Take the fire road on your way down the loop! Also, theres huge gaudy satellite antennas at the top with a barbed wire gated fence. Totally ruins the views at the peak trying to dodge cables in your photos. About halfway or so up (or down) the fire road theres a cute little lookout with a bench. The views are breathtaking! Youll want to take a minute to take it all in!', 'We took a different route to get to cuyamaca peek. We parked at Paso picacho campground and hiked up a maintenance/fire Road. This made it a pretty easy climb. It was Steep at the end, but no big deal because the road was so well-maintained.  amazing views and pleasant hike. This was about a 6 mile out and back.', 'We did this loop counter clockwise, which allowed us to go down the very steep and boring paved fire road at the end.  The steepest and rockiest part in this direction was after the spring.', "Did this hike with my girlfriend on Saturday, 01/27/18. Not terribly difficult until the incline on the Lookout fire road just before the top. Took us 4h, 49m moving time. 9.2 miles, avg speed 1.9 mph, top speed 4.5 mph. Came up Azalea Glen Trail, Took Conejos Trail to the Fire Road up, and also on the way back (no interest in taking that paved fire road all the way down). Took Azalea Glen Road (dirt) from the Azalea Spring Jct down to the campground. Coming down was about 1.5 hours total with stops and picture taking. Most of the trails were great and a nice mix. Saw 2 deer a mile in and 6 at the campground at sundown, also Wild Turkeys on the side of Middle Peak. Views up top were amazing. Windy and cold, but there's a lumber bench set up behind the building, we ate lunch at. Good windbreaker from the Santa Ana winds.. (View recording for route taken)", 'Not sure why it says difficult, it definitely wasn’t hard. Very beautiful hike though! Took about 3 hours to complete. I went during the Santa Ana winds so it was suuuuuuper windy and cold at the top. Will definitely be back!', "Love this hike! Definitely take the far right trail counter clockwise up the mountain.  I think the hike is fairly moderate until you get to the last 1/2 mile or so on the fire road, then it's a pretty steep incline to the summit.  This time around we saw some deer close to the campground entrance on the start of our hike and then a coyote in the distance about 1 mile in.  Scenery is gorgeous and we lucked out with some frosted trees and snow toward the summit. Almost 8 miles roundtrip... took us a little over 4 hours to complete with some rest time in between.", '', 'We did this hike on Saturday (1/13/18) and really enjoyed it.

Parking- you park in the area of a campground along CA-79 and it is the same lot used if you are doing the Stonewall Peak hike which starts on the other side of the highway; you must pay $10 and if you get there early like we did before a Park Ranger is on duty you must fill out an envelope and drop the $/envelope in a slot so make sure you have exact cash; no special Adventure Day Pass is needed

Trail/route- we did the loop starting w/Azalea Glen to the Azalea Springs Fire Road to Conejos Trail which at about 4.2 miles will take you to a paved fire road...make sure to turn right at this juncture and this will be the hardest steepest part of the hike for the final 1/2 mile to the top and you will have completed approx. 4.8 miles to get to the top; we took the paved fire road straight down to complete the loop and it will total about 7.5 miles when you get back to the parking lot and it takes around 4 hrs to complete starting at about 4,900 ft and reaching the top at nearly 6,500 ft

My thoughts: this is a beautiful area and the drive to the trailhead offers so much to see; it is not a crowded trail; there are great views of Cuayamaca Lake and the hills to the east and when you get to the top you are rewarded with a great view looking west to San Diego and the Pacific on a clear day; most of the hike is easy especially the first 2 miles of the loop if you go counter clockwise like we did and the only difficult part was the last 1/2 mile going up the steep fire road to the top', 'i love it, not too easy but great', 'Great area and very cool trail. Recommended.', 'My girlfriend and I did this "part" of this hike on New Year's Day. The weather was a little overcast and made for perfect hiking weather. 

We added a couple extra miles to this hike. Instead of taking the main fire road, which is paved, we hiked up Azalea Glen Road to Azalea Spring Fire Road to the main Fire Road (paved) and finally extending the trail to Cuyamaca Peak. Hiked down Conejos Trail to Azalea Spring Fire Road to Azalea Glen Trail . 

The view from Cuyamaca Peak was fantastic! We both decided to stay off the main fire road because it was paved and felt that the other dirt trails were better on our knees.', 'We love this hike! Done it multiple times now. Has enough challenge and beauty to really enjoy. When we go early, we are completely alone on the trail. Only draw back is the steep fire road down from the peak...rough on the knees!', 'Fantastic views along the way and the view at the summit is worth the trip. We hiked the Azalea Glen trail to Conejos trail then up to the peak. We took the lookout road back down to the parking and it was not a great trail for views and hard on the knees. Overall the hike was over 7 miles. It was challenging, but doable for most hikers. If I had more time I would have retraced my steps going back down the Azalea Glen trail. I would give the overall hike a 4.7 and rank it among the best in San Diego county.', 'Really enjoyed the hike. Sad to see all the damage from old wildfires but it’s still beautiful. Went on Dec 30 and the weather was perfect. Hiked the loop counter clockwise. The view at the summit is amazing. The only knock on it is if you take the paved road on the way back down it’s tough on the knees/back. My wife and I hiked at a leisurely pace and spent some time at the summit and it took 5 hours. Ran into other hikers but it wasn’t crowded. I would definitely recommend it to anyone. Can’t beat it when it’s only an hour away from SD!', "Should've read the other reviews before going up, we took the fire road all the way to the top and conejo trail on the way down. nevertheless, it was an amazing hike...went on 12/19/17 with some friends, it got pretty chilly on top...went back with the wifey on 12/21/17, and it rained the night before...there's puddle of ice on side of the fire road and the pine leaves have frozen dew drops, this time it was freezing cold hahaha..", 'Nice hike with great views.  But it was pretty cold and windy on top. Take jacket', 'Great trail.', 'Did this hike last Sunday 11/05. There are parts of the trail that have heavy machinery cutting down timber. We were able to continue on trail as machinery was not near path. The fire peak lookout is awesome. It was windy up there but very refreshing as the wind will dry up sweat.', 'My knees wish it wasn’t paved the whole way (down)', "park at the camp grounds as others have mentioned.  costs $10.when you start, take the right most trail path to do the loop counter clockwise,  otherwise you'll end up pretty bored on the fire road all the way up.    the counter clockwise loop allows you to hike through a very natural setting.   eventually you have to get back onto the paved fire road to get up to the summit and when you descend,  it will all be paved back to your parking spot.", "Great loop.  We did it counter clockwise. When you get to the fire road towards the end make a right and head to the summit. It's only another half mile up.  My gps was at a little over 8 miles on this hike. Significantly more than the 6.3 that shows on this loop.", 'Awesome hike. Great views, great challenge and not too crowded.', 'I followed the trail description exactly, but in reverse. I started with the fire road, and descended on the Conejos Trail/ Azalea Glen trails. Easy to navigate in my opinion. 
Nice hike, clear day. (I saw a Bald Eagle!)', 'brings lots of water, due to high elevation hike, to get to the peak the fire route is the main trail to hike on, but accessing it from other trail heads are will add mileage to your destination. We started from the West Mesa Trail head and took the West Side Trail to the connect to the fire route which added 2.3 miles. From the connecting loop we got up to a 4.55 mile to the peak. heading back we took the West Mesa Trail connecting loops. carefully as you can easily get lost. Look for the Fern Flat Fire trail which will lead you to the West Mesa Trail to the 79 and cross to where we originally park cause we did not want to pay for parking, plus we wanted distance and adventure. our total was 12.63 miles.', 'This trail is closer to 7.5 miles. Not a very scenic trail.', "Excellent hike. Nice breeze in the afternoon even with temps in the mid-80's. Lots of butterflies today. Nice to see cedars, firs, and pines that weren't touched by the fires. Easy to miss the Conejos Trail if you're not paying attention.", 'Me and my 6 year old son loved the view from peak! We took azalea road to go up and took fire road on the way down because we saw some black clouds with lighting coming towards us I thought we should hurry.', "Loved this trail. We hiked it late July, which was hot, so bring lots of water. Parts of the trail have shade, which we took advantage of by resting and fueling up. We saw wildlife, lots of trees, and great vistas. Coming down the fire access roads wasn't as scenic or enjoyable as the actual trails, but still a great hike.", "Great trail, while hiking the trail. A deer almost ran into me when frightened by something. There's a greater diversity of terrain and environments.", "12551 Highway 79 in Descanso, CA 91916 is the address of the Paso Picacho Camground where you can park.  It is $10 to park there but they have decent restrooms and running water.  I have hiked to Cuyamaca Peak 3 other times taking the Lookout Fire Trail, which is very steep, hot and so hard on my knees.  The Lookout Fire Trail is also pretty open so it doesn't quite feel like a nature trail.  I did not know there was other trails that lead to the peak until recently. So this beautiful warm June Saturday morning, A friend and I decided to take the Azalea Glen Loop to the Azalea Springs Trail to the Conejos Trail up to Cuyamaca Peak and back down the Lookout Fire Road for a total of 7 1/2 miles and 1,700 ft elevation gain. It was 4 1/2 miles to the peak taking the trails up and 3 miles down the Lookout Fire Road.  We were some of only ones on the these trails going up.  I think we passed two other people.  It was a little warm but there was a nice breeze so it was very bearable.   The trails were nice and shaded part of the way up.  There was a lot of wildflowers and a lot of butterflies.  It was so peaceful. The views at the top were worth the work!  I don't think I'll ever take the Lookout Fire Road up again when you have so many beautiful trails to choose from.  If you want to get to Cuyamaca Peak, definitely check out the trails!", "Marching up all that miserable, hard ass pavement is totally worth the view!  First time I ever saw the Salton Sea.  I did this one in skate shoes, no boots needed.  I'd recommend them though in the winter. I'm from the Midwest, and I hate walking on snowy/icy sidewalks. I couldn't imagine walking a snowy sidewalk all the way up a mountain.  I didn't realize at the time there were alternate trails to the top, I might have to go back!", 'Worthwhile hike but hiking on a paved fire road is painful.  Take the trails', 'Trails up were great, fire road down on the paved road was really hard on the legs. View from top was ok but a bit hazy.', "Don't you dare take the paved road up...", 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', 'great hike', "It's really not that hard. And you get to be the highest person in San Diego! Totally worth it. Amazing view. Gets pretty slippery in winter season.", 'Great views at top.  Azalea Trail is beautiful.', 'Beautiful views! Great nature hike, lot of animals sightings.', 'this trail was great nice hike up to the top loved the view', 'Gorgeous trail after the rains! So green and lush. Take the loop to the right at start for sure, steady rocky climb, with breathtaking views! Add the Peak .5 at top for amazing westward view! Easy to cruise down on the paved trail side. Only bad thing was lots of gnats!', 'Decent trek with a fair bit of variety for Southern California hiking.  By that I mean there were some good long rang views as expected, but also some forest, some meadows and a stream with plenty of vegetation along it.  The hike up was mostly a paved path so it didn't seem as "natural" as some hikes, but it still was a bit of a workout.', "Awesome view from the top. Unfortunately, it's a paved road and not much trail. Steady incline all the way up. Not much to see except on the final destination. Would recommend!!!!", "The trail was mystifying. Once you get to some of the fire lane roads it can be a bit confusing so I do suggest getting a map from the rangers.  Beautiful brooks to enjoy and stick your feet in and benches to sit.  If you want some solitude it's definitely possible.  The view from the peak is amazing.  Be mindful of wildlife.  It's not the hardest trail I've done but it's not easy.", 'if you dont want to do the whole loop, you can park in the campground and just do the peak hike which is much shorter.', "Great hike! We saw about 20 wild turkey and 9 deer. It's listed as hard but we thought Iron Mountain was harder and it's listed as Moderate.", 'Make sure you climb on a day that is at least partially sunny so you can get the chance to see the coastline from the top!', 'Great Hike!! I love the variety of trails and the steep inclines really gives you the cardiovascular workout you desire. I highly recommend this hike.', "Loved this hike. Went 2 days after rainfall and it was great having some greenery and a little moisture everywhere.  It was fairly easy in the beginning 30% of the trail then became more difficult from there on. The trail was rocky and seemed to have a stream going through the trail which made it that much more fun.  The peak was beautiful as was expected.  We took the paved road down and we are extremely glad we didn't take it up because there isn't much to see.  We started at Azalea Glen, then Azalea Springs, then Conejos and busted a right on the paved road when it met up with us to the top.  Was really a special hike. Highly recommend. Another good part about this hike was actually the drive up to the trail. You pass through a little town called Julian which could be a whole separate review all in itself.  Pretty fun day! We totaled about 9.0 miles up and back including a few off trail ventures.", 'Can you recommend hiking on this trail on Jan 1, 2017?', 'Great hike today! About an inch of snow and 35 degrees. I ended up with 8.48 miles on this trail. took a wrong turn and lost some elevation that I had to gain back. Beautiful weather today. Clear blue skies, icy and snowy trees. I will definitely come back for more whether in the winter or summer.', "This is my favorite trail in SD. so many loops to hike. It's a must if you love hiking. I usually do around 10-15 mils", 'One of my favorite trails, definitely take Conejo Trails on your way up via Azalea Springs for the best experience.', 'This is hands down my favorite hike in San Diego County. I have done this hike more times than I can count and never seem to get tired of the hike or the view. Great views all the way up and down from the summit with a breathtaking view from the top.', 'Amazing hike. Difficult not for the beginner.', 'All uphill and fairly steep to the peak on a paved road, but still good views along the way. Great views from the peak though. Conejos trail on the way back was much more scenic and easier on the feet, though a little rocky with a fair amount of scree. Good to see the forest making a comeback after the fires. Afterwards went to Julian for an awesome chicken pot pie dinner at rongranch (spelling ?) restaurant and some moms apple pie. Picked up dudleys fruit bars on the drive home.', 'Hiked Azalea Glenn to Conejos trail to the peak. Conejos was very scenic and fun to hike. My 5 yr old little girl conquered this hike in about 5 hrs. My 3 yr old was able to do about 1/2 and 1/2 on my back.  The worse part was going down the paved fire trail... knee buster for sure, not scenic... a death march back to the car! Lol', "A decent hike. Took us about 5 hrs w 2 kids aged 3 and 5. My 5 yr old little girl conquered the whole 6 miles all the way to the peak. The Conejos Trail was beautiful from Azalea glenn/springs. The hike down the paved fire road from the peak was more brutal than going up! I'd do it again when my 3 year old can pull her own weight! Haha", 'hike on Azeala Glenn and Cornejo trail to peak has nicer views than access road, distance will increase by close to 2 miles of gradual ascent', "This hike is gorgeous but not for beginners! We did the route the map shows, which is the Fire road to the peak, then Los Conejos for much of the way down and Azaleas loop back to the park entrance. Stopping to snack and take pictures at the top we took 4 hours. I definitely recommend good hiking socks because the way down is VERY rocky, even with good hiking boots my husband ended up with blisters. Don't even attempt in gym shoes unless you plan on taking the paved fire road up and back. The loop goes through a wide variety of scenery, although parts are a bit overgrown the trail is very clear.", 'Kicked my butt, did out and back on the fire road from 79 to the peak took 2 hr 45 min total.', 'This is a magical little place.', 'Stunning and breath taking view!!', 'A great walk. It took 3 hours. Up by the fire road and down though the back trail. It a great loop just a little exposed. Go to the peak it worth it', 'Amazing display of the different environments experienced at Cuyamaca Ranch SP. Awesome view at the top. All uphill, come prepared.', 'Gorgeous views. Lots of wildlife. We saw a whole herd of deer. Fairly easy but a few semi- steep hills towards the end.', 'Hiked this from Cuyamaca Peak back down the fire road to the campground.  Not a bad hike.  Fire road is a bit blown out but scenic views are great.', 'Tough to find actual trail head although when you arrive at the parking area ( in the campground lot) there are several other clearly marked ( easy) trails.  Beautiful hike uphill rather steep all the way to peak. Be careful about timing, the loop going back is much longer.', 'so far everything is wrong.every place shown said descanso very wrong Cuamaca stat park.', 'The hike isn’t to thrilling, but the views from the top make it worth it. Full hike directions and trip report on my blog.', 'Long steady uphill climb on a paved fire road. Go on a cloudy day for some above the cloud fun. Moderate difficulty,', 'This was a great hike...lots of wildlife. It was amazing how many deer we saw on the way back. The view at the top is spectacular.', "I did this hike by myself a while back and would only recommend if you had a map- I didn't and got lost a few times. This hike is truly beautiful and the views at the top are stunning. There is a small bench a few hundred feet from the last incline that makes for a great pre-summit rest. Plenty of plant life to observe, and gives lots of shade in some parts too. If you take the fire road up it's quicker, steeper and easier (navigation wise) but I think, less pretty. I would say take the trails up and the fire road down, or vice versa.", 'Cuyamaca state park is one of my favorite places, everything right now is green. This hike is relatively easy with good elevation. Scenery is so beautiful and peaceful. I will definitely do it again.', 'I did this hike with 6 other friends and my parents.  we ended up taking the wrong turn and first did a smaller azalea loop and then my parents got sun burnt. The sun was hot this June  and we had to carry at least 2 liters of water per person. parking is 8$ and they have restrooms and cool water at the bottom on the campgrounds. after our initial mis turn we stated from the bottom on fire road and went all the way to the peak. the hike was hard with constant incline up. we took 4.5 hours to complete. views from the top are good.', 'Beautiful view', 'I did this hike with a group of friends. We took the trail up by Azalea Glen, Azalea Springs, Conejo Trail and finally the Fire Road. It took us approximately 3 and a half hours to reach the top. Azalea Glen is a gorgeous, leisurely stroll from rolling prairies to lush forest, except toward the end of it. The trail gets quite challenging on Conejo. Overall it was a great hike with beautiful, scenic views. Definitely worth the drive from Imperial.', "Fairly easy hike up along a paved fire road. There are some areas of steep elevation gain. We brought our golden retriever who loved the walk. This is the only dog friendly train in Cuyamaca Rancho State Park. 

It was rainy, windy, and foggy on the day we hiked, so we didn't see any of the spectacular views. Lots of pretty wildflowers to enjoy along the trail, and you do see a lot of the damage caused by the 2003 Cedar Fire. Completed the hike in about 2 hours.", 'Hard last part.Great cardio.', "I came up via the fire road. Which didn't bother me as much as I thought it would. It is a pretty hike up and the view from the top is wonderful. It was fairly difficult my heart rate stayed reasonably elevated and I was a bit sore the following morning. I figured I would get some bang for my buck, with the $8 parking, so I headed up stonewall peak trail then afterwards did Cuyamaca.", "I took this trail up to the peak via Fire Road. It's a paved path and my friend had a dog & it's one of the few trails out there that allows them. You can get to that part of the trail via the Paso Picacho Campground, $8 to park & there's bathrooms. Anyhow, tons of burnt trees out there, but we went on a super foggy morning so it did create sort of this nice, eerie backdrop which allowed for good picture taking :) Saw a bobcat on the way up too. Awesome! Great views pretty much the entire way & wonderful at the top. Breathtaking really. It's not super difficult & plenty of options to stop, rest & take it all in. It's one of my favorite hikes in SD to date & plan to do it again & again. We ventured to Julian after for food & wine tasting - lovely day!", "Super windy this morning. I got an early start, so I didn't see anyone else on the trail until I was on my way back. The fires really did a number to the first portion of the trail, mostly burnt/chopped down pine and cedar trees. The top was much nicer with great views. I took the Azalea Glen trail to the  fire road on the way up and the Conejo trail back to Azalea on the way down. Make sure to get a map at the ranger station.", "Just finished this trail. Went up the Azula Springs side and ran down the road. Took just over two hours. Make sure to stop at the lookout on your way up, the view was so beautiful it surprised me. Insanely windy today so I didn't spend much time at the top but it's the journey not the destination.", 'Did this hike in early January. From a barren wasteland to a lush forest, we made our way through a variety of trails interspersed with patches of snow and fallen trees all culminating in one of the most spectacular views in San Diego. We even got to do some light rappelling and tree climbing at the 6,500 ft peak!

We took the Azalea Glen loop to Azalea Springs, then to Conejos Trail to the Lookout Fire Road finally to the peak. We took the Lookout Fire Road all the way back to starting point for about 7.5 mile loop.

Great moderate hike with a kind of foreboding scenery with all the burnt and fallen trees. The scenery does gradually change and is a nice forest near the peak. The views at the peak are some of the best in Southern California. I definitely recommend this hike as it has it all!

*Parking is $8 so definitely carpool if you can!', "I hit both Stonewall and Cuyamaca peaks in the same November day, starting at the Paso Picacho campground.Both were great hikes with quite a lot of different scenery and beautiful sounds of birds much of the time.  I'm glad I brought a jacket and gloves (and shorts, this is still southern California) - it was chilly in the morning and also chilly/windy on the peaks.  Much of the trek was well shaded as well.All the trails are well marked, so just have a map handy, as there are quite a lot of options if you want to do more than just go up and back.  The whole park is gorgeous!  Bring some binoculars for the tops as well - the views are as well!I saw a fair number of hikers throughout the day, but spread out quite a bit.  I did not see any deer as others have mentioned in the past, bummer!", "If you avoid the fire road, there is almost no one on the trail (even at 11:00am on a saturday). There are a good deal of fallen trees to climb over, but that's part of the fun! I managed to take a wrong turn twice and turned a 4 hour hike into a 5.5 hour hike, so watch your map. The view from the top is beautiful, but the large amount of electrical equipment spoils the ambiance a bit.", 'Went there first weekend of February 2014 and the temp was 37 degrees at the Paso Picacho campground ($8 to park) parking lot.  It was a nice treat to see icicles on the bushes, the trees, even at the tower.  It was a short hike and the trail was very easy to follow.  After all, you are following a fire road.  The peak was very beautiful and the burnt trees offered their own beauty.  Another peak across is the Stonewall Peak which at first glance might seem higher than Cuyamaca but definitely not.  The air got a little thinner towards the top but the air was crisp and very rewarding and worthwhile vista is waiting for you at the top!', 'This was a great hike. I really appreciated how empty the trials were at 8AM. So much fun and serene.', 'Lovely trail all around. I would avoid the access road unless you enjoy walking on asphalt instead of the dirt -- albeit, the access road is substantially shorter. The trail is seldom traveled, I ran into two solo hikers throughout the hike. The chilly temperatures made the experience and little bit more technical, however, the amazing view from the top definitely made the trek worthwhile.', 'Nice trail. Beautiful view from the top. Neat to see the regrowth of the forest, especially on the Conejos trail. ', "Took my 11yo son. parked at Milk Ranch road on the 79. Took it up to Azalea springs fire road with lots of deer on the way. Then took Canejos trail to the peak. Lunch at the peak, then down the lookout road back to Azalea springs fire road. Stopped at the springs.... Nice. Then proceeded back to Milk Ranch. We decided there was enough daylight and energy to tackle Middle peak. So we took the Black oak trail up to the middle peak fire road and back down to the 79. Tons of deer. Some as close as 50' throughout the day. Saw some Turkeys in the early am. Trails were mostly graded fire roads, except for the paved section to the peak. Total distance of 12 miles and 2 mountains hiked. The hot tube in our apartments came in very helpful in recovery. Oh, and the view from the peak is way so worth it...", "I do believe that the 45 min drive to Cuyamaca State Park is worth it once you reach the top of Cuyamaca  Peak. I took the Azalea Glen Trail Loop to Pico Picacho to the Fire Road to the Lookout all the way to the top. If you're in fairly decent shape, then the hike shouldn't be too bad, as its around 7-8 miles round trip. If I had to pick the hardest part of the trail, it would probably be the last 1.5 miles hiking up the fire road is it can get pretty steep, but if you hiked El Cajon mountain in San Diego then it about that same grade or easier. I arrived in the morning and it was about 50 degrees and then later in the afternoon the temperature rose quickly to 70 degrees, so bring clothing to adapt to the environment. Pack a snack or a light lunch to enjoy once you reach the peak. Great photo opportunities at 6512 feet!!", "For climbing up 1500' feet, this was much easier than we thought it would be.  By heading up the Conejos trail - as opposed to just walking straight up the fire road - the grade is much less.  There are also far fewer people; we didn't see anyone until the Conejos trail joined up with the fire road just below the summit.  We did, however, see two groups of deer, plus a number of birds and wildflowers.  Despite being a mile high, we didn't really notice any shortness of breath from the elevation.  The trail is in good shape, and just sort of meanders about through the forest, which is coming back from fires a number of years back.  Because of the elevation, the temperature was comfortable.  Of the various hikes we've done in San Diego (Hot Springs Mtn, Palomar Mtn, Mt Woodson, etc.) this one was our favorite.  And that was even without a view from the top (it was foggy and so the view to the west wasn't very far).  We came back down the fire road, and the total length was 7.4 miles, and it took us right at 3 hours.", 'Went back in January, still fresh snow on the ground, as I got higher up it began to snow some more and made this a very adventurous hike! Would definitely recommend this hike. Beautiful scenery ans an amazIng hike.', 'This trail is absolutely awesome. Very scenic the whole way up. Lots of shade and plenty of spots for rest if you need it. Bringing a camera is a must do for this hike!! Once at the peak there is a rock you can stand on for a great photo op where you can literally be on top of the world. It is very windy and cold once you get to the peak but you will not regret this one especially if you are looking for a getaway from the city.', 'Warning this trail is not kid friendly ,towards the end of this trail there is a huge hill you must hike to get to the end.
however very beautiful make sure to take a camera', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Ahwingna and Native Oak Loop Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'kid friendly', 'birding', 'hiking', 'horseback riding', 'mountain biking', 'nature trips', 'trail running', 'walking', 'forest', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife']
hike_description: Ahwingna and Native Oak Loop Trail is a 4.4 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Whittier, California that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.

user_texts:
['Great hike with good incline/elevation gain as well as stretches of flat ground. Trails are dog friendly and must be kept on leash- unfortunately many people dont pick up after so that is one issue.  Be sure to bring plenty of water and follow the signs as there are many different trails', 'I wish these trails opened early than 9am. during the week Native Oak Trail is lightly trafficked.', 'Please !!! Open it early!! People that work and wants to do some hiking is not able to do it due the horrible schedule ! PLEASE!! 6am at least !!', 'We give it 4 stars because it opens until 9am. We took Coyote trail instead at the trail head because it had more vegetation and incline. You can make these trails as long as you want them, there were trails all over .Great views of Whittier, small but free parking and the trails where trafficked but nice . The only sad part is that people on these trails don’t embrace or don’t know the concept of “leave no trace”. It was sad to see some trash (we picked it up) we saw graffiti on trees (what big of a loser had to do that? ) and seeing pictures of people who picked flowers (food for pollinators, hello) honestly, we don’t live in a fairy tail anymore and it’s not news we must take care of the planet. It was sad...', "Great weather for a hike. So happy that we decided to take this hike. very challenging considering that I'm not an avid hiker. Overall, great experience.", 'This trail definitely didn’t disappoint ', "pretty decent hike, my 5 and 7 year old were able to keep up at a decent pace (for them). I liked the switchbacks and elevation was quick but didn't seem tough. It was a clear day so the views were gorgeous. I would go back to this one again.", 'Nice hike on an overcast morning like today. A few steep hills which I loved. Met some nice people on the Coyote trail. Watch out for the dog poop.', 'Considering I live 10min away from here..I'm always running Azusa canyon for trail running. I decided to hit this trail after work and it turned out to be a good run. They close at 6pm so I didn't get much of the hill. I went up Ahwigna, left on "Coyote" trail (fairly steep) back down Ahwigna. 3.1miles 33min. I will be back SOON!', 'I really got my workout on this hike!!', 'I saw a coyote ', 'Found parking up front but lots of parking on a Monday near the school. Incline was something we both enjoyed as it was not something that lasted extremely long. There’s a part of this hike that is after you come downhill all the way, there’s a beautiful stretch of trees and foliage that made us both fall in love with the hike even more. There’s also quite a bit of shade that made the hike more enjoyable in comparison to Hellman’s Park (in close prox to this trail) that has almost no shade at all. Would come again because of the experience we had—there were also a lot of options for trails which was nice as well. Next time will try the Coyote Trail.', 'Steep. Steep. Steep. Did I say steep. I hike often but this one goes up in a zig zag a lot. I was almost half way up when I had to turn around and go back. There was very little shade. Be careful with all the dog poop.', 'Nice trail Not a lot of parking And the coyote trail was too tough for my kids But over all the trails seemed clean and the views are wonderful', 'nice little hike I always take the the coyote trail, simple', 'Fun hike. It never ceases to amaze me how you can find open spaces in the middle of a metropolis like Los Angeles, this one is just of the Pomona Hwy near Avocado Heights and the City of Industry. Not surprisingly, this trail is heavily trafficked on most parts. Also worth noting is that some parts of the trail are shared with Bikes and Horses, though we only saw a couple of bicyclists and horse apples but no horses. The trail head has a small parking lot, with only a couple of spots but there is more parking down by the street by the Orange Grove Middle School sports field.  Worth noting is that there are many different hikes you can piece together in Hacienda Hills, we did a version of the hike that was closer to 5 miles.', 'Great trail..only downer for the early birds is it doesn’t open till 9am. Other than that..awesome. Different path/trail options once you get started some more difficult and longer than others. Very good workout!', "I really enjoyed this hike. It's a little tough starting out because it's got some pretty steep trail to start. But once you get past the first two real big ones, it's a great hike. It starts uphill, takes you down to the very bottom of the hill in a zig zag pattern. It was nice & cool at the bottom. Beautiful scenery & a great view. Then back up the hill, but not as strenuous as coming in, then back down to the entrance gate & that is just as steep going down as it is coming up. Overall, great hike. I loved it, but wouldn't recommend going when it's too hot.", 'Native Oak trail is heavily shaded and a great up and down trail.  Will not disappointed! Great views too!', 'Great trail. Take it the back way to get max workout!', 'Perfect hike to wear out and over energetic pup...we walked up from the left entrance, it feels like an actual woodsy hike..loved it...but man fucking people need to pick up their dogs shit!!!!', 'looks like an awesome hiking trail. very hard on a bike. they have big rocks to break momentum about every 100 yards. fun but hard', 'A family-friendly trail that has a little bit for everyone; hikers, dogs, and bikers. Unfortunately, this trail now opens at 9 AM so it really limits the distance you want to hike during the warmer days.', 'I loved this trail...the scenic overlook is beautiful. its a great workout and it has some really nice shaded areas. I rate it moderate/hard for beginners.', 'Walked 6 miles upon entering walking on the gravel about 1/4 of a mile on your left I took the trail entrance by the benches..walked up to the top n did the loop...at the end you walk down and have to walk back up then back down to exit....its pretty cool not to hard not too easy...the cool thing is that you can hike from or to Hellman to these trails ...Hellman has very steep hills so you can add or take from or to these hiking trails', 'The entrance to Puma trail from the end of Orange Grove is completely fenced off. We did not see anyway to crawl or climb over the fence. We went to the start of the  Ahwingna Trail from the corner of Orange Grove Ave and 7th Ave. However, the gate is locked and will not opened until 9 am.', 'Nice!', '', '', "Pretty okay hike. I finished it faster than I anticipated. I took the Coyote trail up to the water tank then took the Achwinga trail back down. There's a lot of dead trees/plants. There is also a lot of dog poop on trail, so beware. I'd prefer somewhere more scenic, but it's not a bad hike. The incline is manageable. Good for beginners if you've been active or have hiked places before.", 'Great workout. Very nice trail. Good elevation gain.', "It's a great trail for a cardio workout", 'Its a good workout and its fresh to walk', 'very nice place !! 100% recommended!', 'So much fun took my daughters and nephews Great for kids, ages 10 months, 5 years, 7 years and 9 years', 'Been there a few times. Very steep in parts. Went on coyote trail today. Nicer than the main one but steep. Love the back side of the loop - feels like a forest.', 'not moderate at all....HARD', 'Good hike! Dog friendly and open... make sure to be early, the first part of the hike is pretty full of people but if you complete the whole loop it gets fairly lonely.', 'nice trail to hike. not too strenuous.  you have multiple choices depending how many miles you want to put in.', 'Loved that there is shade!', 'I had not much experience doing this besides basic walks up Industry. I loved this even though my legs were killing me next day.', 'great trail went up coyote trail walked to the tanks and back down the other trail lots of people lots of parking on 7th', 'The trail is overgrown and poorly marked and it is infested with foxtail. It was amazing. My 13 year old daughter and I did this as part of a 7 mile loop and we feel amazing despite the heat, the pollen and the bugs.', "this trail is great, it got's steep inclines for you to work those legs and once you get to the top you got an amazing view of the city. the trail does narrow a bit where your walking on the edge so be careful . and please for those of you who take your dogs pick up after them nobody like's stepping on land mines. enjoy your hike.", '', 'Great trail. Very nice scenery and some great inclines!', 'Great Day full of flowers.', 'Great views, plenty of parking, and allows dogs. I will be coming back.', 'A good place to hike.', 'MUY BONITO PARA CAMINAR CORRER HIKING Y MTB', 'nice', 'What a beautiful place! I will definitely return!', 'Great quad workout! My endurance was tested.', "It's was just beautiful after the rain. The Tarik was well kept and the views were gorgeous. It was closed because of the rain but it was really easy to hop the fance.", "I do this trail in a regular. It's a good work out/hike that's close by", 'it was very good I hike it almost every weekend I love it.', 'CLOSED!', "Great workout. I do this pretty often when I want to get a good hike in close by. You park off 7th and Orangegrove in Hacienda Heights. After a quarter mile walk up the gravel road, I branch off to the left up the Coyote trail. There's pretty good elevation gains that can tire you out if you're not ready for it. The trail has a lot of switch backs. Once you get to the top of the first hill, at the electric towers, you can start heading back down toward where you started, OR you can decide to complete the beast and take the half mile level walk to the next set of hills, which are larger, with more elevation gains and switchbacks. I like the second part better because it's far more beautiful. It's a lot more foresty (I know that's not a word, but you get it.) overall the trail is mostly shade covered, with the long middle stretch out in the open. It's a really good workout and comes in around 5-6 miles.", 'I really enjoyed this hike. Beautiful and just challenging enough for a moderate work out. However, I hiked the coyote hills trail and about a mile and half up the hill, I saw a group of 4 coyotes together. I was alone with my dog, so we turned around. I would only come back with a group.', 'The trail is a good moderate course, be careful with bikers coming behind you need to constantly be looking behind you, other than that this trail is awesome and guaranteed for a great workout..', 'Great for early morning hike with the rising sun! Hiked on a Sunday and very popular for hikers, bikes, and dogs. Even though there were many people on the trail, it did not impede our hike. Views are spectacular, sky so clear you could see the snow capped mountains!', "nice hike with good elevation gain + distance that doesn't burn you out.  good panoramas of the city and wasn't that crowded on a weekday.  entrance is right off 7th Ave and trails are marked well", 'I enjoy this trial, would be a 5 star if people picked up after their dogs.', 'Very good trail besides there being a lot of', 'wonderful', 'love it', 'it was a grate hike , BUTT I had to watch where I was walking do to the Dogs poop', 'Good hike, moderate to hard depending on your fitness level. Not easy. Secluded areas, well traveled but would not hike alone. Nice scenery. Will definitely go back,', 'Do not depend on GPS for directions. It led me to Rose Hills Cemetery on Workman Mill Road.', 'Excelente !!!!', 'love this hike! If you like some elevation this hike gets  it done! You hike uphill for about 40  minutes and then options are endless, you can hike to the water tower or trekk around and back down if you choose. Only complaint is the trails are not marked.', "Took like a 3 hour hike.  Got lost but on purpose.  Definitely a great hiking experience.  Can't wait to return", 'Fun trail', 'Good hike, great got bikes as well.', 'This was an awesome trail! Starts out with some decent climbing in elevation then opens up once you crest the peak. The power towers are so majestic up close, and the water tower is a fun trip!', "Lots of hills to climb. Keep a lookout for snakes. A lot of people use this trail and it's we'll defined. Many routes to choose from. Coyote trail offers a lot of shade and so does Oak Canyon. The water tower trail has the hardest hills.", 'Got lost, went for an hour hike. Took 5 hours to get out.', 'Nice trail', 'Nice trail and a good view once you get to the top at the water tower.', 'I love this hike! I came down the Coyote trail.', 'I do a 7 mile loop Nice moderate work out', 'Hiked Coyote trail which is to the left at fork and was a very good uphill hike.  great workout. dog friendly. would go again.', 'awesome', 'Easy parking, not crowded & more then one trail to choose from.', 'it was good.  broke a small sweat. will most likely go again.', "this is one of my favorites. it's not the hardest but it gives you a good sweat. easy to get to and it loops so you just keep going. once at the top there are so many other trails and a beautiful views. I've done most of these trails, but like I said this is one of my favorites... not a lot of shade so wear sunscreen!!", 'love it', 'I tried to do a loop and end up on Orange Grove but there is a fence now. It looks new. There are signs warning you though but overall a nice hike', 'Hot and dusted.', 'It was easy to follow the trail. There are giant towers, they were pretty cool looking.', '', 'hard trail.. love it', 'HIKING RUNNING WALKING BIKING', 'Fun great place', 'a good views good workout a gets u tried.', 'wheel chair access well kept trail but would prefer more shade', 'its pretty hard, from 7th street about a quarter of a mile up, is where the difficulty starts... its just constant uphill. I will come back again as a work out trail.', 'Great', 'Great trail, some climbing, beautiful scenic views, once you get to the top there are Two water towers. Bike riders with action helmet cams. Dog friendly! semi kid friendly more for older kids.', 'try running it.. challenging.. never gets easier', 'It was pretty neat had to jump the fence though. But very quiet and serene.', "Love it.  2nd time here.  Brought  my 10year old and he loved it..  He can't wait for the next adventure.. Awesome hiking.", "If you want a good challenge for a trail run, this one's pretty good. Running partner made me run up to the hill, its a steady incline to the top. At the top you have a great view of the city. We didn't do the full 7 miles.", 'nice... moderate incline. Enjoyed the views.', "This is a beauty! The views early in the morning are to die for! I bet sunsets are breath taking too!! If Turnbull is crowded, come here. You won't be disappointed, just make sure to bring plenty of water, shades and a hat! Very little to no shade on this hike.", 'Good workout', 'Awesome a really good challenge', 'Steep, not too much shade, dusty on sunny day, not for kids. Good work out for adults :)', 'Wonderful', "This hike was enjoyable - took it during the summer, so it was definitely a warm experience with various amounts of shade along the way. Not the most beautiful hiking trail (not too green these days, more earthly brown hues and slightly polluted skies) but ... it was a really good workout, easy to navigate, easy to get to (which is not always easy to find), and we didn't pay for parking. Good hiking experience if you're looking for a good morning workout in that area.", 'Hiked about a mile into the coyote trail with my dog this morning. Due to the heat (82°F at 11:30am) we cut it short, doing an out & back rather than a loop. Trail was nice, well-marked, with a decent amount of shade. Moderate intensity going up and a little tricky coming down with the loose gravel. Definitely coming back, but earlier!', 'By far one of my favorite trails!  You can pick the level of difficulty you want. I believe I did the coyote trail (moderate) and it was perfect.', '', 'Sweating it all out', 'Fun', 'BEWARE!! DO NOT TAKE THE LOOP AS MARKED. The only entrance/exit is off 7th St, the other gates off of Orange Grove Ave, Autumn Moon Dr, and Los Robles are locked and inaccessible, unless you can jump over 6ft tall gates. If you start at 7th St and go up Ahwinga trail, head left at Skyline instead of right to Puma trail unless you are ok hiking about 4 extra winding miles back to Ahwinga. THERE IS NO LOOP TRAIL AVAILABLE.', 'This is a  very good utilitarian trail.

If you live in the eastern portions of the greater Los Angeles area and have a new pair of boots, trail runners,  breathable rain gear, pack, or other hiking gear which you would like to test, then this trail is a good proving ground for "test driving" this gear. The trail is located in the San Gabriel Valley, a bit South of the City of Industry and off of the 60 Freeway; about 15 to 20 minutes to the east of Downtown Los Angeles (on the weekend).  So, quite accessible during the weekends (I say weekends because the 60 Freeway gets very congested during the work week.).  The first mile or so of the trail is all uphill with about 767 feet of elevation gain, followed by about a quarter of a mile to one-half mile of level ground, and the rest is all down hill.  This trail profile will give one a good idea of how well the new gear performs.  This trail is a part of a larger trail system managed by the Puente Hills Habitat Preservation Authority, which will give one considerable flexibility in testing gear.  If the approximately4 miles of this loop trail is not enough for one to get a feel for the new gear, then one can take any one of the connected trails and extend the test run up to 12 miles of up hills, down hills, and rocky slopes with lose dirt.

In addition to providing a convenient location to test equipment, this trail is also a good place to ease into the start of a hiking season.  Depending upon the trails taken in this network of trails, one can get from 700 to 1000 feet of elevation gain, much of it in the first mile.   This moderate elevation gain will serve as a nice way to ease the body back into trail shape.   Since the trail is in the San Gabriel Valley, it starts at about sea level, so there is no issue with having to deal with higher altitudes.

Finally, this trail is a good place for those who want to make trail running and mountain biking a part of a varied fitness routine.  However, if one is looking to commune with nature during one's fitness routine, then this is not the place.  The fact that this trail is managed by the Puente Hills Habitat Preservation Authority pretty much says it all.  This Authority was  created to acquire and manage green space, for public use, in order to balance the effects of the Puente Hills Landfill, the largest landfill in the United States.  This green space is bordered by a few suburban bedroom communities, a middle school, the 60 Freeway, the aforementioned landfill, and the Rose Hills mortuary and cemetery; all of which are visible, or in case of the Freeway heard, at times on the trail, in addition to the power lines and towers crossing the trail at places.    This is not to say the trail is anything like an urban park trail where one is essentially hiking on fire access roads.  The trail is really well maintained and marked, and the users are generally respectful and appreciative of it.  This trail is even much better than some of the more accessible trails in the Angeles National Forest (now National Monument).  Also, though hikers will be sharing some of this network of trails with mountain bikers and horse riders, there are trails in this network which are for hiker's only.  

In sum, a  nice, accessible trail.  Free parking, but very limited.  There is plenty of street parking in the nice residential neighborhood.', 'Good alternative to Hellman. On the back side of the same hills. Actually connects to Hellman at the top of the ridge. Some shade over a lot of the trail. Steep canyon in the center and switch back trails on either side. Coyote trail pretty steep, better to go up the main trail and back down coyote.', 'This trail is cool as in shady so I liked that. However the mountain bikers were a bit nerve racking.I wouldnt wear my ear phones as some mountain bikers flying down the mountain will not yell out to give you a heads up.', "hiking with my dog, good for a beginnermake sure u where hiking shoes/bootsI'd do it again, meet some cool ppl with there kids also.", "I hike and go mountain biking here and it's so much fun. Many trails to try when hiking from easy to advanced trails and for mountain biking plenty of jumps to hit on the way down", 'This is a cool little spot to go hiking and mountain biking! They have steep inclines that just let you be free and forget about everything! beautiful scenery and close to downtown LA.', 'Very nice hike!! My kids love it!', "This is my favorite of all the Habitat Authority managed trails.  I like to hit this after work.  you can make it a approximate 3, 4, or 5 mile loop.  You'll find some steep inclines and panoramic views of the San Gabriels to the north, and all the way to Catalina to the south on a clear day.  Some of the trails permit mt. bikes, so keep your ears open!", 'I LOVE this beautiful trail but HATE all the bikers flying down!', 'I took my daughter (4 years old) and she loved it. There were some difficult sections for her but overall it was very safe. Definitely going again.', 'Good hike! Easy to get lost and has a lot of diversity!', 'Went there today with my dog (Tuesday) and there were a few mountain bikers (that come flying down the hills so look out) but not many hikers. I got kind of scared if I am honest. LOL! Next time I will bring a buddy because it is kind of deserted on weekdays (today is new years so that could be part of it too.) Good trails. I fell coming down so I could recommend shoes with better traction or hiking pole thing. Good workout.  Takes me about 1 hour and 40 minutes to complete. (Edited to add, check your dog for ticks after this one.)', "Took my boys ages 8,5, and 4 on this hiking trail! This is only their 2nd adventure hiking!  I didn't realize this trail is on the backside of Turnbull Canyon! I prefer this hike as it was more colorful and seemed taken care of! The boys wished for a waterfall! I would pack snacks for your break at the top! And bring bug spray!!!!", "Trailhead is easy to find, and right off the freeway. There are only a few spots for hiking, but there is parking available in the residential neighborhood. 

Trail is well kept and pretty well used. It's a good hike with sections of dense trees further in. During the summer, it's incredibly dry, dusty and hot. It's a a little less than moderately challenging hike. Steep hills at points, but levels out. Great place to trail run and be in mind that you share the trail with mtn bikers.", 'Wow....what a work out!  Lots of uphill action to get your heart pumping and quads burning.  everything was brown and dry in the heat of the summer, but we did spot four deer on our hike.  The mountain bikers come flying down the hills, so if you hike with music, keep one ear clear', 'good workout and elevation gain. not impressed with the scenery compared to other hiking trails.  when you get close to middle of the loop look down for the car at the bottom of the mountains, that was kinda cool. lots of wildlife.', 'Pleasantly surprised!  I typically hike mt wilson,  never realized that this trail existed without trails.com.  The trail is a five minute drive from my house and the intensity is perfect for some decent cardio.  I like the various looping and connecting trails and I am feeling motivated to do some mountain biking!  This will definitely be a frequent trail for me and my wife.', 'This trail was really awesome!!! What I liked most about it was that every direction had two routes. One route for easy hiking and one route for difficult hiking. (My group of 4 at one point split in 2 groups of 2 on a trail that had a difficult and easy route. By the time we both reached the end, we were able to easily find each other). The views on this trail were beautifully pleasing to the eyes! There were people here with their dogs and children so go get out there and have a fun hike with the family!', "I recommend to thoses who haven't hike on this trail you will enjoy it...", 'a very good Hike. nice scenery just be careful with the rattle snakes...', 'NICE!', 'One of my favorite trails. You can mountain bike and run it. Great workout and beautiful view in the spring.', 'Good, semi-steep trail. Shaded at points, but can get warm in open ground. Views throughout are worth the climb. Even saw a coyote. Lots of hikers and trail can be narrow at points so hike early.', 'amazing views once you get high enough up the hill.  narrow trail and green shrub all around. lots of rabbits and birds. dog friendly!', 'Beautiful', "I had fun hiking on this trail making a loop using the Ahwinga Trail and I believe Coyote Trail? Anyways, pretty steep at first but well worth it for the views. Ended up going to the Turnbull Canyon Water Tower in the middle which made this hike well worth it. I recommend it for that sight, it's a muse see in person. Way back was narrow and not as hard as going up. Good overall. So do it ya weenie!", 'Nice steep trail so you get a good workout, but the payoff is views in all directions. Betting on a clear day you might see the ocean. Downtown LA was beautiful in the distance. Lots of mountain bikes though, so have to be careful. Took our kids and they enjoyed it also.', "This was my first hike and I really enjoyed it.  Parking is free either at the school parking lot across the street or on the street.  I got there for a 9am group hike with the Puente Hills Preserve Hikers that I joined through Meetup.com.  I really loved how green the trail was with just hints of flowers here and there.  Even though we came across other hikers and bikers, it wasn't crowded and their were pockets where our group were the only ones visible.  The inclines weren't too severe and they were doable at a slower pace.  I'm goin' back again, enjoy!", "Very nice nature trail. Many trails to take. Did this as a loop. Trails along the ridge were forest like. Only negative I'd say is the construction at top, but you can walk right through it", 'This place needs some signage!  Otherwise, I enjoyed the hike.  I ended up doing some of the trails twice to complete a double figure eight type loop. If you start on the ahwingna trail it is really easy to miss the native oak trail split, as its almost behind you as you walk by where it intersects. If you catch that trail then you can do a kind of double figure eight to see most of this section of the Puente Hills.  The views are surprisingly good and you can see the ocean on a clear day.  Nice hike hidden in the middle of suburbia, 5.4 out of 10.', 'Hidden gem with connecting trails.   Very crowded.  Recommend doing early or late afternoon.  Bicylists are not mindful of hikers so be weary.', 'Hidden gem.  Plenty of trails to take from easy to hard.  Have done several times and will definitely return as the time changes.', 'A very nice and moderate hiking experience. Very easy to find the entrance, and conveniently outlines the different trails one can take. The trail we took kept us sweating with our heart rate up -not difficult, just a good workout. The only cons potentially involved were the little bugs (flies) that somewhat followed you everywhere and the lack of rocks or spots to sit along the way. But really, these are small nuances. I definitely enjoyed the hike and the sights along the way.', 'I hike the trail today and was a little confuses with the directions. There are 2 place you can start the hike. The directions all trails directed me to was at the end of Orange St. However the actual trail head is at the corner of 7 St and Orange; which has a map with a overview of the area. You need to park on the street because there is only 5 parking space at the trail head. I would suggest that you bring plenty of water and a camera; there are some great viewing points.  Most likely will do this hike again but will start earlier in the mourning. This time of the year it really get hot.', 'Was kinda disappointed with this hike. Read the reviews and was really looking forward to a more picturesque hike with more of nature to see as well as creeks. Did see a lot of rabbits, lizards and deer. Overall it was a pretty good workout.', "This is part of a wonderful set of trails tucked in the eastern part of LA County.  I run these trails often, and there is a variety of terrain along the trail, from fire roads to single track.  The environment definitely changes as you move from the shaded canyons to the open coastal sage and scrub at the ridge lines.  The initial climbs can be a challenge, but once at the top it flattens out and you're treated to an expansive view of Southern California.", 'Fun hike with great views. Moderate amount of people--It is not the most secluded trail.', 'I love these trails there are so many. They got me to really start enjoying hiking. You have your saturday or sunday morning hike going up thru 7th st trail and then also your after work trail coming from Turnbo Cyn / Beverly  both leading to the victory "Water Tower". It awsome cant wait to experience other trails. ', 'Amazing hiking. A mix between hiking and history with beautiful nature surround. I recommend a good hiking shoes, plenty of water.', 'This is a great trail to go for a quick trail run or a relaxing hike through the canyon.  Dogs are not allowed on this side of the ridge and there are also a lot less people.  By going up the ridge you can connect to the Hellman loop for a round trip of 6.5 miles.  You can also branch off and go to the water tower or rattlesnake ridge.  Its not the most amazing hike you will go on but being so close its a great place to go after work.', 'This is a good trail accessable from many different areas if you just feel like going for a nice one or two hour hike.  It branches off from Schbarum park and goes up the mountain near the top of Azusa Ave.  One section goes to Hacienda Blvd and stops.  You can also access from Hacienda Hills near 7th Ave.  All in all a good hike with alot of wildlife.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Overlook Trail to McWay Falls - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['wheelchair friendly', 'kid friendly', 'stroller friendly', 'hiking', 'nature trips', 'walking', 'beach', 'views', 'waterfall', 'wildlife', 'no dogs']
hike_description: Overlook Trail to McWay Falls is a 0.4 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Big Sur, California that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and nature trips and is best used from September until December.
