user_texts:
['Due to the partial government shutdown, the gate leading up to the parking lot is currently closed. You can still park at the bottom and walk up an extra 3-4 miles though. Wish I could have known this before driving an hour and a half!!!', 'Very good and very challenging hike. Some steep cliffs with long drops; watch where you step! The ascent wasn’t too tough but the descent down the winter creek trail was brutal; bring poles if you have them. Was bothered by bugs at times but not overwhelming. Would hike again!', 'Awesome 15 miles hike!!!', '15 miles! Great hike', 'Awesome loop hike. Bugs were really bad. I had to hike with a head net from strutevant camp to the summit. My GPS had me at 15.7 miles.', 'Wow what a butt kicker...Beautiful trail. Took the lower trail out ( this is the trail from the lower parking lot. It was shaded almost all the way to the top of Mt Wilson. I didn’t run into any bugs not even at the top. Up to the camp the trail is pretty moderate after that it’s all incline and you will feel it. We arrived around 6:15 am and there was only about 4 parking spots left. Not sure about the overflow parking. On the weekends there is a cafe open at the top of Mt Wilson and there are restrooms as well.', 'First hike for the Six Pack of Peaks challenge and I loved it. Went on a Wednesday and only saw 3 people the entire hike. The trailhead to go back down is kinda hidden, once you are in big parking lot look to the right. Would for sure do again!', 'I did this yesterday and it was very enjoyable. First the parking was super packed at 9:30am already. I did I two round in the lots then I was trying to find on the road and there was a nice guy pointing at his car that he’s leaving! Thank you sir!!Anyway if I didn’t know about the trail, I would be sure to get lost. So you should check where the trail sprit. And like everyone said here it’s not 12 miles. It’s more like 16miles. (My phone die on the way coming down, so there is no accuracy but I was glad that I made it to parking lot) Last couple of miles going up was tough. I kept stopping and looking up when this uphill/switchback end. I finished my entire 1.5l water going up so make sure you have enough water and snack to refill. Cosmic cafe save my life on summit. Going down from summit was confusing. There is no sign going down. I had to walk around the parking lot and observatory gate. There is a trail in the middle of parking lot. But again no sign!Downhill was easy but sandy and easy to slide so be careful. At the white creek ? Trail sprit and I had no strength to go uphill at the beginning of trail, so I went right to chantry flat for another 3 miles. Going up and down, there is plenty of gnat and mosquitoes. Be sure to spray bug spray everywhere and I saw a sign that there is a bear so maybe bring a bear bell. I saw a deer family running by me and looking at me so it was a delightful moment and that it self made my day.', 'Excellent training hike - I took the loop via Stuyvesant camp to the top and returning on the opposite side. 1st thee+ miles felt great - I started early to avoid the heat (6:00am) and bugs. Once I passed Stuyvesant though the uphill kicked in. There is some serious uphill for 3 miles so be prepared for a long slog. The observatories, exhibits and cafe were a welcome respite while preparing for the descent. The descent is tough - what goes up steep will come down steep so pace yourself.My GPS unit had me at 15 miles and I spent a little over 7 hours on the hike (3 hrs up, 2 1/4 hr down and about 1.5 hrs trying to recover at the top and during the steep switchbacks). Key is to pace yourself and just keep moving.Because of the lower elevation, heat will play a bigger factor so watch out - the downhill was interminable but the last 1/2 mile climb to the parking lot in 93+ degree heat was rough when your tired and ready to be done lolLeaving early helped minimize the bugs while the afternoon sleep also seemed to have tempered them. I really only saw the gnats and they were less than many other trailsOverall excellent hike that let me know I had done some hiking! Be proud of your accomplishment', 'Great hike! However, like previous reviews stated it’s more that 12.6 miles. My fitness watch doc’d it as 17. 7 miles. Cafe at observatory was a lifesaver. Note: they close at 5pm.We will def be back!', 'Great hike super easy overnighter but tons of bugs', "Definitely challenging. Gnats, mosquitos, and poison oak are in full effect. Going up thru Sturtevant is particularly steep in last 2-3 miles to the summit; other side is more gradual. But the entire trail was shaded (at least 80%, minus the summit).All Trails' directions leads you to the summit (DON'T USE IT). Google Maps to Chantry Flats. We clocked the full loop at 14-16 miles, not the 12.6 miles on All Trails.Cosmic Cafe is a legit place to eat. Apple pie with ice cream was out of this world!", 'completed this trail last weekend and we knew it was rated difficult but the mileage is way off. it says 12.6 but we charted 16.2 miles with an apple watch. make sure you have a full day to complete this hike. if you are not in top shape it will take you more than half the day. beautiful hike and definitely recommend.', 'Did a solo trip with my dog. It was my first time making it all the way to mt wilson. Very difficult after sturtevant camp cabins all up hill. Amazing views. Definitely will go back on a cooler day.', 'Awesome!!! Great views, mostly no sun. It’s 7 miles uphill and 7 miles downhill. On top they have a coffee shop only open Saturday and Sunday. I went memorial weekend the weather was perfect but it was 39 degrees on top lol. But my husband and I have such a wonderful time. I would gladly do it again.', 'Doing the six peak challenge and was told this was the easiest to start with. It’s actually really hard! It’s the lowest in elevation out of the peaks but has a very steal incline. I was expecting something easier. It is shaded almost all the way up which is definitely a positive. We we were sore for days after this hike!', "Hiked this on Saturday 5/26.   Arrived at 06:15 and parking was full.  Luckily found a good spot on the road just outside the lot (when I got back cars were parked miles down the road!)Nice hike up the creek and some nice waterfalls.  Re-fueled at Stuyvesant (sp?) camp.   Going got tougher after that with steep switchbacks,   Got to the top in a little over 3 hours.   Low cloud made it a complete whiteout unfortunately - and it was COLD!   A bowl of chili at the Cosmic Cafe warmed things up.The way down was much easier but interminable!  The only time I had any concerns was at around 12 miles where the trail split and the sign was confusing.   Apparently both options take you back to Chantry Flats.  I took right (upper winter creek I think).   A climb initially by then flat until the descent to Chantry Falls.   Some nice wildflowers and squabbling Stellar's Jays!A tough hike but a great day out!", 'Loved this hike.  Went with a group of 4 other ladies.  Part of the SoCal 6 Peak Challenge.  We ended up doing about 18 miles of hiking.  Very very challenging.  This was the first of our six, lowest in elevation, but one of the toughest as incline.  The last 3 miles going up is lots of switchbacks and steep, narrow trail.  Loved the following the creek almost all the way up.  It did rain throughout our hike,  but the tree acted as a nice umbrella for us.  Cold once we got to the peak and our body temps started to cool down as we rested.  Loved the Cafe on top, nice lunch and headed back down.  Start your hike very early so you can get out before dark.', 'The directions from this site will take you all the way up to the peak- so just search for Chantry Flats address instead. The peak itself has little to offer, Other than that this is a beautiful place- long walk. The switchbacks are steep so be prepared to burn some calories. Have fun!', 'I am writing this after my ibuprofen has had a chance to kick in the day after! I am an older, slower hiker but I peaked this mountain yesterday. It was challenging yet so rewarding. It became steep after Spruce Grove Campground. The shaded, foggy trail kept me cool...making the uphill trudge more bearable. I loved reaching the top and going to the lookout area immediately to the right when you summit. You will find the elevation/Mt. Wilson sign there. After that, a trip to the Cosmic Cafe for some tasty food is a well earned treat.I thought I got off trail on the way down.  I would recommend getting the map at the little store at Chantry Flats. It includes the locations of all  the campgrounds, call boxes, river crossings, etc. and can be helpful when your electronic devices don’t work.  My phone tracked this hike as a 17.5 miler...but that includes my doubling back when I thought I had gone off the trail I was supposed to be on AND  getting to my car parked a ways from the trailhead. If I can do it, you probably can too!', 'Did this route counter clockwise.  It’s not 12.6 miles, more like 17.5 from our car at chantry flats.  Beautiful hike up & down.  I was pleasantly surprised how much I liked it.  Trail gets pretty steep from sturtevant campground up to the summit.  We also had great weather.', 'Did this hike Saturday. Hard but enjoyable.  We didnt have gps, but thank goodness another hiker did. We would have gotten lost for sure. Hiked up the backside first. Road less traveled.  On the way down lots of trail splits.  Ended up going 15.52 miles in 5.52 hours. Mt Wilson is badly marked and no elevation sign at top for photo op! Doing the 6 Pack of Peaks. 1 down 5 to go. Cucamonga  Peak is next.', 'We hiked Mt Wilson early April. If you plan to hike during the weekend, make sure you arrive no later than 6am if you want to park in the lot. It gets filled really quick. As for the hike, it was a fun hike with the stream crossings. We did the loop around  14.6 miles in about 7 hours.  Check out our YouTube video: https://youtu.be/HKCKhwmzuk8Or YouTube search: Socal hikes and beyond', "Just went this past weekend with a hiking group starting out the 6 pack, and it was such a great time! We got there as soon as the trailhead opened and there was a line at the gate to get in, completely packing the parking lot as son as the gates opened a little after 6, so I would definitely recommend getting there at opening time like we did. Plus it takes pretty much all day anyway to hike it. restrooms at the trail head. Need Adventure pass (available at trailhead) or National parks pass to park or you will get ticketed. Let me just say, I was so impressed with the accommodations at the top! Actual bathrooms, running (hot!) water, a cafe with fresh hot food, coffee, plenty of seating-- such a great stop for lunch, I wish I brought money for coffee or something! A bit bummed we didn't take a picture with the sign, I couldn't find it. A bunch of cool camping spots on the way up, offering both cabin lodging or regular tent camping spots, might go back for camping some time. Folks at one of the cabins even offered us coffee and let us meet and greet with their puppers! I would recommend bringing bear spray-- although we didn't see any on our hike, we did see evidence of them, and they have been spotted frequently. Also bug spray, it got a bit buggy towards the end but not super horrible. TONS of poison oak lining the trail, so be mindful. Shaded most of the way and still went through 3 liters of water. Great views from the top, neat little places to check out along the way (including a tree swing, volleyball court, archery etc at one of the camping spots), beautiful waterfalls as an added bonus :)", 'Hiked to the summit Thursday, April 12, 2018 on a beautiful clear day.  Three of us went up Winter Creek Trail to the top and then down Sturtevant trail and connected with Gabrileno Trail (meets this trail at the Sturtevant campsite) back to Chantry Flats.   The full loop was 13.75 miles of which the last 1/2 mile was a fairly steep (albeit on a paved road) climb which was a bit of a kick in the teeth after going that distance and being an Illinois flat lander!   At first having reached the summit I was like “I wouldn’t rate this a hard climb” but after finishing the full loop I would concur that it is a hard level hike due to the length and unless you are used to hiking long distances don’t take it lightly.   Great views from the “bench” which you reach at about the 5 mile point on the way up.   We could see all the way to the coast and great perspective of Los Angeles.This was our first of the Six pack we hope to achieve over the next couple years while our son goes to school out in SoCal!Great time of year to go I guess as we had no gnats or flies (which apparently are a big issue on the hike later in the summer).', 'Great hike.  Steep from Sturtevant Camp to just past 1/2 way rest area.   Cosmic Cafe for food open weekends.  Great scenery.  Mostly shaded.    Very busy from Chantry Flat to Sturtevant Falls but not bad after.  Depending on time of year can be lots of bugs.  Adventure Pass needed to park or you can buy one at trailhead for $5.00 day pass.  Part of 6 Pack of Peaks.    Went on Tuesday and only saw 5 hikers including one idiot who liked to talk loud on cell phone and liked to talk about terrorist.   If you read this, please stop hiking, your an idiot.', 'Awesome hike! Make sure to leave before 8pm.(We got locked in.) :0)', "This is a fun and strenuous hike.  There is good tree cover and there are a few places along the trail where it's easy to take a wrong turn, so I'd recommend paying close attention.  The observatory and cosmic cafe at the top are fun features.  If you're in the mood for seclusion, this may not be the hike for you, but if you're feeling like a mountaintop banana split, then go for it.", "I did this hike today and my biggest tip is be prepared. If it's in the winter or not even entered spring, bring a snow jacket because it is COLD and possibly snowing at the top of the mountain. Bring food, electrolytes, enough water, hiking poles (it DOES help), and maps. 

I would definitely take screenshots on ways to get up to the mountain and down the mountain, it helped so much when my friend and I missed some turns. If a beginner went on this hike, I'd start early. We started close to 8 and it still took us about 7 hours, not counting the hour we spent at the summit. The difficulty of this hike is high because of the TIME it takes to complete it. Like it's JUST long. SO long... I didn't experience any bugs at all, but there are PLENTY of poison oak at the beginning of the hike, so wear long sleeve and pants. I feel very proud to have completed this because it is a challenge.", 'This trail is a great long hike for beginners! It was for sure a challenge, but very doable and well populated. Had read a lot about bug issues, but this time we experienced no bugs at all! The viewpoint at the top had some gorgeous sites and after a little walk through the parking lot, there was a great place with tables to hang out and take a break. Great hike! :)', 'Definetly worth the hike. Gets pretty tough past Sturtevant   campgrounds especially carrying 40 lbs of weight backpacking.', 'Awesome no bugs right now', "It was a really intense hike. The waterfall at the beginning wasn't worth the extra mile. All the buildings on the first and last mile were kind of creepy walking alone in the woods (I'm guessing they're all rented out and full of life in the summer but right now it feels like a scary movie). The views were nice, I feel like there are better ones in the area, though.

I'm happy because I wanted something fairly challenging and definitely got that. Also I got there at about 7:30am on a Tuesday and saw a total of 9 people on the trail, so that was awesome", 'NO BUGS IN JANUARY Do to a temporary road closure from the recent rain and rock slides, we had to improvise and start at the top, then loop down and end back at the top. My girlfriend and I just completed this loop on an overnighter while backpacking. We camped at Spruce Grove camp. Amazing hike and beautiful views the whole way. Definitely bring trekking poles for this type of elevation gain. If you don’t have poles you can rent them at adventure 16 for $7 the first day and $2 every additional day.  Also I read so many reviews about how terrible the bugs are on this hike. Let me say that we had no problems with bugs at all as we hiked the loop earlier this month (January). Cheers!', 'What a great hike. Long. 15.2 miles. Great elevation gain. Hiking poles are a must. Bring plenty of water. Enjoy the views!', "Lots of elevation makes this trail challenging, but it's absolutely worth it. Gorgeous scenery and a beautiful observatory at the top. This trail is a must!", 'great hike! perfect way to spend Thanksgining.  although we were going to try to make it up to Zion, luckily a fellow hiker told us the sign located near the campground is wrong it says it is only 1.5 miles more. Really is 3 to 4 miles more, glad we asked. ', 'Rosa was visiting her family so I took our 8 year old son who had some difficulty but the snack bar at the top was worth it.', "Be mindful that the directions for this trail lead you to the peak of Mt Wilson, meaning you hike down the mountain first, then back up. Also, the trailhead can only be accessed after 10 am, it's behind a locked gate until then, with no access. The views are beautiful and it's cool to see the equipment up on the mountain, the amount of flies ruined the hike for me.", "Very strenuous hike but beautiful and serene. I took the Chantry Flats loop but took a side trail to Switzer falls before heading to Mt Wilson using the upper trail.  This was a very challenging hike given the steepness & elevation change.  Hiking poles a definite must have.  I thought I packed enough water but consumed every bit of the two liters with another half mile to get to the top.  The elevation change was a major factor as I was affected with altitude sickness which caused me to drink more water in order to avoid dehydration.  I began feelings leg & ankle cramps by the time I reached the top.  After a much needed break & late lunch I made sure to consume/pack excess water for the trek down.  I strongly recommend packing at least three liters of water to ensure staying hydrated. Next time I'll try the lower trail but will definitely be more prepared with at least three liters of water.  Also be advised, the mosquitos & gnats are relentless, you will be under attack the entire length of the trail.  Strongly encourage long sleeves, full pants, head/face net and/or bring some deet or Off to spray over your clothing if nothing else. Otherwise it will not be a fun trip. Happy trails.", "Great hike! Lots a varied terrain and foliage.  Great views as you get to the top.  A lot of shade helps the temps, though it covers views as you head up, but I'll take that trade! Saw several deer at Spruce Grove camp. It was way too hot (90+) when I went, but otherwise is a manageable hike.  No joke about the bugs. Bring a head net and forget worrying about how it looks.  I gave five stars for doing this when it's NOT 95 degrees.", 'The bugs really took away from the fun of the hike. Enjoyed the first and last few miles along the creek. Bugs started about 3 miles in once the trail leaves the creek.', 'Bugs and flies were unrelenting today. Beautiful sweeping views! The trail seemed to take forever in the summer heat. Bring lots of water, bug spray and sunscreen.', 'Hike was great except for the bugs!  We fought swarming gnatlike bugs all day. Insect repellent had no effect, as bugs would not land or bite. They just swarmed around your face constantly. At times a face net would have been great.', 'After an attempt to summit here in March that had to be cut short, we decided to start early and give it a full go. We went counterclockwise, and got a treat of the stream and falls on the way up. I enjoyed the telescopes at the top, as well as logging benchmarks and finding some geocaches. Then the hike down the familiar route taken in March got us back with plenty of daylight to spare.

https://youtu.be/2-L6wz4weEs', "This is a challenging hike and the day we did it was the hottest day in So Cal this year.  The amount of bugs on the way up were insane.   There was a good 3 miles of continuously swatting them away from my face.  We only stopped once about 4 miles in and only for a couple minutes because we didn't want to get slaughtered by the bugs.  Very cool streams and waterfalls and the hike is shaded by trees the whole time.  I'm glad I did it but felt reaching the top was uninspiring.  This one was more like a exercise in self torture with no great views at the top.  Definately go in cooler weather.", "Great hike! Bug repellent was definitely not enough for the amount of bugs you will encounter. The hike up is mostly shaded, and pretty easy to follow with great signs leading the way. The last 2 miles or so of switchbacks were definitely a killer, but aside from that, the hike was pretty doable. We took the old toll road down and there wasn't many shaded areas so a hat and sunscreen are highly recommended. If you have bad knees or bad ankles, trekking pole will help greatly. There is a little cafe at the summit which is only open on the weekends. And there are bathrooms and places to fill your water on top. Get there early to get a good parking spot!", "No parking at the trailhead by 6:50, had to park 0.8 mi down the road. Lower part of the trail was packed, but closer to the summit there weren't many people. Got eaten alive by bugs (20 bites on one leg, through leggings), and it didn't seem like it was just mosquitos, someone mentioned that there are horseflies in June. Cafe at the top had good food, but staying at the top for an hour definitely made the hike feel dragged out. The loop I did (approach from the east, descent along the west) kept us in the shade for a good portion of the hike, especially on the ascent. I remember doing this hike maybe four years ago and being eaten alive by bugs and then deciding to never do it again. I had forgotten just how bad it was, and I did it as the first of the six-pack series this year. The views were gorgeous but I probably will opt to not hike it again for another four years, since I prefer hiking at elevation to big bites.", 'Beautiful hike, but horrible bugs!', "These trails are the prettiest in the L.A. National Forrest.  However, they are also home to some of the thickest swarms of gnats, biting flies and mosquitoes I've experienced in California.  DEET will NOT protect you.  Long sleeves , gloves, pants and head nets if you plan on going to the summit.  Or, do what I did, and just wave your arms all the way to the top like a lunatic.  The final leg has little shade and no streams to refill water until you get to the Observatories at the summit.", "I did this trail as an out-and-back from Chantry Flat to Mt. Wilson instead of a loop as described on this page. The total mileage ended up being around around 16 with 4000+ feet elevation gain (including the distance from the trailhead to my car). It was very crowded at Chantry, so I had to park about a mile down from the trailhead. The total mileage would've been around 14 miles had I parked closer.", 'Did this on Memorial day. Tons of people there but it died down the further we got into the hike.We arrived before 7:30 am and had to park about .5 mile from the lot. We started the hike at 8 am and ended at 1:30 pm. The bugs on the way up were annoying. I suggest bug spray as I ended up with over 40 mosquito bites. We also encountered a rattle snake on our descent from the top. Other than that, great workout with amazing views from the top.', 'mostly easy for moderate hiker', 'Switch backs after Sturrvent Camp are KILLER; highly recommend bringing a bug net for your face, too. We did see a donkey delivering a package from amazon, lol. Took us about 8 hours, but we went to hermit falls & stopped at sturrvent falls too', "The worse part about this hike is beating the masses to parking at Chantry Flats. I arrived at the parking area at 5:50am after having unsuccessfully trying to park there at 7am a few weeks ago. The weather was perfect for the day and I never got hot as most of the hike is done in the shade. The first few miles are quite pleasant, meandering along a nicely forest stream. I took the detour to the Sturtevant Falls which was defintely worth the extra 20-30 minutes. The ascent was difficult for the middle 2 or 3 miles but defintely manageable. Unfortunately there was a lot of cloud coverage when I went so I couldn't look out over LA but it was cool trekking above the clouds. The only time I wish I had poles was on the descent to take some pressure off my knees. Otherwise keep on the look out for mountain bikers and keep hydrated and you should be fine. I was back at my car at 2:15pm and was practically being shooed away for someone else to take my spot. But besides the crowds, it was a great way to start of my 6 pack.", "A friend and I did this on 4/30 as the first peak in the 6 peak challenge. We left at about 9:30am and went up the westerly route; somehow managed to overshoot the top and clocked in at 14.4 miles about 7.5 hours later. The bugs were horrible, but we brought lavender oil which, with repeated applications kept them at bay. This was a fun hike, filled with varied terrain and views. As everyone notes, the peak isn't terribly interesting, but there were some nice large rocks for a lunchtime sit.", 'Went last Sunday. Great warm up hike waiting for the snow to melt off of the big hills!!! Bugs were extremely heavy so if you take breaks you will need to prepare.', "All you beginner hikers doing the 6 pack...Make sure you print a map and bring trekking poles. You will need both for an enjoyable hike. We also screenshot hikingguy.com for step by step directions. Anyway, relatively nice hike. The views at creek level were gorgeous and it was nice to have some water crossings. The waterfall was a nice detour (no one was there when we went!!!) Be prepared for snakes! We saw two going up Chantry Flats and one was a big ol rattler sunning on the trail. Protect yourself and your dogs! After the camp, the last three miles were pretty tough! A couple washed out gravel areas that made me a little uneasy but overall not a bad ascent. Bring a lot of water and snacks (especially during the week when the cafe is closed) This summit was nothing special, but we got to check another one off our six pack, so I'm not complaining. There is a water fill station up at the top and bathrooms with running water. We took that trail loop down (over by the parking lot) and it was a lot less steep and less dangerous. Pretty views of LA. Checking this one off the list. On to the next!!! PS-bring a bug net for your face. You'll thank me later for this advice..", 'Good', 'The nearly 7 miles to the top starts off relatively easy but the last 3 miles from Sturtevant Camp to the top are grueling.  RT was 13.5 miles and took about 6 hrs with an additional hour to eat, rest, and take pictures.', 'Hiiked this trrail on Thursday, great hike, super fun and a lot of water in the streams. Canopy was nice even though it was a cloudy drizzly morning', 'Hiked the trail Sunday 4.09.2017 via Chantry Flats.  we weather was overcast most of the day thankfully.  The first part of the loop Chantry to Peak was excellent, mild mid level inclines, and incredible scenery.  Fro peak back to the parking lot by way of the loop was very difficult.  yes it was downhill but really rough on the knees. Not sure i would do this hike mid summer but who knows.  Some trash on the trail though not much, oddly lots of orange peels (pack it in, pack it out).', 'We just crossed this hike of our list just like many others that are doing the Six Pack of Peaks challenge. We were lucky enough to have great overcast, cool weather. The trail was a lot more scenic and beautiful than a expected! And yes, the last three miles are brutal but over all the hike was beautiful. Like everyone has said do not use these directions. We started at Chantry Flats and used the directions that are on hikingguy.com!', 'Go up the waterfall side and descend to chantry flats.', "****DO NOT FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS TO THIS TRAIL. IT TAKES YOU TO THE SUMMIT and the trail opens late.  Instead, search for the Chandra flats trail from the Arcadia side off the 210.   Super intense hike... like a previous hiker said, the last three miles of the descent into Chandry flats feels like a never ending trail. My comments were, Eff John Muir! Lol. The last three miles of the ascent going up to Mt Wilson peak from the lower side is brutal. Trekking poles made the hike up and down easier. Especially during the light creek crossings when I was running out of gas. Not much parking available so get there early, or get stuck walking uphill for a mile. Not a fun walk when your legs are shot. There was plenty of bathrooms available on the lower trail side but when you climb down on the upper side trail, they don't exist, at least I didn't see any. So pack a TP system. Bring 3L of water and good coverage to protect yourself from poison ivy. I wore trail running shoes which made my hike easier than wearing boots. Water refill was available at the top. Cafe by the observatory was decent. On to the next peak.", 'This hike should be renamed as The Trail That Never Ends!!! The last 3 miles are brutal and never ending! After Sturtevant Camp I cannot express how grueling, intense, and how difficult the last 3 miles are! I have hiked up to Spruce Grove Campground many times but never beyond that until now. This was my first peak out of the six peaks I did and even though the last 3 miles killed me and I was hating my life at that time I loved every minute of this hike! Would I ever do this hike again? Absolutely...but not anytime soon!

 **Please note there is a stapled notice on the Sierra Madre side Mt Wilson trailhead post stating the trail is closed due to a bear attack until further notice. So we actually went back down the same way we came up which was via Chantry Flats.**', "This was not only physically but mentally very challenging. Would not recommend to beginners. The entire hike is incredibly beautiful though. The start of the trail it like walking through a Disney movie with all the cute little cabins hidden away in the forest. Also lots of little newts to make friends with along the trail sides by the creek. So watch your feet or your may step on one by accident. Ascending to the peak was difficult to say the least, so make sure you have lots of water with you. I would recommend a camelbak since they hold more. Also if you don't have trekking polls I would invest in some. We ending up using sturdy sticks since we didn't have any. Reaching the top is such an accomplishing feeling. Unfortunately the cloud cover was super heavy when we went up, so the view was a bit lacking at the summit. Be prepared though. The hike down is extremely steep and a killer on the legs and knees. Honestly this was more challenging to me than actually reaching the summit itself. Overall, it was a great experience.", '', 'Snowy at the top', 'The final 3 miles are steep, so new hikers -- be prepared to hurt the next day. There is a great observatory area at the top with clean restrooms and a space to rest for a bit before the hike back down.', "This was so incredibly intense! I was totally not ready for this. If you haven't trained for a long distance steep hike then don't do this unless you're ok with not walking for a few days after lol. Absolutely beautiful trail. A good portion on the way up is right along the creek. Those last 3 miles going up are so brutal. We seen several groups going back down from the top the same way but we decided to do the loop. Going down was not easy either. It was pretty steep and felt like it was never going to end. There were several spots on the way down that were pretty confusing but we studied the trail beforehand and managed to take all the right trails. We took screenshots of a trail guide we found online and that helped SO much. When you get to a sign in the way down that says chantry flats 3 miles, you can go left instead and it's a bit shorter but it will lead you back to the steep pavement road at chantry flats and you'll have to crawl back up that... Not what I wanted at the end of a nearly 15 mile hike, but in our minds at the time an extra mile the other way seemed even worse. Moleskin saved my life. Even though my feet felt completely bruised and broken I didn't get one blister! This trail was beautiful but definitely physically mentally and emotionally challenging!! ", 'It was a little tough due to snow and rain but doable...', 'Awesome hike. I have hiked this trail during the summer and in the fall and both times it is always fun. I loved hiking during the rains the most and i was fortunate enough to see many salamanders in the forest areas near the rocks and water. I also saw a huge redtail hawk, alligator lizards, huge grey fluffy haired squirrels, blue jays, and plenty of other birds and insects.', 'Great hike, the last 3 miles were steep.  Be aware there are two benchmarks at the top.', 'Trail conditions were great!', "It was an amazing hike. We didn't expect to see that much snow. It made it a little more difficult to go up but still fun. On to the new mountain.", 'awesome', "Loved this! Super long and tough (at least for me, a moderate hiker), almost consistently uphill, but beautiful with a really cool observation deck at the top. Took us about 8 hours, granted we spent well over an hour at the top taking pictures, walking through the observatory museum and snacking. All in all, we walked about 15 miles. I don't know how, since the trail is 12, but I guess we wandered a lot  at the top (and parked a far bit away at the bottom).", "It's a very hard but nice hiking trail, got shade from start to finish!", 'I'm sure most hikers here know about the "SoCal six-pack". Well basically, I've hiked most of the 6 but never did Mt Wilson (the easiest), so this Saturday I did that. It's about 14 miles round trip, we finished in about 7 hours with some breaks. Super fun, more beautiful than I expected to be honest. For some reason I though it would be pretty easy and but drab. In fact it's actually fairly tough and the views are fantastic. I made a short video of some of the views: https://youtu.be/ZPblDbuZmOM', 'I was amazed at the abundant shade. Would recommend doing the loop counter-clockwise, as this puts the longer part of the hike before the summit. Consider adding the Mt. Zion summit for an even greater challenge.', "These directions are wrong.  They take you to the observatory. Looks like maybe you can start that way but the gates don't open til 10 so when we got up there at 7am we had to drive back down the mountain and follow the directions on the other one listed.", 'Great hike EXCEPT, Mount Wilson trail is closed as of 10/21 due to a bear attack on 10/10.  The trail is physically accessible, except for a small sign at the trailhead saying it's closed.  Otherwise, the climb up Sturtevant Trail was a bit tough, and took my wife, myself, and our dog a full 4 hours starting at 6:45AM.  The trail is cool in the morning, and mostly shaded and through trees and woods.  A few small sections are exposed and have a "desert feel" to them.  GOOD NEWS: the water refill at Mount WIlson is up and running as of this post.  

We did this hike as the first of the "six pack of peaks" and found it challenging and rewarding.  The 13+ miles was JUST at the limit of our dog's abilities, and I wouldn't recommend bringing a dog unless he/she has long distance hiking experience.  

After a 45 minute break at the top, we hiked back down Sturtevant Trail in roughly 3 hours, which took longer than normal due to having to stop every 10 minutes towards the end to give our dog a break.  The last .6 miles up Chantry Flats road was the hottest part of the trip, and unfortunately at the end which really pushed our dog to the limit.', "Great hike! Make sure you have plenty of water the the trip back. You can't refill your water at the top anymore because of the drought.", 'Great trail, a lot of switch backs. Very difficult, and from chantry flats its 14 miles round trip. I also had a deer run up the creek in front of me and cross the trail, it was a cool sight. Bring lots of water. Happy hiking', 'Beautiful shaded hike all the way up very challenging for me.', 'This is a tough hike in my opinion. The views are impressive! Most of the trail will be shaded. Lots of different trees, shrubs, plants, flowers, and fauna. There is a water filling station at the top of Mt. Wilson. This is a 4-6 hour hike. Well worth the pain!!!', "Do not follow the directions through this app as it takes you all the way up to the Observatory (the peak). Type in Sturtevant Falls on maps so that it can take you to the chantry flats trailhead and then you can make your way up via chantry flats. The falls was a trickle this time of year, but I plan to go back in spring when it's supposed to be very nice. The hike itself was very challenging as it is nothing but incline and very few leveled areas. There are bears in the area so please be safe and keep eyes and ears out. Take keys or anything that'll help you be a little louder. There were 3 in our area yesterday including a cub which can be dangerous. The bright side to this hike is that most of it is very shaded until you get closer to the peak. The views are nice once you are up there but there is no plaque to take a picture next to. You will end at the observatory and Cosmic Cafe which is nice since its shaded, has tables and clean restrooms! We did the loop which took us about 9.5 hours total including an hour of rest at the peak. It all depends on your fitness level obviously. We were a slower/ steady group. Arrive early as parking can suck! And don't forget your adventure pass which is also sold at the trailhead area or REI", 'Nice long hike. The Cosmic Cafe at the top makes the way back down much easier. Take your time on this one.', 'Great hike But I only hiked for the coffee. LOL!', 'Such a beautiful hike :-) Love the shade all the trees provide all year round!', 'bomb hiking. my favorite trails so far. I love this place.', 'Beautiful', 'Good training hike for Whitney or Half dome.', "All in all a very beautiful and challenging trail to hike. Great scenery all the way from the bottom to the top. There is a lot of shade throughout the trail so the sun wasn't killer but that isn't an excuse to not use sun protection and bring lots of water. The switchbacks going up were very difficult so make sure you're prepared if you do not hike harder trails often. The only downsides to the trail were the minimal amount of parking after 7 in the morning and the large amount of bugs I encountered on my way up. They were very difficult to deal with at times.Make sure to check out the Observatory Cafe at the top of the mountain for some food and drinks before you make the descent. Trust me, your body will thank you. The descent is much easier than the climb up so if you made it up, you're pretty much set!", "This has got to be one of the hardest incline of switchbacks I've been on in years. This trail is clearly defined, but definitely not for the beginner. It is all uphill with very little let up. It is very scenic with lots of overhead cover. I went about 3 weeks ago and it rained all the way up, but all the cover kept us from being drenched. Restrooms are bad. Bring your own tp and sanitizer. with the detour to Sturtevant Falls, my total roundtrip was 15.1 miles. The best hiking workout you can get.", 'great workout.', "One of the toughest hikes out there. Mega tough switchbacks. All up-hill all the time. Beautiful waterfall at sturvant falls. After the waterfall thats when the fun starts. The mountain gets as high as the clouds. It will trully test you so be fit, dont bite off more than you can chew, Please!! Here's a link to the YT video I made of the whole trip you can find it on ChampsOfTheOudoors channel that way you get an idea of what it truly entails? http://youtu.be/O_RAJ7mmwLk", 'Very good tracking experience, though it says 6.4 miles from chantry Flats its actually about 7 miles...
I will rate this as Hard for the last 2 miles. View and vegetation along the way is very freshening.. Great experience!!', "Trail is beautiful toward the beginning and gets a little plain near the top.  Stuartvant Falls and the stream that runs parallel to the trail makes it one of my favorites in the area.  This isn't an easy trail so be ready!", "I hike this trail for the coffee. Best coffee within 8 miles from the peak. LOL!  Do the loop and take time to enjoy the scenery. I've never done it during the summer time but spring was super awesome. Anyways! If you are in the area. take a day to hike this trail.", "Took our pup Quinn for her first summit. Good hike for a dog as most of it is shaded. Quinn's jet black fur appreciates a well shaded trek. It's a long one, but the elevation gain isn't too bad so it's more stamina than strength. Good hike for those who are working toward long hikes like baldy. This hike is actually longer but with less elevation it's a good trainer.", 'Already having completed baldy and cucamonga peaks, mt Wilson was my third peak to bag. I thought it was just as hard as the other two due to the length of the trail. We clocked over 15 miles, 37,000 steps and 480 flights of stairs. No joke. Started at 730 am and finished at 330 pm with two 30 min breaks. Bring electrolyte chews! We went through almost two liters on the ascent and one liter on the descent. You can refill your water at the observatory as well as buy lunch. We thought it was delish! Took a Motrin 800 halfway through. My knees and hip flexors- ouch!!', "We planned on spending the night at Spruce Grove Campground, but also doing the whole loop. We started at Chantry Flats and headed NW towards Hoegee Campground and up to the peak with our packs. This was my first overnight backpacking trip and I was ready to call it off once we reached the top, it was very difficult with the 30+ pound packs. We hadn't made pick-up arrangements, so we needed to continue onto Spruce Tree.  The last 2  miles or so were in the dark since we arrived at the peak around 5pm and we reached the campgrounds around 8pm.

There seem to be only 3 restrooms, pit toilets at the camp grounds and flush toilets at the peak; Hoegee's restrooms were as expected, but Spruce Grove is in dire need of some attention and repairs. 

It was a rough hike to do it the way we did, with full packs.  We weren't in good enough shape to check out the spur off to the falls the next morning, but we will probably go back to do it by staying at Spruce Grove again, but not doing the peak.  Plenty of water is very important, as well as trail snacks/bars for energy.  We also had a late start which meant a 1 mile walk back to the car, heed the advice and arrive early!", "Went with a group of friends and the day resulted in us being up above the clouds and fog that rolled in during the morning.  Get there early or you'll be parking on the road down the hill!  6:15 AM and we got one of the last parking lot spots. Lots of great views and water running in both creeks this time of year.  Check out the history of this area and you'll find out why all the cabins are up there along the creek!  Difficulty is high, both up and down, but well worth it!", 'The first 3 miles to camp is nice and easy and after that the trail turns up a ton. Be well prepared with plenty of water and electrolytes to prevent cramping as the last 3 miles will definitely test the calves and thigh muscles. There is a place to refill water and eat at the summit if needed. The loop down is also not that easy on already warn out legs so take extra caution on your footing.', "3/5/16 - Hiked the Chantry Flats to Wilson Peak and it was awesome! Took two co-workers that have never hiked a peak before so it was a fun day. This was my 4th time doing this hike but this year I'm doing the six pack of peaks challenge to prep for Whitney ", "This home was so green and gorgeous. We were went to Sturtevant falls and from there decided to keep hike so we followed a trail and then realized we were on Mt Wilson trail. It was only 3 more miles up so we continued and I must say the last 3 miles up were a killer on the legs. So with it when u reach the top. Coming down wasn't fun on the ankles when ur wearing Nikes.", "Chantry Flats to Sturtevant camp is beautiful! After Sturtevant camp the trail up to Wilson gets brutal and not particularly noteworthy other than being very steep. It's a great challenge but the top was anti-climactic and the cafe was closed. I would say be sure to give yourself 8 hours in case you need it for the whole loop!FYI there are smaller loops inside this that you can create and see all the worthwhile views without summiting Wilson.", "This was an awesome and challenging hike.  I got to the parking lot at about 0610 and it was at least half full. If you don't have an Adventure Pass, you have to pay $5.00 and park in a dirt lot that doesn't open until 0700. The lot fills up fast! Luckily I invested in an adventure pass last September.  I stepped off at 0635 from Chantry Flats and hiked to Sturtevant Falls (about 1.8 miles) before back tracking and completing the loop. The entire hike for me was 14.28 miles and it took me 6 hours 8 minutes (not including a 30 minute lunch break at the top). I underestimated how hard this distance, with the elevation gain (about 4200 feet), would be. I lost my legs at about the 5.5 mile mark and slowed down drastically. I found my legs again at about 6 miles when I caught my second wind, but that was short lived. With about 2 or 3 tenths of a mile to go, I hit a wall and slowed again. As the narrative says, the peak is a bit anticlimactic. Going down was fast and fun. I stopped and took lots of photos. I even got some great pictures of San Gorgonio, San Jacinto, and Mt Baldy. Each one covered in snow.This was my first hike from the SoCal Hiker Six Pack of Peak Challenge.", 'Such a beautiful hike!! My 1st of 6-pack of Peaks!...The last 3 miles are pretty tough but well worth it!! 4,000ft. Elevation gain. We ended up doing about 15miles which was my longest day hike so far, but it was such a wonderful experience!!', "As others have mentioned, the directions link to the peak of Wilson. I'm sure it's great starting here too, I just prefer to have the peak in the middle of my hike! Began at the Adams Pack Station, Trailhead at N34° 11.735' W118° 01.346'. Lots of cool cabins to check out for the first couple miles. 

Sturtevant Falls are beautiful, and certainly worth the quick detour. From here the trail gains pretty steadily to the summit, a good workout for sure. Stopped at Spruce Grove Campground for a snack and rest before continuing to the top. Be sure to look behind you as you go, just past the halfway rest, 1.4 miles below the summit, the views really open up. The observatory and surrounding structures are great to check out, however they weren't open when I hiked, would definitely go back when they are!", "Im from San Diego, so I started EARLY and left SD around 3:45am. I arrived at the trailhead around 6:45 and was happy to see that a permit could be purchased from the store. I was worried I would have to find one back in town and probably never would have found a decent spot to park. I posted my permit and hit the trail head right at 7. I didn't know they had primitive camps along the trail, they are only 3.5 miles from the trailhead, so it would be perfect for the kids. The switchbacks were killer and I was able to try out my new trekking poles. I used to think trekking poles were for old people, but they are awesome.....maybe Im getting old, I don't know. I took a rest after passing the Sturtevant Falls camp and my pouch with my phone, compass, map and GUMMY BEARS fell off my pack and proceeded take a 60 foot tumble down a ravine to the rocks below. Everything survived but my phone, so I am currently trying to get all the pics off of it. The rest of the hike went well and I hit the peak at 10:30am.  The hike down wasn't as nice at first, but once you get to the multiple creek crossings things get nice and lush, I'd have to say that the Hoegee Campground was my favorite section of the hike. Cool rocks, lots of water crossings and super green. It took 6 hours and 8 minutes to complete, this includes my side trip to collect my broken phone.", 'Started the hike around 8:30am on a Thursday morning in January. Stopped at the falls for some pictures. Saw lots of different species of fungi, a lady beetle mating extravaganza, and rode an enormous swing between two trees at sturtevent campground.Stopped at the undefined peak and ate lunch next to the 100 inch telescope building. We explored the grounds, refilled our water, and took in the panoramic views of LA,OC, And even Catalina. Then came the decent. We started around 1 and were back at the car around 4. I picked up 6 pieces of trash. Cool!', "12/28/2015 - the directions link to google maps took me straight to the observatory and not to chantry flats trailhead (type in chantry flats trailhead to google maps, instead).  so after waiting awhile and being unable to locate my meet-up friend, I ventured to the fire road just off to the southwest of the observatory.  the trail descends rapidly at about 500-750 ft per mile. knowing that it would take me longer to hike back up than down, I turned around at the bench, which was roughly 4.5 miles down the trail. hiking alone, I always have the nagging fear that I won't be back before sundown, but I proved a faster ascender than I had given myself credit for. so, the round trip took me about 3 hours with quite a few stops for pics and to check the cliffs above for mountain lions (that review had me in high alert!). the trail twisted around and back again exposing the sun to the west and shadows to the east, vacillating between about high 50's and 30 degrees. both warm layers and sun protection served me well.  the views are fantastic, stretching to the pacific off Santa Monica (hey I can see my house!), to Orange County and the Inland Empire (hey mom and dad!). the trail, as mentioned by all the reviews is, indeed, challenging, but I'm definitely in it next time for the full loop. cheers and happy hiking!", 'Great trail - wooded,several streams, not too crowded.  Lots of gnats in sections.  Take bug spray and/or netting.', "It's Great,Beautiful View", 'Great hike!!! The last 3 miles to the top of mt Wilson is pretty strenuous. Make sure you take plenty of water. The scenery is incredible. There was a snake on the path...so, I would be on the lookout for any slithery creatures.', 'Great hike. Gets tough towards the last few miles but otherwise it isn't too difficult. I got lost trying to find the "toll road" after being on the summit... If you are doing the loop, head west out the road from the snack shack and parking lot and once you exit the observatory entrance gate, immediately go to the left and head through that small gate that has surveillance cameras and a tiny dirt road... That is the toll road... Follow that down maybe 1.5 miles or less till you see a trail to your left... Head down there and you will head down to the upper and lower winter creek trails and you then have about 5 miles till you are back at chantry flats. I took the upper winter trail and it wasn't too bad. You descend kind of steep and quickly but then it's mostly flat. Have fun!', 'My wife Tracy and I arrived at Chantry Flats around 5:30am and there was parking, halleluiah! This wasn’t our first time summiting this peak so we knew to plan ahead and arrive early. The hike was mostly uneventful, except for a squirrel that gave me a very dirty look, must have thought I was after his nuts. The weather was pleasant on the ascent, once we arrived at the bench where this trail and the Mt. Wilson trail meet, we were hiking in the clouds until we reached the summit. I took a short detour to Harvard peak and there was almost zero visibility. Once we reached Mt. Wilson, the temperature dropped and we had to put on warmer clothes and rush through our chili pie (highly recommended) and got back to work on our descent. The trip back to the car was pleasant and we enjoyed a coffee and snack from our favorite coffee shop on the drive home.', 'This is an amazing hike. Beautiful scenery, incredible views, lots of shade,  and immensely challenging. The side trip to Sturtevant Falls is well worth it, even though the fall itself may be smaller than in the past, a splash of cold water on your neck and a moment to get psyched up for the coming ascent is not a bad thing. The descent is challenging as well, and offers a multitude of great views. You definitely want good, comfortable shoes and lots of water.', 'Done several times, but one of the best trips was in between storms with snow at the top.  Half the trails where washed away the mud in great condition lol but we had a blast, wet, muddy and steam coming off my clothes from a unexpected trip in the river.  What fun.', "I've only been hiking for seven days and decided it was time to start prepping for Mt. Baldy. Hiked July 7th, 2015 at 1000 ended at 1645 with a 40 min lunch at the top n roughly 30 mins of couldn't find the trail went up the creek bed..experience is quite the teacher..ha! It was mild temp in the AM hotter than hot by noon day. Started at Chantry Flats hiked up the seven straight miles with significant elevation increases (stayed steady paced with about 4 stops near the last 3 miles-last mile n half is the most intense- took about 3 hours n 15) and the seven (give or take) miles down came thru upper winter creek to hogge camp back to chantry flats was a breeze. Tighten up those laces however n save your toes. I did this solo, only saw 2 other hikers so if you're weary of heart go on the weekend which will ensure more folks. I packed 3 liters and went thru all 3 plus coconut waters. I'm 5'4 ringing in at a buck 20. So pack hydration. Sunscreen- the answer is yes. Bug spray like the dickens bc it's riddled with mosquitoes n huge flys that make you feel like you're in Jurassic Park. I wore hard mountain pants n long dry fit top, Trail shoes were fine but I might opt for boots next time. I also didn't use poles but recommend them. Poison Oak a plenty and some parts of the trail are hard to spot as well as risky foot placing so when your hands look to grab something -pay attention. Overall it was moments of easy n intense mind over matter trekkin. Beautiful views that remind you of how glorious our Creator is. Which He indeed, is. I packed lots of bars, nuts, fruit, hard boiled eggs- ate it all. Y'all will want to pack enough food- the hunger is real. I loved every minute of this trail. I feel as healthy as a horse radish now! Reckon I'll give Baden-Powell a go to help with my elevation endurance. Then Baldy. Y'all should know I sat down on the trail n got a mysterious sap on my trousers. Just about a quarter size amount, didn't think to much of it. Middle of the night a welt had puffed up on my rear end right where the sap was on my trousers. Y'all know this girl immediately grabbed the dish soap n took the coldest shower known to man. It itches like a fleas on a dog so putting two n two together I'm sayin it equals some kind of poison oak. Haven't had any other rashes praise the Lord, I have been tendin to it to with witch hazel, tea tree oil n oatmeal. Y'all seriously- look were your puttin your butt. Still wouldn't take back climbing that Mt even with this painfully precious souvenir. ", 'I thought this was much harder than I expected. Cool thing was at the cafe at the top and even along the hike, ran into people getting ready for Mt. Whitney in Sept. which is our goal too.  Definitley a challenge also bing bug spray, the big black flies really bite hard.  Lots of mosquito bites after this hike too.', 'Harder than I thought.  I have done Cucamonga & Baldy twice before this. Went from 1.1 miles south of Chantry Flats (where I had to park) down to Winter Creek to Hoegee Camp (bears in this area, saw a cub swimming) to Mt. Wilson Toll Road to Cosmic Cafe (7.8 miles) where I ate.  Way down was through Sturtevant Trail, back to Chantry Flats (7.5 miles)  With lunch and stops along the way, it was 7.5 hours total.  Hot and humid out so take a lot of water.  I am 5'11" 225# and I went through 4 liters of water, iced tea and a gatorade at lunch, and still had to coconut water cans in the parking lot. Water bottle filling at the Cosmic Cafe.', 'Man this hike never seems to get any easier!  Went up from Chantry to the Sturtevant trail via the "horse trail" to the Spruce Camp...then onto Sturtevant Camp, Then from there on up to Mt. Wilson.  This time I chose to come back down  the Upper Winter Creek Trail, to create the loop.  At least this way I ended up at the top of the Chantry parking lot at the pack house, which was nice.  This hike is a bit challenging and not for beginners.  It ended up being 16 miles, ( I think cause I chose to go the horse trail, which is a tad bit longer).', 'Great trail. Potable water at Mt Wilson and a snack shack with sandwiches and other snacks. We did the loop clockwise going up winter creek and coming down Sturtevant. The trail head for Sturtavent was up the observatory road behind the last telescope. I was exhausted and the last climb up to Chantry was a big push for me.Took about 8.5 hours including our lunch at the top.', "Great trail. The Falls were cool. My favorite area was the bluff overlook above the falls. Great spot. Beyond the falls is pretty but a long haul of generally the same scenery until maybe the last half mile near the summit.

I didn't do the loop on this trail, I came back the way I came, So i can't vouch for the second half of the loop. Stuartevant Trail was cool though.  The weather was very overcast and I could literally see nothing at the top, So i'm going to have to try this mountain again on a clear day some time.", 'This trail is amazing until you get to the Mt. Wilson turn off. After that it is several miles of nothing but up. It is fairly steep and this makes the way down a bit treacherous. I fell twice and by the time I got down, my ankles and toes were goners. Not for the faint of heart or beginning hiker.', "It's a beautiful hike. A ranger gave me a map on the hike, so that helped extremely. I'd suggest getting a map for the long hike. I also suggest, NOT parking at Mt. Wilson (parking is better though). It's all down hill, and THEN back up... yes, back up. If I had more water, a head-lamp (it was pitch dark and the trail has cliffs), and a partner, then it would have been excellent. Don't underestimate this one. ;)", "Start early when tneSun comes up. You can find psrkinf and it's still cool. Bring a camel back for each. Water is the key. Nuts, raisins, twizzlers and power bars will do the trick. It took us three hours up and one hour down. Very invigorating!  We are seasoned hikers. Only go as fast as you can. Don't forget to stop and look around, and appreciate the beauty that you see. Life is too short  not to take it all in.", "I'm so sore, but it was a great hike. I started at 11am and got back to Chantry Flats about 640pm. I ran about 5 of the 14 miles. The last 3 miles to the top of Wilson are a killer. It got dark my last mile back, so bring a flash light or get an earlier start than I did.", "Favorite hike because it's beautiful. There was a massive tree blocking the trail by the bench yesterday. (12-6-14)", 'I did this hike last year and the switchbacks after the "halfway" point, make the halfway point seem a bit off.  I've hiked 75 mile from the San Fernando Valley to the Santa Barbara Zoo overnight and this dang hike was a bear, seriously.  If you're going to the top, do not start after 6 or 7am.  Make sure you've hydrated well the night before and the morning of.  They this is the first of the 6 pack of mountain trails...well I'm in trouble...lol   

It is seriously one of the most scenic and historical hikes I've been on, and right here in my own backyard. Oh and no "mountain bikers" on this one...nice! Just you and the trail...', "Great hike!  Did this with my teenage son and he lead the way and pushed me up the strenuous never ending hill. We Started early at 6:20am and avoided crowd and finished in about 6.5 hours.  It was long ways up but nice and under trees most of way. The halfway sign is a little teaser as it seemed much longer with the switchbacks. The way down was easy but a little rough on the toes. Poles would have helped maybe. Adventure pass is needed and café is not always open so don't depend upon it. Will do again!", "I loved this hike - challenging but some great variety of terrain and scenery.  Nice and shady too.  It is busy, so if you don't want to walk a mile up the road to the trailhead, get there early.", 'This was a great, challenging hike.  We went up the Garielino Trail, through Spruce Grove Campground and came back down via the Mt. Wilson Trail/Upper Winter Creek Trail (trailhead is diagonally opposite the Cosmic Cafe across the parking lot).  It took close to 7 hours total.  Most of the hike is in shade which is great and the sections that were exposed had fantastic views, particularly near the top.  I found the views from the hiking trail to be more epic than the views from the actual top of Mt. Wilson.  We stopped at the Cosmic Cafe for hot dogs and apple pie which was a nice reward.  When we got back to Chantry Flats I was definitely very tired with some sore feet but it was totally worth it.  I plan on doing this hike again for sure and would recommend it to anyone in decent shape.', "Let me start by saying that this hike is a butt kicker and so far my most strenuous hike, but every step I have put on this trail worth the hike!  I started 7:15-ish in the morning on 3/22/14 from Chantry Flat and came back to my car just on 3 pm. To ascend I took trail via Spruce Groove Campground and Sturtevant Camp. Last  2.4 mile ascend was never ending!  On the way up, clouds were so amazing, please take a look at my track (link posted in Helpful Link).

To descend, I took Mount Wilson Trail, and then upper winter creek trail to Hoegee's Campground, from there I continued Upper Winter Creek to avoid the steep uphill to Chantry Flat even though this trail was little longer than the other trail. I think this is why my track ended up total 15.3 miles.

Only reason, I couldn't give 5 star, only restroom near cafe on the peak of Mount Wilson was closed. Their season starts on April 1. I will come back to this trail again but may take different route to make it more challenging.

Helpful link: http://alltrails.com/tracks/sun-23-mar-2014-00-01", "As a start to the 6 Pack of Peaks my husband, 2 teenage sons and I accomplished Mt. Wilson via Chantry Flatts loop on Saturday. It was amazing! At the beginning of our outting we took the small detour to The Strutevant Falls... Beautiful waterfall, worth the little bit of extra time and distance. All together with a few snack and rest breaks and about a 30 minute break at the summit for lunch we completed the trail in 7.5 hours. This trail is no joke, do not underestimate the trail the ease of the first few miles... be ready for a battle of wills. Steep incline and switchbacks to the summit. Just when you think your getting close you will come upon a sign that says halfway rest point, take a breather and then drudge on! A lot of people say the summit was anticlimactic... I have to disagree, for myself I felt a great sense of accomplishment making the climb. At the top you will find the Mt. Wilson observatory. There is a cafe at the top which was closed (it does not open for business until April). The view was beautiful. We opted to make the loop and come back into Chantry Flatts via Winter Creek... Absolutely fantastic! The entire trail has great shade coverage. The day we hiked it was about 80 degrees but under the tree canopy it was perfect, I was even a tad bit chilly. Word to the wise, I would recommend hiking poles to save your legs a bit. We went without and wish we hadn't. Get there early the parking lot is small and fills early by 7! There is an over flow lot at the pack station that opens at 8 and cost $10. We parked a ways down the grade off the road which made for a longer day. You will need to purchase a parking pass (if your doing the 6 Pack then just spring for the Annual, it will be good for the rest of the Peaks). Bring lots of water!!! We went through 4 liters each. I would highly recommend this trail! Simply gorgeous So Cal nature!!!", 'Great trail, a bit of a grind after the falls to Mt Wilson. The balance of the loop  is cake. Lots of great views and shady most of the way.. Did it in 6 hours at a steady pace, minimal stops. Lot was full at 7:00 am, get there early to beat the crowds.', "I started out from Chantry Flats but didn't quite do the loop trip, although I was inspired to try it next time for sure!! Instead I set out on Gabrielino trail with a meet up group and set out to do the Sturtevant trail up to Mt Wilson.  Then came down the same way via Upper Winter Creek trail to avoid the climb UP the ROAD….It was sunny and warm on Mt Wilson but most of this hike is shady", 'One of the best routes to take to Mt. Wilson during the summer with most of the trail in the shade.  I take this trail about once a month and it can be a busy on the weekends.  Not too steep but a steady climb once past the falls.  Parking on the weekends is tough if you get a late start.', "Started from Chantry Flats. Took it all the way up.  Awesome views, scenery, and challenging trails.  Wish the mountain was higher.  Only came across  few hikers throughout the entire 14 mile treck.  Go with a buddy.  It'll make the hike/trailrun much funner.  The weather was good. Shaded almost the entire way.", 'My friend and I started the hike at 7am from chantry flats up to mt. wilson and looped down to mt. wilson toll road. We were supposed to get onto the winter creek trail, but missed it. Nonetheless, it was a great hike.  It took us all day (5pm) to get down and ended up in Altadena. 
Once your up there, there are tv towers, a museum, and cafe to rest and enjoy the scenery. It was pretty awesome. " I conquered mt. wilson!"', 'THis is a nice hike amid trees and by streams. I love hiking in this area. There can be bugs so I try to avoid the area in mid summer. It has a lot of ups and downs with some very challenging climbs', "Pretty cool hike. It kind of kicked my butt. My knees were killing on the way down. I'll probably take polls next time. Checked out the Cosmic Cafe at the top. I had a hot dog because I'm an idiot. ", 'Awesome hike.  My buddy and I took the route that has you run up Mount Zion (3575’) on your way up to Mount Wilson and then we looped around the Mt. Wilson Trail to the Manzanita trail then to the Upper Winter Creek Trail.  Overall it took us about 5 hours to get to the top and about 2.5 hours down (we aren’t exactly in prime hiking condition either).  We chose that route because we did not want to hike up the dreaded paved road at the end.  We went on a Wednesday and I think we may have ran into other hikers maybe 4 times and all that was before Hoegees camp.  After that was total seclusion for the rest of the hike.  I would suggest getting their early and hike during the week.', "Made this hike on a cool, sunny Thursday in June. Began the hike by mid-morning and headed towards the falls. The trail was busy and the falls had a couple dozen people hanging out. From there on to Mt Wilson the trail was very light in traffic. It is a strenuous hike for the most part though I found the worst of it is at the end when you hit the pavement and it seems like you have to hike back forever and a day to get back to the parking lot. I thought I'd be back in at 6 1/2  hours but that last hill made it 7 hours. Didn't see much wildlife this time out. I went through all 4 1/2 liters of water this time out. I enjoy this hike because of the scenery and  the shade provided along the way. there are several campgrounds and picnic areas along the way to stop and rest. I do wish people would remember to pack out their trash and dog poop.", "Fantastic hike! It was pretty brutal though...still recovering. My boyfriend and I ran into a huge Mountain Lion on the way down. He didn't seem to care we were there, but we were pretty freaked out by it. Eventually he moved off and we got the heck out of there. This was on the trail back to Chantry Flats, shortly after the bench. We ended up doing this hike in just under 4.5 hours. We are really fast hikers anyway, but I think seeing that big cat shaved off a bit more time!", "Like Mark said in the previous review, this is a seriously scenic trail. Shaded almost the entire way, it makes its way through forests that showcase what it was that drew everyone into these mountains 120 years ago. It's a steady climb past Spruce Grove campground, but it pays dividends in views at the top. Winter Creek back to Chantry Flats is a steady descent; it spits you out at the footbridge you originally crossed starting out. Of course, that means one last, steep climb back up the paved road. Worth it. ", "Great hike. One of the best in Southern California. The trails are what make the hike. The views are awesome but this trail's right hook is the consistent beauty of the path along the way.

The trails are well maintained and well marked. There's even a cafe at the summit open part of the year. I had read that Chantry Flats was the best way up to Mount Wilson and I think you'd be hard pressed to find a more scenic route although I cannot claim this from personal experience. I'd note Sturtevant Falls... but that's just a tease. It only gets better from there.

We were lucky enough to hit the trail with a ton of snow on the ground. Pretty awesome in Southern California at such a low altitude. It felt like we were at a significantly higher altitude.

I don't think the difficulty is quite as hard as it is rated. While it is a long hike, it's nothing that's going cause problems for the average Joe... as long as you've gotten a few moderate hikes under your belt.

You can knock it out in 6 hours hiking non-stop. 7 hours taking breaks. 8-9 if you take long breaks and/or stop to take all the scenery in (or take pictures). 10 for turtles.

Just go.", 'This is a very difficult hike, but this route is very beautiful. You are shaded by trees throughout the hike except at the summit. The scenery is almost like your in a jungle/forest. Very easy to follow trail because of the all the trail signs.  Trails are very well maintained. Bring adventure pass.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Hollywood Sign via Canyon Drive - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'wheelchair friendly', 'kid friendly', 'stroller friendly', 'birding', 'hiking', 'nature trips', 'road biking', 'trail running', 'walking', 'paved', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'bugs', 'rocky', 'washed out']
hike_description: Hollywood Sign via Canyon Drive is a 5.7 mile lightly trafficked out and back trail located near Los Angeles, California that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
