user_texts:
['This hike was pretty neat. I was able to see some awesome breed of dogs.... it’s funny because we came on this hike by mistake trying to see the caves on the Bronson hike (something like that).I recommend WORKOUT gear. I saw a lot of people that might have missed that memo and ended up sliding and falling. Be sure to have a shoe that has a grip to it! Take water...don’t make the mistake I made. There is horse poop everywhere (lol) soooo look where you are going. Great little places to take photos. But this trail is connected to many other trails that will take you to the Hollywood sign. Oh! PARKING! Keep DRIVING ALL THE WAY UP. There is parking all the way at the beginning of the trails so do not stop at the first gate!Enjoy folks!', 'Great hike!  It was a beautiful day in LA.  Started early to beat the crowds and to get a good parking spot. Took my uncle visiting from Minnesota.  A must for out of town guests.', 'We have been doing Runyon Canyon because we live on an easy access block.  Every once in a while we need change the scenery so we drive 15 minutes and do something touristy and easy for us to get off the bucket.   This hike is everything that is described in the description as far as we are concerned as locals.  Very enjoyable.', 'Great hike. Come early!!', 'It was a nice trail. I set out at 7:30 a.m and finished it in 2 hours. Carry water and sunscreen!', 'This was a relatively easy trail to the Hollywood sign. The hardest part about this trail is that it is straight up to get to the Hollywood sign. I started from the Canyon Road parking lot and went to the back of the sign first and then the front of the sign. In total that was 7.5 miles. If you only go to the front of the sign it is 5.7 miles. Listen to what everyone else says -go out super early, there is no shade. You’ll need sunblock, a hat, water and sturdy footwear. The ground is not technical at all, it’s a flat hard pack and actually at the very top its asphalt to the front of the sign.', "Loved the hike! The views were amazing and I got great shots of the sign. It is dry and open trail but if done in the early morning it's not bad at all. Definitely bring apply sunscreen and wear hats and sunglasses. We didn't go all the way up behind the hike, but it isn't much further up the trail (maybe like another mile) if you decide to go further up.", 'Great hike - and easy for kids.', 'This was a fairly easy trail. Gradual incline. It’s really open so hats, sun screens, and at least a liter of water or more if you start late as it will get hotter in the afternoon. We spent about three hours total because we stopped at the Hollywood viewpoint ( front view of the sign) and Mt Lee ( back of the sign)  to take in the breathtaking views and for lots of pictures. There is no trail that will bring you right to the sign as it’s gated and in a protected area, however if you get onto Mt. Lee trail it’ll get you to Mt. Lee just behind the Hollywood sign and it’s as close to it as you could get to the sign. Hope this help, have fun!!!', 'This is a great adventure.. you need to have good shoes lots of dust and water. We saw rattle snakes so no flip flops...', 'Great moderate hike to bring out of town guests. However, if out of shape, it may be difficult. It’s up hill at beginning and end.', 'Great views. Would be great at sunset or early morning.', 'It’s a nice hike but nothing spectacular. The smell of horse poop and pee can be a little overwhelming from sunset ranch. There is no shade so avoid on hot days.The view at the top is fantastic however. Amazing views of the Hollywood Reservoir and the view of the back of the Hollywood sign is certainly unique!', 'Great hike just watch out for the horse poop. minimal shade.', 'This trail is filled with horse crap and is absolutely disgusting. Horse tour companies should be responsible and pick up the horse crap. Dog owners must so why cant a paid business giving tours do it. I would never recommend this trail to anyone, unless you want to fight flies, nat, and dodge horsecrap the whole time. the smell is not enjoyable either. hike at your own risk!!! only giving 1 star because I have to. the city needs to make these horse tourist responsible.', 'great trail, amazing views and cold drinks available once you reach the top via the tank trail...', "Nice and easy hike up to and behind the Hollywood sign.  Trail is more of a smooth dirt road and the presence of tire tracks indicates this.  Went in January and it wasn't crowded and the temps were very 'normal', not too hot and not too cool.  Sunset on the way back down was amazing!", 'This is the best trail to get in front of the Hollywood Sign!! You can also go to the observatory once you are up in the trail. The hardest part is finding parking and then you are off. No bathrooms on the way. I went during the heat of the day, I took my liter water bottle. It took me 2 hours total while I stopped for lots of pictures. If you bring your dog, don’t forget WATER for them!! I saw so many people with large dogs, husky’s in 90 degree weather.... one collapsed... it’s hot on their feet too and they can suffer heat stroke!! Anyways sorry about my dog rant, there is a nice breeze and the beginning starts out with lots of shade and then it opens into a dirt road for truck access. You will see horses on the trail if you are lucky; I also saw a man and his goat. There are trash bins in the area which was nice. The Bronson park opens at sunrise and closes at sunset so keep that in mind. My recommendation is to go early in the morning and bring a small car for parking. I would also wear a hat that has flaps on the back and sides for those that have sensitive skin, sunscreen and bring a little nap sack so you are hands free.', 'Great trail! Amazing views!! Bring a lot of water & wear a hat :)', 'great hike! Bring water, sunglasses & a hat.', 'This was wonderful!', "Less of a trail and more of a wide dirt road. No shade, so bring a hat and plenty of water. Views of the city are stunning, but there isn't much else by way of pretty nature photo ops. Loved being able to go to the front and around behind the Hollywood sign, but doing both does add extra mileage, so be prepared. Iconic views from the sign itself. So glad I did this at least once. (And it only took 20 years of living here!)", 'I love this hike!! Bring at least two liters of water and a snack. This hike was 6.9 miles for me because I also went to Bronson cave and I recorded from the time I exited my car until I got back. It is an all uphill hike so go slow and steady. Wear a hat and put on sun screen. Enjoy!!', 'Amazing trip, hike is tough, lots of uphill, all the time and a fairly steep incline. Took a few hours. The payoff at the end is worth it!', 'Amazing!!!', 'Great hike!', 'Love the views of the Citi... And the Hollywood sign.. Pretty traffic during the weekend.. Good workout not to steep for beginners.. Bring water n hat...', 'Step drop-offs and some climbing but great hike, excellent views from the Wisdom tree.', 'Fun hike..very hot on a sunny day. Majority of the trail was not shaded. Prepare to bring a hat, sunblock, and plenty of water. I would recommend to start earlier in the day. Enjoy!', 'Take Franklin Ave to Canyon Dr. go north. Plenty of parking along Canyon if parking lot at trail head is full. Took 4 kids, all 11 and under. Great family hike with views of the city.', 'Parking fills up quickly off Canyon Drive, wide dusty trail with options to go in front of Hollywood sign or behind it or to Griffith Observatory, all are worth exploring.  Beautiful views on the way, especially from the very top.  Bring enough water, Rangers do provide water buckets around half way point depending on time of day', 'Dirty, dusty, windy and hot. But the views are awesome. Went on a Thursday afternoon, not crowded at all. Watch out for horse crap, bc there was a ton of it. Good steady climb and felt a sense of accomplishment looking DOWN on those letters knowing how far above they were at the start. Glad I did it, but won’t be back.', '', "Lovely views and lots of photos ops! Look out for the small brown sign that will direct you to the back of the Hollywood sign or otherwise you'll end up hitting a dead end and/or getting fined.

Park at 2980-3000 CANYON DR, CA 90068", 'Challenging route, but affords many gorgeous views of the LA basin on your way up to the sign.', '', "Loved it! Brought my friend and my dog. My only complaint is parking and the crowd at the top. Some people have their dogs off leash. It's mostly uphill going in and downhill (much easier) going back. Great leg and butt workout! Great view at the top!", 'Easy hike with some amazing views', "There isn't much shade so it can be hard work climbing up the trail. Definitely worth it for the views.", 'Tough hike in the beginning as it is steep and there is absolutely zero shade. Make sure to bring plenty of water.', 'Good hike. Starts off steep. Go around 4ish and you get the cool walk on your way down', 'Finally made it! Went last weekend with two friends and we got incredible views and photos! Can check it off my bucket list!', 'I loved this trail. Lots of options for paths. You can even hike to the observatory. Great views. Would do again', 'As expected, great hike about 10 miles, long but easy hike that includes great LA views', 'Busy busy trail. Nice view of Great Los Angeles area. Not recommend to do after 9 a.m. cuz there is no shade and will be very very hot. Pretty good trail for beginners, not so steep, wide trail.', "This is the 3rd trail I've done and it was a little hard for me but well worth it. It felt good to finally see the Hollywood sign.", "This trail was a bucket list item for my 19 yr old daughter.  Pretty phenomenal.  Busy, BUSY trail.  Parked in a neighborhood below sign and walked at least a mile (uphill) just to get to trailhead.  Trailhead is manned by a security guard who fields questions and keeps an eye out for ne'er-do-wells.  Took my Doberman puppy up -- his first big hike.  It kicked his butt.  No bathrooms, no water.  No shade.  Wide area to hike -- a road really.  Great views of the LA smog.  ;-)", 'Despite different website claims, we parked on Beechwood (no time limit, lots of open spots but no parking Fridays-Sundays) and walked up. There is a guard posted at the top of Beachwood Drive. Beyond the guard is a public access gate that was open. Regular locals access the gate for access to Griffith and the Hollywood sign. Moderately steep incline on some slippery gravel to the Sunset Ranch sign and the trail to the Hollywood sign starts to the right just before the Sunset Ranch sign. The rest of the trail clearly marked. The rest of he trail is a mixture of moderate inclines and flat ground. Bring water!', "Its great hiking however going back down didn't we didn't make the right turn and end up at wrong place but it was overall it fun", 'So this is a drag, but the city just announced that the trail to the Hollywood Sign can no longer be accessed from N Beachwood Drive starting April 18.  They are permanently locking the gate. ;-(', "The directions on here will get you to the area but really you need to start at Los Angeles River Park. you can park next to it and hike from there. it's about a 1.5 hour hike just walking. you have to pass the do not enter signs but once ya get to the trail (about 20 mins in) it's a easy route to follow. Great Views!", 'Not too long. But steep. Definitely a workout for the lungs. Almost no shady areas, so prepare for sun. Went on a Friday. So had no problems parking on Beachwood Dr. almost right at the trail entrance. But God help you if you go on a weekend. :\', 'Awesome hike... constant views of LA and the Valley as you wind through the trail to the top of the sign. No parking in neighborhood but I read other reviews to get advice on were to park!', '', 'Amazing views! Great trail access to front and back of Hollywood sign. Parked on Beachwood Drive before "No Parking" signs start appearing.', "Great trail! Very difficult to find parking tho. But overall it was a great hike and perfect view of the sign. Also like that there's 2 different trails. One to look directly at it, and one to go above and look down at it.", 'Beautiful views! Great workout but not too steep. Really enjoyed this hike. It was longer for me because I started at the bottom of the Cauheunga loop trail and worked my way up.', 'Pretty good trail. With the exception of making sure you have to park in a zone that does not require a permit. Last thing you need after a beautiful day and a hike is to come back to your car with a parking ticket or worse, towed.', 'Great Hike but Moderate plus due to the incline. I saw a lot of people just quit and turn around. Parking is tough we got lucky that someone was leaving when we arrived. Great Views, good for Pics. No shade, so wear your Sunblock', 'As a hike, so-so. Lots of people, even mid-week in November. Of course, the real reason is to get to the Hollywood sign... but even then the closest you can get is about 100 ft, due to fences (with lots of security cameras). It was a very hazy day too, maybe better views on a nice day.', "So, I would call this borderline moderate.  Cool view but pretty steep!  No weekend parking so that's a drag and some of the locals are a--holes.  My g.f.s and I were walking up the street talking but not making too much noise and this woman comes out of her house and tells us to get the f--- away from her house.    A couple of weeks later I tried hiking to the sign from Canyon Drive north of Franklin Ave near the big Gelsons on the corner.  Tons of parking on Canyon past the gate and in a dirt lot.  The hike was  maybe 10 minutes longer, but not as steep.  Also water and decent rest rooms that were pretty clean and no screaming residents.  After we went to the Trails Cafe on Fern Dell nearby.", '', "Awesome hike. It's actually pretty difficult as it's all uphill. I'd say the first 20% of the hike is hard as the incline's the steepest but if you battle through it it's pretty awesome and it evens out a little. The views behind the Hollywood sign are really cool!", 'Love this hike. Its not too steep and the views are beautiful. There is not a lot of shade so it can get pretty hot.', "I found this to be a difficult hike for my being mostly uphill. The views were definitely worth it though. I got to be so close to the Hollywood sign and there weren't a lot of other people there", 'If you approach up the Beachwood Canyon entrance, there is no parking on the weekend on the streets for about 3/4 mile leading up to the trailhead.  Agressively enforced! The trail itself is wide and well traveled, pretty gradual incline.  Lots of people coming from other trails in the park.  Upper half of the trail is blacktop.  Great views of both Hollywood and the Valley and of course the iconic sign.', "Make sure to bring sun screen and water. Also be prepared with the type of clothing you wearing and don't forget to wear hiking shoes. Most of the hike is uphill. On the other hand it has amazing views of Griffith Observatory, Downtown LA,  and the Hollywood sign. I personally enjoyed the hike.", 'Fun time, took my son so we could check out our legendary Hollywood sign!', 'Nice views', "Well, I got lost and decided to just wonder around and look at the different houses. I hate stairs so I'm glad I got lost and got to explore the neighborhood. It would be better if the stairs were easier to find. I would not consider this an easy outing. I'm out of shape and I met some alethic women that were struggling like I was.", 'Butt kicker going up the summit', 'Amazing', 'awesome', 'Too easy for me!!!! But beautiful and fun to see how big hollywood sign is up close.', '2nd time and it was great!', "I wish I could give this hike a real review but the directions if gives you to get there are wrong. Drive almost and hour and a half from home to go to this hike to get to the very top and the gates are chained up and it says no hiking access. Drive through this small neighborhood thinking we were getting closer to have to turn around and not be able to enter. Stop at a small grocery store near by to get directions and were told to go a different way and the same thing happen. Chained up gates and no access to the trails . Wasted a Saturday morning driving around and getting no where. Disappointing. If you want to give this a try don't follow the directions this app gives...", 'This trail is not as "easy" as they claim.  Be prepared and bring water and sunscreen.  Also, make sure after the first big hill to keep left.  I went right and wound up almost at Griffith!  Took almost 4 hours, but I was determined to get to the top!  The view was worth it, but I won't be doing it again soon.', 'Great scenery. Crowded on a Sunday. Watch out for the horse poop.', "Iconic! I'm born and raised in Southern California and just did this hike on 1.1.16. I waited way too long to make it up here! I would recommend it to anyone and everyone that can make it up the hill. We were lucky on our hike to have such gorgeous weather. We could literally see from OC to Long Beach to Catalina to Santa Monica on the south side and Bubank on the north side of the peak. It's a long uphill but worth it!", "This is a really easy hike - great for the whole family and to take out of towners to or to get outdoors for a fresh breath of air. As a fit person that works out about 4-5 days a week, I wouldn't recommend this hike if you're looking for a workout.", 'The hike itself is not too bad, suitable for all ages with a generous view over the city of Hollywood/Los Angeles area.', 'Awesome hike, easy paved road half way up, took my 9yr daughter she loved it.', 'Many back end staircase. It is very easy to get lost in between the houses. There are pretty neat houses in different styles from every corner.', 'easy hike. all paved road to the top.', 'One of my favorites!!', "A friend took me and I don't remember the trail but it was the awesome trail of my life.", 'Bucket list check off! Xoxo', "Here's another way up:

https://hikingguy.com/hiking-trails/easy-hollywood-sign-hike/", 'Directions to get to the trail were confusing. Other than that, it is an all asphalt trail that leads to the top of the Hollywood sign. Beautiful view at the top.', "I went hiking here in the beginning of december with a friend around 4pm. It happened to be a gloomy and cold day so we didn't have such a great view, but still able to see downtown la from the trail. We got to the top of the trail behind the hollywood sign and were just breath taken!! We came across a few horses along the way and very friendly people. By the time we came down it was already dark so we decided to run half the way. The view of the city lights is spectacular! I would definitely go back again.

Parking does get crowded during the day but we had no problem parking in the lot. 

Living in LA County for 21 years and finally being able to hike to the Hollywood sign was definitely a day I'll never forget.", "For me, it was a great experience coming up to the Hollywood sign since it is such a huge attraction. To the Hollywood sign in itself, follow the trail that will lead you to the back of the sign. If you are expecting to be very close to the sign where you can touch it & take pictures with it, you will be disappointed since there is a fence bordering it. Amazing views at the top! 
Lot's of incline and horse poop, just a heads up!", "Most go if you're visiting Hollywood. There is a fork that splits for the front of the sign and a hike to the top behind the Hollywood sign. ", 'The entrance to the Trail is off of Beachwood Drive right by right next to Sunset Ranch. My girlfriends and I started hiking around 6:40 a.m.. We ended up doing both trails. One trail ends behind the sign and the other in front of the sign. There are inclines and declines during this hike. The trail to the right is a little more strenuous and ends up behind the sign.  There is a very nice memorial with a little bit of history regarding the trail and the donors who make the trail possible.', 'Smooth and flat road. A road of horse poop when passing by the horse ranch.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Mount Judah Loop Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dog friendly', 'backpacking', 'birding', 'hiking', 'nature trips', 'snowshoeing', 'trail running', 'walking', 'forest', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'rocky', 'snow']
hike_description: Mount Judah Loop Trail is a 4.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Truckee, California that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from June until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.

user_texts:
['one of my favorites', 'Rocky start, possibly ankle rolling. Very pretty. Pretty easy hike for a moderate but I don’t really know how they grade here! Lots of dogs!! People are nice.', 'We started late not really planning on a hike but could not resist and the weather was great.  We took our border collie who loved it.  The high point of the hike was seeing a bald eagle!  We will be back to complete the loop.', 'Great hike but more like 5.7 miles from parking area. Even longer if you decide to take the detour out and back to Donner Peak from main trail up to  Mt. Judah. Beautiful views.', 'Nice views. Get to walk on some of the ski runs and good views of Sugar Bowl ski area.', 'We are new to hiking and in our 50’s-60, so this is for newbies like us. Loved the views and weather was perfect in October. We actually walked the path counter-clockwise, not knowing how this app really works, and just realized, late, that the path direction is on the app. Heading down the peek of Mt. Judah Trail back to Pacific Crest was slippery and steep, the trail was hard to recognize. Now that I see we should have ascended that way, it makes some sense. We’re learning and love adventure.', 'The first 2 miles could be challenging for people who have knees problems because the trail was steep and could be slippery. We hike relatively slow with our dogs and it took us about 3.5 hours round trip.', 'Great hike!', 'Very crowded and when I hike I like to get away from people. I’ve lived in Truckee since ‘91 and have never done this trail as I had heard it was too busy. Rocky parts and uphill but not a difficult hike. Beautiful views! 2 hours and 12 minutes to do entire loop.', '*There are some lengthy steep and rocky parts of the trail*Great workout*No water sources so bring plenty of water for dogs*A lot of exposed/unshaded areas of the trail*Took about 3.5 hours to complete the entire loop with several breaks*Well signed trail; hard to get lost*Nice views (lake, summit, trees, etc.)', 'Great! Especially hitting it just right for wildflowers!  Views are magnificent. Good workout.', 'Beautiful! Amazing views. Great hike with older kids.', 'A beautiful October hike, with saturated colors, cool temperatures, and no other hikers. Although a relatively short hike, the climb provides good exercise if done at a brisk pace.', 'Beautiful!  Good workout.  Fall colors beginning and great views.', 'beautiful views and amazing trail.', 'Pleasant beautiful loop, definitely go out to Donner point.', 'Great hike', 'Amazing views!', 'Loved it.  Beautiful views.  It’s a good work out for those that want to push it.  Or you could take it easy and enjoy the scenery.Took my daughter and I and we completed it in two hours.   We ran  the whole way back..There were only a few other hikers in the area.', '*popular hike....lots of folks here.*easy hike....not well signed though...*beautiful views, very pleasant ...some shade.* bring enough water- there isnt any here.', 'Loved it!!! Great day hike!', 'Great hike. Spectacular view of the lake!', 'Wow it was definitely 4 out of 5 stars', 'Great trail with outstanding views of lakes', 'Amazing views!', 'Nice mix of rocky path and forested trail, sun and shade.', 'It is about 6 miles total from the parking area. Very very rocky in the beginning. Almost impossible to run. It’s worth it as you get to the summit and then a great run back to the parking area. Running up to the summit is really hard at a high altitude! Beautiful area!', 'Amazing wild flowers end of June through July', 'The trail starts of fairly rocky and smoothed out again until you get closer to the top.  Very nice scenery throughout the hike.  View from the top is a nice payoff.  No water so bring what you’ll need plus food.  Did it in early July and saw lots of wild flowers.  Well marked.  Hard to get lost.  It took us three hours with stops.', 'This was a fun hike with a friend. Lots of great views and the weather was perfect since we live in the valley. Nice day trip to get out of the heat and get in some fun exercise. Would definitely do it again.', 'Great hike !', 'Beautiful hike!  Good workout. Stunning views.', 'Beautiful!', 'Great views of the lake, easy hike', 'Nice enough hike with some good views of the surrounding mountains.

It is a single file track for most of the trail so some basic trail etiquette would make this hike more enjoyable for everyone. But no such luck. Yielding to uphill traffic, packing out dog poop or even a simple "hello" seem to be altogether foreign concepts on this trail. We did this on a Monday when it was relatively quiet, I would definitely not do this on a weekend when lots of people compound the trail etiquette issue.

The notable pleasant exceptions to the above we encountered were PCT hikers and a handful of very friendly Europeans.

Who this trail is for: people looking for a workout instead of their usual gym and do not care about hiking as such.
Who this trail is not for: Anyone looking for inspiration or who enjoys hiking.  Keep looking elsewhere because you are not missing anything by skipping the Mount Judah Loop Trail.', 'Wonderful hike with beautiful views.  Fairly easy and steady climb up to Mt Judah.  We started at 6:30am to avoid the crowds and hot temperature.  There were a ton of mosquitoes at the trailhead so be sure to bring your bug spray.  Not much snow at the top (small patches here and there).  Highly recommend Mt Judah and maybe tacking on Donner Peak along the way!', 'Third time hiking this trail yesterday, June 22.  One of my favorites in Truckee - I’m a local.  Views are stellar. Started at 7 am as it was going to be a hot day.   Got very warm at the end.  The trail is sun exposed.   We had 3 dogs with us all in good shape and young but they went thru almost all our water.  Leaving the trail around 12 noon we ran into people just starting the hike (in the heat of the day) with a 13 1/2 year old dog.  Felt very, very sorry for the dog.  Asked if they need the rest of my water.  Said they had some by didn’t have a bowl.  I gave hem mine - which is a collapsible.   Folks: there is no water for the dogs on this trail and it gets very hot especially at the end when the dogs are tired already.  Please remember to bring lots of water for your dog.  And think about whether a 13 1/2 year old dog should even do this hike.  Hope he made it.', 'Busy trail, but definitely worth it.', 'Kind of technical first mile ascent, but great afterwards. Went last week and there was still significant snow! It was awesome! The top was super windy (50mph) to beware on windy days. There’s no coverage up there.', 'Warning! In order to cross Sugar Bowl terrain during their ski season, a uphill pass is required. Even with an uphill pass, only some uphill routes are approved and unfortunately this is not one of them. I ran into a ski patrol while attempting this trail and was turned around. They told me to visit Sugarbowl.com and read the uphill policy for more information.', 'Absolutely gorgeous! Park right off the highway as the road to the trail head is narrow and there is no closer parking. Trail was easy to follow the tracks until it crossed the ski runs.', 'It’s a good hike ,  very moderate- not to hard . Views are great.', 'We did the loop counterclockwise. Micro spikes were definitely in order on some of the lower parts and all of the upper. Once over the summit and past the ski lift, the backside was too steep and unstable to try. Getting late so we came down the ski area in the woods. Treacherous in spots but at least there were trees to stop you (which we did not need).', "I do not recommend doing the full loop in the winter. The trails up to Donner Peak are of medium difficulty and were mostly easy enough to follow people's footprints with some GPS confirmation. They were mostly covered in snow and a bit of ice, so I would recommend bringing some kind of spikes or snowshoes. I think this section would be good as an out-and-back during the winter months. If you plan to go up any side of Mount Judah, I would definitely recommend crampons and maybe even an ice axe in the current conditions. Following my GPS, I accidentally found myself on the trail to the east that runs parallel to the ridge. The whole south and east sides of Judah are pretty icy and slick, with no easy tracks to follow if you don't count the deer footprints.", 'Didn’t do loop however still a great workout. Few patches of ice but you can walk around them ( by doing a little bit of bolder hoping) Once you get near the top snow shoes really help', 'We went November 18th. The mountain was covered in snow. Once we got to the top the trail was completely covered in snow so we just explored on our own and hiked back down under the ski lift. You will defiantly need snow shoes once you get to the top (we rented them for the week from rental shop where we live). If we didn’t have snowshoes and gps we probably would have turned around. The views are beautiful and the land that you can scale in snowshoes an awesome experience!', 'Took the hike early summer. Great hike all the way around', 'Great hike. Somewhat confusing junction after crossing over Judah when descending at PCT T-junction, not signed but take a right back toward sugar bowl to reach Donner Summit lot', 'We are not fond of the beginning (or end) portion of the trail which consists of rocky switchbacks on the face of the mountain but then it becomes a pretty reasonable trail. Lots of people and dogs. Beautiful scenery. Took us 3.5 hours but we are in our late 50s.', 'Beautiful hike. Moderate level. Would definitely do it again.', "Great trail, first part is the most challenging. Great views at both Donner Peak and Mt Judah. Took about 2.5 hours (didn't stay at summit for long as it was very windy).", 'Beautiful hike.  Some snow,Ice and mud.  The view at the top is amazing. It was a super cold day.   28 when we started.  SuperWindy at the summit but so worth it.', "Great hike. Wonderful views from the top. Left at 9:00am on a Saturday. We didn't see a sole until the split and then only a couple until we reached the top. Saw lots on the way down. Parking was also full at that time 1:00. (We're really out of shape ☺) It was a great workout for us!", 'Great round trip with some perfect trails for trail runners. Hi early though as this is a popular hike and gets super busy after 10am.', 'The begining of the trail is somewhat difficult as you walk on stones the loop after is easier, the slop is gently bringing you at 8200 feet, it is worth it for the view and different landscapes, our 10 years old, did it without a problem, even younger kids were able to do it, make sure you have the right equipment (shoes, water (there is not a lot of shades))', 'Absolutely beautiful views', "Such a fulfilling hike. Please do not do when it is hot as it is mostly without shade. I met some amazing people.  Please complete if you are working towards a higher elevation. My fav couple was I am guessing in their 60's and they rocked it!  Love and Mother Nature rules! YOU can do it!", 'The hike has beautiful views the whole way up, but the vista at the summit ridge is easily he highlight.', "Beautiful views.  Took a detour and climbed the rocks to catch view of Donner Lake.   There's a box hidden under the granite rocks where you can leave a note to share your experience with the next hikers.  Getting to the top was a little challenging, but well worth the views.   Coming back down you get to see some spectacular terrain.  Make sure you don't miss the beautiful moss growing on the trees.   Pay attention to the forks in the trail towards the end of the loop, it can be tricky getting on the right trail.  We would definitely do it again.", 'Beautiful trail, not too far but enough for a good workout. Great morning trip!', 'Beautiful, diverse hike. Lots of hikers of all ages out today. Lots of sun, but storm clouds were just around the corner. Gradual incline and decline. I agree that this is moderate (more challenging than easy), but some with knee issues might find it difficult with lots of steeper granite steps.', 'Completed this hike on 8/16/17. Mt Judah loop is one of the most beautiful hike I have done this year. The scenery was filled with different types of natural scenery. There are beautiful rock formations and various types of flowers and trees. Moreover, there was snow on the trail we had to walk across. We started late around 10:30am and got to Mt. Judah by 1pm. Along the way to Mt. Judah, we also visited Donner Peak. Donner Peak overlooks Donner Lake which the view was spectacular(I like Donner Peak more than Mt. Judah). During our descent, it sprinkled hard. The weather around the summer is quite bipolar, so, wear water proof gears. Descent took a little over one hour. Overall, this hike offers beautiful views of nature. It might be tough during some part of the trail due to incline and rocky trails but the reward is large. Would do this hike again.', 'Great hike! Definitely on the harder end of moderate though as the climb is continuously uphill - be prepared with good shoes and lots of water!', "Nice moderate hike great views! Also beautiful wild flowers this time of year! It's crazy that there are still patches of snow near the top", 'You get a lot of bang for your buck!  Vistas, flowers, tall trees, this trail has it all!', 'great scenery and good distance', "One of the best day hikes I've ever been on!  Amazing views, crazy amounts of wildflowers, some patches of snow.  Varying terrain keeps it interesting.  Highly recommend.", 'Beautiful trail! Well maintained and gorgeous views.', "It's a short, alpine wilderness loop trail with lots of flowers and a couple nice spur trails along the way to little peaks. The trail isn't far from the interstate, and clearly popular but still quiet, especially after 5pm. The climbing is steady and not too difficult. I enjoyed being there and getting that exercise so much that I walked the loop twice, and got good and worn out, the best.", '01AUG17 Lower & mid-hike slopes & small meadows of beautiful wildflowers ("Spring" in August)', 'The wildflowers were beautiful as was the  moss on the trees.  I recommend this trail if you like to go through woods and open fields.  The top has really nice views as well.  It was a bit crowded today but ppl were pleasant', "Terrain: Rocky in sections, mostly soft dirt
Sun/Shade: Very exposed (it is above the tree line)
Views: wildflowers (late summer), views of Tahoe National Forest and two lakes, beautiful rock formations
Difficulty: 3/5 (5=Very strenuous)
Overall rating: 4 stars

I completed this loop in early August on an overcast day that brought some rain while on the trail. If you're considering this trail for the 2017 season, I'd suggest going very soon - the wildflowers are out in full bloom (see my pictures).

This is a beautiful trail that was full of wildflowers (if you time it right) and views of Tahoe National Forest, including Lake Mary and Donner Lake.  Along the trail, you'll see lots of interesting rock formations. 

I ascended on the Mount Judah Loop Trail, then came down on the PCT (as AllTrails suggests).  It is a relatively steep climb for a moderate hike, and much of it is on rocky terrain, and it is completely exposed to the elements. Since it rained earlier in the morning, and while I was on the trail, parts of the trail can be slick.  I brought hiking poles and mid-rise hiking boots.  My husband had trail shoes and no poles, but he's much fitter than I am.

Once you get past the initial climb, you have a choice for how you want to ascend to the peak: Mount Judah Loop or PCT.  We did the loop and hit a patch of snow on our way to the peak along the Mount Judah Loop - we had to walk around it. It was very doable, but it might have proven much more challenging a week or two earlier. That being said, we met fellow hikers that did not go over or around the snow because it was raining.  We did, and it was worth it to get to the peak, and the trail down along the PCT.  At the peak, it is pretty barren, but you have nice views of Tahoe National Forest. We ate lunch overlooking Donner Lake.  It was chilly, but well worth it.

The trail had a lot of wildflowers when we were there - it looked like a garden - pretty amazing at this altitude.  There is a small forested section with trees covered in lichen and moss.  There were more wildflowers and tree groves on the PCT side - this side of the mountain seems more protected.  

The trail is relatively exposed, so on a sunny day, you would definitely need sun protection and a hat.  I think only about 10-15% of the trail offers shade.  While I got rained on, it was still perfect weather for this trail that would undoubtedly feel very hot given the elevation, steep ascent at the beginning, and lack of tree cover.  

Bring sunblock, a hat, poles, and bug spray. While we didn't need big spray, it was a very cool day.  I'd do this hike as soon as you can after the snowmelt - then you're likely to enjoy the wildflowers.", "Lots of nice wildflowers, and the snow at the top was easy to cross today July 30th.  The views from Donner Peak and Mount Judah are awesome!  If you're carrying a filter there is only one spot with snow runoff on the way up to refill, so plan accordingly & bring enough water.
Traffic on the trail is pretty high, my only reason for deducting a star.  It's not the trail's fault, but all the groups of people did distract from the experience a bit.  Do this on a slow day and it's 5 stars all the way.", 'We hiked this yesterday. The wildflowers are still blooming but are almost finished. Get out there in the next week to enjoy them! There is only one snowpatch to hike over at the top.', 'I love this hike.  The view from the top is breathtaking....', 'Loved this trail. Excellent views along the entire route and easy enough for the entire family to traverse. We turned around at Donner peak, wish we had done the whole loop...looking forward to doing the entire loop next time!', 'very pleasant hike. lots of wildflowers! hiked over the weekend and still a couple of large snow patches.', 'We had a great hike today on Mount Judah Loop. Great trail for kids (ours are ages 8-11) and our dog too. Busy trail for a Wednesday.', 'Great views and a good workout without being to difficult to hike.', "A few snow fields.  And lots of people for a Monday.  Most hiking groups I've seen and most dogs.  What's great is everyone is friendly, kind and warm.  Best hikers with trail etiquette I've ever seen.", "Beautiful views and so many different things to see.  We ended up at snow so the trail became a bit confusing at that point but it was still worth it and something I'd do again.  I went with my 64 year old Mom who rocked the Trail.  We were checking it out for my kids to see if it would be appropriate for their age range.  After hiking this trail I decided I won't be taking them until they are older because there are some narrow and very rocky areas that are not suitable for small children.", 'Great hike to gorgeous views of Donner Lake and Sugar Bowl.  Still has a bit of snow on the backside of the peak.  I also recommend a lil jaunt towards the smaller white stone peak which has the Donner Lake view and top roping set up', 'Great hike!!! Had to be creative around the snow but it was doable and it was rewarding succeeding the challenge. My fiancé and I are completely tired!!! Go early you will thank yourself it gets very hot after noon!  Great hike!', 'Beautiful hike. The trail has places where it was not clearly marked or the trail was covered with snow. But the AllTrails app kept me on target. Best hike ever and well worth the effort. If you start later in the day, it is pretty hot going up and I would suggest using the streams to cool down and wet your clothing.', 'Fun trail with some pretty nice views.  Very diverse as you progress, going from bare rocky switchbacks to conifer forests.  Went in July and still plenty of snow, making the hike a little more difficult.  Trail markings are sparse so keep an eye out, especially in the areas of snow, as the trail becomes less clear.  The summit is pretty awesome.  Those ski boundary signs are a bummer though, degrade some spectacular views!  Still worth it!', 'Magnificent Hike - The wildflowers were beautiful and the view from the top was fantastic.  Still some snow to get around which made it even more interesting.', 'Absolutely stunning. Still a little bit of snow, but easy to get around it.', 'awesome hike. took a detour for Donner peak. so gorgeous.', 'Gorgeous day on 7/17, with wildflowers on the ridge and a lot of snow to admire on surrounding peaks. What a stupendous hike! I completed he loop, but had to skirt, scramble, and in one place crawl, over large snow patches on the trail. The most challenging area was getting up to the ridge, where I needed hands and feet.', 'definitely marked as one of my favorite trails now. BEAUTIFUL!', "I have done this trail many times. It is spectacular as a wildflower hike. Some years better than others. Go counterclockwise as the east slope is in full sun and you want to be going downhill there. The view from the top is excellent. At the Donner saddle you can take a side trip to Donner Peak. Pretty easy except for the last 100 ft of elevation. Fantastic view  Also some years. Even in July. There is snow on the east side of Mt Judah. Can be tricky. Be careful. It's a long dangerous slide should you lose footing. Otherwise excellent trail", 'Still too much snow to hike the complete Mount Judah Loop as of July 3! Enjoyable nonetheless. Created a loop trail through ski slopes and road at lower elevations.', 'I love  this hike.', "Did the hike mid-June of 2017 and as others have mentioned there is still quite a bit of snow. This makes finding the trail a fun exercice. The view of the valleys on both sides as you climb up is stunning but the true treasure is the 360 view from the very top. I'd highly recommend planning on stopping up there for lunch to really spend time taking the scenery in. The snowy tops observed from a blossoming summit can keep me going for hours.The hike is easy and short. Since we couldn't see much of the trail we decided to just go straight up under the sugar bowl chairlifts. Perfect for a one-day/afternoon outing.", 'As of June 18, 2017: due to the 160% of normal snowfall of 2016-17, this trail is not (as of date) very passable. Right now, you should take an ice ax and crampons to get across steep sections of snow over the trail. Just 1/4 mile in, you must cross a snowfield that, if you slipped, would slide you fast down and onto a boulder field. Yet, past this, most of the trail is clear and good, until you get up to where it crosses the Sugar Bowl ski area. Then, the snow patches become continuous and often steep, and without GPS, the trail is hard to discern. Very pretty up there. The map route posted here is not adhering to the loop trail, probably due to detours around snow patches. All in all, it would be best to wait a month or more to hike this excellent trail, and follow the trail markings on the map via GPS.', 'Loved this one!  Did it wth our 6 and 8 year old kids.  One part was pretty steep drop off but great views!', "The hike was 1/2 up hill and 1/2 downhill but the view was so pretty! Perfect for beginners that want to hike high but can't commit to a too many miles.", '5.5 mies with 1220 ft elevation increase. Pretty Moderate to strenuous at times. It is well worth the hike to the top for the gorgeous views of Donner Lake and the area! Portapotty at the trailhead. Bring water. Several dogs on the trail. Great hike!', 'Awesome 3 hour hike through the forests with great views. Easily accessible.', 'Great trail!', 'Awesome hike!! Take PCT and you where go right or left.  The view up top is amazing!!!!', "Can't wait to go back when the wildflowers are blooming!", 'Spectacular views and lovely forests. Gives you a great sense of how the transcontinental railroad was put in.', 'Great hike. Popular trail. I recommend to start early. Great view at the top of mt Judah.', 'Really busy, a big tourist spot. Trail is almost always congested, but on a clear day, the views from the top of Donner Lake and a 365 of the Sierras is worth it! Fun boulders to climb at the top, and a perfect spot to eat lunch and enjoy the view before heading back down. Dog friendly, most dogs off leash. Windy at the top!', 'Not good.  Windy, boring, no payoff.', 'Busy holiday weekend, but worth the traffic.', "One of my 3 children has a cold. We went back about 3/4 away up. We ate lunch overlooking Mary Lake. Not bad I've been on better. His cold gave us the excuse to head back. Maybe we will do it again in full. Not sure if our heart wasn't into it or it was something about the trail that left us feeling average rather than superb.", 'Had a lot of variety as I tend to like loop trails much more than out and back. Two photographers in our group so we had plenty to shoot along the way. Rocky switch-backs at the start but mostly packed dirt the whole loop.', 'nice 3 hr hike.  great 360 view at top', 'School's back- and what better way to "celebrate" than going out to Donner Pass? Our school generously took the Class of 2020 out to Donner Pass for three days, and the highlight of the trip was unquestionably this hike.

The hike starts out on a rocky switchback trail. You will walk only on rocks (no dirt or vegetation,) but you will be able to easily stay on the trail. The entirety of the 0.9 mile leg is composed of broken-down boulders. A great leg if you like hiking along boulderfields.

The first peak you'll have the chance to summit is Donner Peak. The views from the top are unrivaled by any others in the area; you get a view of both Lake Mary and Donner Lake, as well as Van Norden and the Chinese-constructed tunnels in the distance.

You will then hike along a ridge up to Mount Judah (beware the false summit halfway from Donner). The path is sturdy, albeit narrow, and can be done with relative ease. Mount Judah offers a view of Sugarbowl Ski Resort (Mt. Lincoln) and the Pacific Crest Trail. In the distance, a small patch of snow could be seen on Tinker Knob.

The rest of the loop is mainly through a peaceful forest and/or meadow. You will pass four streams in the early summer (dried out by August, unfortunately.) You'll have a brief stint through a ski resort before returning on the aforementioned boulderfield path.

Beware of yellowjackets. Two of my friends got stung on Donner Peak alone. Move away from water sources or limit your breaks to stay clear of these pests. Do not let the bees keep you from hiking this trail- it's a must do!', "Absolutely loved this trail, not difficult and the views at the top are amazing. Trail markers are minimum but it's self explanatory and usually there are a good bit of people on the same trail just in case", 'This trail does not seem to exist where marked on map.  It seems to refer to a trail in the Sierras (several hundred miles away), or at least that what the pics look like. It does not seem to exist on the Boonville Ukiah Road.', "Great hike with amazing view and rocks to scramble up all the way. Plan on it taking around 3 hrs. if you aren't going fast. But the views are well worth the walk.", 'I soloed this trail today and really enjoyed it. Gonna sleep well tonight. Friendly fellow hikers along the route', "Completed this hike in a little under three hours. It's an easier hike (I managed it with carrying my toddler) with beautiful views. The start is a rockier and the day we hiked it, haze had set in- but it was still great!", 'Great hike!', 'Lots of loud hikers during this time of year. Good hike, lots of wildflowers. Take the short side track to check out Donner Peak along the way for amazing views.', 'Really nice traile, dog friendly, amazing view,  i have done it twice and i can do it again', 'Beautiful hike❤️', 'This is a lovely trail. Not one bit of it we did not enjoy. Still a few patches of snow, but nothing to worry about especially if you have poles.', 'Nice little trek, uphill all the way to the top, down hill all the way back. Beautiful views of the High Sierra.', 'Awesome trail. Starts at the pacific crest trail that leads to the Mt Judah loop trail. Easy and slight snow on the trail still. Views are amazing at the top. Bring bug spray. Would do it again !!', "amazing view of the Sierras.  not a very difficult hike.  be careful of the snow; it's slick.  If you're not somewhat experienced then check out Donner peak or wait for warmer weather", 'Still snowy in early June as we had a lot of snow coming down this year. Parts of the trail are covered through with snow, but you can easily spot footprints from others who have made their way through to continue the path. Great views up top!', 'Great hike with the kids and dog.  Took a good part of the day as I have smaller children.  Pretty windy near the top, but beautiful views.', 'This was a cool hike. Snowshoes make it very challenging. I was a little disappointed at first. It looked like we were going to hike Sugar Bowl ski resort but only had to cut through one slope. We headed the trail counter clockwise and it worked out fine. The uphill /side hill was not easy! The view from the top was very nice.
Winds on the top were at least 40mph.', 'Awesome views. The elevation climb was a little rough for someone with asthma.', "Unfortunately it was too smoky to really see the view, so I guess I'll need to go back for this one. :-)", 'My Fitbit tracked it at 6.25 miles. Good training ground for backpacking. Saw a few dogs on the trails and some children as well. It can get warm in some areas of the trail so layers would be good to wear (remove your hoodie when walking towards the summit). There is a porta potty at the beginning of the trail and nothing else throughout the whole hike. View of Donner lake is spectacular.', "I love the trail even if it's rocky to get to the beginning of the Mt Judah trail. Breathtaking view especially at the top of the mountain. Absolutely one of my favorite.", 'Really solid hike! Beautiful scenery.', 'Great hike to do!!!', 'I would rate this as an easy/moderate hike.  Nice views of Donner Lake from top of Mt Judah.  A lot of switchbacks at the beginning/end of the hike, but once past those, the trail becomes a lot more manageable.  Trail has some steep drop-offs on the back side of the mountain.  Nice day hike for the family (youngest being 10).', "My husband and I hiked this trail in August '15 and it was amazing. It was my first time in California, and I have never hiked at such high elevations (being from GA). The trail starts out a bit hard because of all the rocks and most of the elevation gain was in the beginning. We ran into a lot of people finishing the trail (it was around 2pm when we started), but by the time we got to the ridge we were the only hikers on the trail. The views were breathtaking, the most beautiful I have ever seen! It was my favorite part of our week-long stay in CA and I can't wait to go back and do more hiking. I wouldn't recommend the trail for young kids because of the very rocky terrain in the beginning, but if your an adult in decent shape than do this trail- you won't regret it! FYI, we got a map for the trail from the Donner Museum- and I can't thank the young lady who recommended the trail enough! And if you are pale skinned and not use to elevation like me- make sure you pack plenty of sunscreen! The sun is intense up there!", 'The top of this trail is beautiful, when you get to the top you can see what I would guess is 100 miles in one direction and 50 in the other, a local hiker who we spoke to on the way down said the top is "the crest" of the PCT. The first half mile of the trail is actually advanced and all rocks stacked on rocks but the rest is intermediate and we'll groomed, remember not to veer off into the service roads. The trail is actually 6.5 miles from the road, the first mile is just technically a different trail, but I don't know how you could avoid this first mile unless you could fly. Overall, for a guy from southern California this trail was well worth the effort.', 'Trail was very rocky to start.  Then It between woods and sunny areas.  Great views of Donner Lake.  It was much longer than 4.5 miles.   According to my fit bit it was more like 6.5.  Views at top were fantastic.', 'Great hike convenient for a stop on way from Sacramento to Reno. We hiked in early July and the wildflowers were tremendous. Views are outstanding, of Donner Lake and surrounding peaks. Very nice. Be careful with the roads that cross the PCT; signage could be better.', 'Beautiful views of Donner Lake and the surrounding Sierras. I would rate this trail as moderate - got our our hearts pumping on the uphill. It can get a bit busy on the weekends (especially with a holiday), so we recommend an early start to avoid the crowds.', "Done this twice - views from the top of Mt Judah and Donner Peak are great.  Donner Peak has a wonderful natural labyrinth on top which is great for kids. I'd rate the full loop as moderate rather than easy - I measured 2000' of elevation gain over 5.1 miles.", "Okay, now that I have officially completed this hike it was AMAZING. I am 26 years old, and it moderate shape as far as stamina and strength goes. I am also from FL, so the elevation kind of took the wind out my sails a little, making the trail more difficult (for me). I was also carrying my 2 year old in the Kelty; he weighs about 26 pounds and I had an additional 20 pounds of water and food and emergency gear in the pack bringing the total to about 46 pounds. All this being said, if you want to carry your child in a hiking carrier, you DEFINITELY need hiking/trekking poles. DEFINITELY. I wouldn't go up the first set of switchbacks, nor would I traverse the narrow trails with sheer sides with a kid on my back without them. There is a lot of loose gravel and rock on many sections of the trail. So long as you use your situational awareness, and have proper gear, you'll be fine. Bring lots of water and snacks. This trail was seriously amazing, and afforded the most amazing, spectacular views. Even on a hazy day like today. Just a heads up, there is little to no shade once you're on the Judah loop, so if you bring children bear that in mind. I personally wouldn't let a child under 11 or 12 walk alone on this one. 

The start of the trail is just a brown sign with a white arrow pointing toward the trailhead. It isn't super clearly marked. There are two logs you step over to get on the trail. Just park in the parking lot of the Soda Springs Ski academy and walk down to the bottom of the hill and you will see it.", "I actually have a question. I hope someone who has hiked this trail sees this! I am trying to plan a hike on this trail, but I have a 2 year old whom I carry on my back in a Kelty Tour 1.0 hiking child carrier. While it does distribute the weight like a normal hiking backpack would, my balance is still slighly off when I carry him. So my question about this trail is this: Can I hike with him on my back safely? I am concerned about losing footing and falling off a cliff, or sliding down a steep rocky incline/decline. Thank you! Unfortunately this website doesn't have a function to ask questions.", 'Well maintained trail. Nice views at top. Moderate difficulty in a few spots, especially at the start. Dog friendly but start is rocky for dogs with tender paws', 'The view alone makes this trail worth it.
Make sure you take time to wander a little bit. There are multiple lookout points that are amazing if you step off the trail briefly.', "one of our favorites! we do it often by either going to Judah summit, Donner summit, PCT to saddle, Anderson, Tinkers knob,etc. beautiful area, lakes, views of Donner are breath taking. been up when it's very windy and have to hold on to your hat and other times it's quite calm. see many people but not so many that you can't still feel the wilderness! bit of a climb up pleasant rocky switch backs soon after parking but the beauty  will keep your focus.", 'Great hike, pretty easy for experienced hiker in shape. Gorgeous views and eat to follow. Pretty busy trail but most hikers are awesome people so no worries.', "Beautiful hike! As you're traveling south on the PCT section of the trail, continue on for another 300 yards or so past the second turn off for the Mt. Judah Loop.  You'll come to a Donner party monument that is very informative and pretty cool. Great views also.", 'Definitely more than 4.5 miles- the hike to the trailhead for the loop alone is 1.5 miles.  I would say around 6 miles, a little less.  Fun uphill, beautiful views.', 'First things first, this hike is longer that 4.5 miles. Closer to six. I only say that because we had six kids under 10 and although we are very proud they did all 6 miles not sure I could have convinced them to do it if they knew it was 6. That said, great hike with lots of beautiful wild flowers and views. Bring plenty of water.', 'very nice trail, short drive from Reno, most excellent views', "Nice, clear trail. Only the beginning was tricky to find from some overgrown bushes, but they may be cleared. Views are great and it is nice to see a ski area when there isn't snow.", "nice hike. bring water and a camera. decent ascent, but not what I'd call strenuous.", "Mt. Judah Loop and Donner Peak – Pacific Crest Trail 5.5 Miles - 1700 ft Elevation Gain (7,100 - 8,243) 4-5 Hours

The PCT trail head is off Donner Pass Road.  If you are coming from Sacramento, take the Old Highway 40 exit in Soda Springs. Once you pass Sugar Bowl Rd you will come up to a cluster of buildings on the right, one of which is Sugar Bowl Academy. Pull in and drive to the back of the parking lot which is the beginning of the Old Donner Summit Rd. The PCT trail head is at the bottom of the hill. 

It's a great hike with some pretty stunning scenery. Most of the beginning was switchbacks with rocks, making your tired feet at the end of the hike a little unhappy… BUT – I’d do it again! The climb between Donner Peak and Mt. Judah was robust with several switchbacks. Once you get to the top it’s worth the effort and the way down had nice views of the Royal Gorge.", 'Love this trail! Amazing panoramic views, easy to follow, good workout, nice and short.  The first time I did this trail was in early July and the wildflowers were amazing.  Second time I ran it with a friend.  We actually had to hike the first part due to the steepness and rocks, but once the trail leveled out a bit nearing the summit we ran it easily all the way back to the trailhead.', 'Lynn and I were a bit apprehensive about going on this hike because of the description ... Altitude climb of over 1,700 feet! The first part of the trail was loaded with switchbacks ... and rocks. Karen's description was very appropriate,  "It appears we are ripping off the band aid quickly as the most difficult part of the hike is in the beginning" as most of the climb was at the beginning meaning most of the descent was at the end. There was a pretty healthy climb between Mt. Donner and Mt. Judah with a lot of switchbacks, as well. There were a few times I questioned my own sanity, but it was well worth the efforts! Absolutely breathtaking views all around! As always, I've included a link to my blog that's filled with photos that are too large to upload here. (And, yes! I'd do this hike again and again!)', 'Loved this hike! Scenic the whole way. Huge ass trees. We went to Donner peak before going to Mt. Juda . Good workout and great trails. Definitely going back. ', 'This is a nice trail, though busy.  This is not a wilderness trail, you are basically in Sugar Bowl,  though it makes a nice run with the hill and is well maintained (and new).  Great views including Royal Gorge on the way back down to the PCT.  you can also include Donner Peak from the saddle between Donner Peak and Mt. Judah..', "I actually didn't get to do this trail as they were running a triathlon on the weekend we were there. I did want to comment on the other post. Once you get to Donner Lake you need to make a right onto Donner Pass Road and continue up the mountain towards Mount Judah in order to find the trailhead. ", 'Nice hike, with great views! For some reason the map was telling me the trail head was down by donner lake, took me a while to find it. Brought the dog, and the terrain was not too bad at all! Recommend this hike to anyone of any skill level!', "This is one of my favorite hikes.  You get a good work out, lots of vistas and different terrain too, all in around 2 1/2 to 3 1/3 hours depending on your pace and side trips.

We usually head for this hike in July and August especially if its been a snowy winter.  You always get a nice breeze here and its typically 15 degrees cooler or more than the valley.  Today was another great hike.  Since the snowfall last winter (2013) was light, there were only a few snow ponds to traverse.  Lots of spring flowers though and they should last into July.  

There are many great spots to stop and soak in the majesty of the mountain views, and with Donner lake in view at the summit, well  it doesn't get much better than this.  There are many side trails to take for even more spectacular views.  

It can get a little busy in July and August but not so much to detract from the hike.  You'll usually run into people hiking the PCT too.  Your on the PCT for a short period.  And there's history to be experienced here too.  A little side trip to Roller Pass and you get a first hand look at where the pioneers dragged their wagons, Oxen and all their gear up shear slops.  

Bring plenty of water and a good hat.  Enjoy!", 'This hike is truly great. Wonderful views. May want to go later in the season unless you have snow shoes. I went on 5/18/13 and some parts of the trail were covered in snow and I was unable to reach the summit once you hit higher elevations. Will go again!', "My friends and I loved this hike! It was an absolutely beautiful/well kept trail with awesome views. We included Donner Peak in our loop for some additional distance/difficulty. The trip took us about 2 hrs and 40 mins for the 6 mile loop. It was quite windy at the top of Mt. Judah, though it was not the warmest of days (in the 50's). Everyone in my group really enjoyed the trip and I would definitely do it again. ", '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Towsley Canyon Loop Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'birding', 'hiking', 'mountain biking', 'nature trips', 'trail running', 'walking', 'forest', 'hot springs', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'muddy', 'rocky']
hike_description: Towsley Canyon Loop Trail is a 5.6 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Newhall, California that features hot springs and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
