user_texts:
['Absolutely perfect - so beautiful, challenging, and easy to do in one morning or afternoon!', 'Gorgeous day, great views, nice to find snow on Christmas Eve. Hard packed snow was easy to navigate with hiking shoes or boots.', 'Micro spikes highly recommended. Icy patches off and on in lower elevations. Snow gets deep near the peak. Trail may be hard to follow after fresh snowfall. This is a moderate trail but not one I would go on without the proper gear. Saw people heading up at nearly sunset as we were coming down who were under-equipped and without any concept of how long the trail takes to complete.  Be safe, not sorry, especially in the middle of a government shutdown which means no rangers out patrolling.', '12/14/18 You will have a better day hiking if you bring micro spikes! Patchy icy snow for first 1/2, lots of soft snow 2nd 1/2 to the top. It’s cooler so dress warm and trail tip: at Saddle Junction you must make a hard RIGHT turn (almost like a U-turn) or you will end up on the wrong trail like we did! Thanks to the AllTrails map & GPS we connected to the correct trail after 30 min! You can’t see the trails because of the snow so make sure your phone is charged so you can keep checking the AllTrail map!', 'Made it to about a half mile from summit. too much snow and sun goin down. Ice to saddle then powder the rest of the way made it slow but well worth it. Amazing views  past saddle along ridgeline. not too strenuous. Most elevation to saddle. Will do again definitely. Make sure you get a parking pass or adventure pass. Also need permit at ranger station. Self serve. Got there at 7am on a sat. and about 6 permits were left.', 'Such a beautiful hike all the way to lookout tower. enjoyed the hike up but decent was very hard on my knees even using my poles. Will do it again', 'The hike to the saddle completes most of the elevation gain.  From there to Peak is flat or gradual gain.   Really pretty hike.  Lots and lots and lots of dogs on trail.   If you get there by 7am or earlier you pretty much have the trail to top by yourself.   Coming down in late morning or early afternoon and you will pass excessive amounts of people.   Bathrooms at trailhead and all trails well marked.   I started hike at 7am and was the only one on top.   Did see 4 people coming back down.   All but one spent the night camping.', 'Gorgeous hike! Stop at ranger station in town for parking permit and trail pass. Learned that hard way. Wilderness up there is just gorgeous! Saw one black rattle snake on trail near top.', 'Dope trail dope views dope! there was snow towards the end but didn’t bring micro spikes so it was kind of sketchy.', 'Great hike! Clearly marked, beautiful views, steady climb and well maintained!', 'Great hike, nice views, not too strenuous and beautiful weather', 'Great hike.  Beautiful with different views that are amazing. Trail is not rocky which I love.  Some switch backs but not many. The peak is incredible. It can get windy but we got lucky and it was calm.  The tower allows you to see forever views.', 'Got the last permit and hiked to the fire lookout via Devil’s Slide on Saturday, Sept 1. Didn’t see a lot of people on the way up, but saw quite a few on the way down. The volunteers arrived just after we did and unlocked the fire lookout. It’s a great view, and well worth the hike. On the ridge top you will see where the firefighters stopped the fire this summer.It took us just over 5 hours round trip including 30 minutes to enjoy the view on top. GPS showed 8.6 miles round trip.', 'Absolutely breathtaking views. A lot of people stopped once they got to saddle junction. DON’T. follow it to the peak. The views are amazing and the volunteer at the fire tower is extremely kind and friendly. Great hike.', "not anything like the sierras but amazing for down here. I wouldn't rate this moderate, it should be rated easy. although the incline is pretty significant in the first 2.5 miles, taking your time upon ascending will prevent you from getting overly tired.", 'Fire look-out was unoccupied but the deck was open. The views where oddly good given the usual summer haze.', 'This was my first time all the way to the ranger station, there are not words to describe it (You have to see it) in my first hike to Saddle Junction (over 18 years ago) I have my 4 years old son in my shoulders round trip, it was late and my wife didn’t want to keep going, this’s time I took my son (23 years already) and we really enjoy the trip, it was somehow emotional, because my son’s mother divorce me (without a reason) and she was missing in the trip. Check my pictures but better yet DO IT, you wouldn’t regret.', "A lot of elevation gain and heavy traffic,  but we'll marked and maintained.   Great views along the way and a 360 view from the peak", 'The views from the fire lookout are just mesmerizing!The trail is well kept and easy to follow!The trail from beginning to end is absolutely beautiful.', "Really enjoy this hike. It's not that difficult but great for intermediate hikers.    Scenery is beautiful.  You can do the loop to Red Tahquitz through Saddle Junction to make it a longer hike.   Just love the scenery.   The ranger station was closed for repair so couldn't walk up the stairs.   When I got to parking lot at 7am there was only two cars there.   When I got back down, and after passing about 50 people going up, the parking lot was full.   Weekends, as with every LA area hike, get there early.   You also need the American the Beautiful or Day Pass for parking and a permit to hike this trail which can be obtained in the town of Idyllwild about 2.6 miles before the trailhead.  First 2 1/2 miles are the struggle and plenty of shade.   Last 1.4 miles is pretty level or low uphill so once you get to junction with all the signs the hard work is over.", 'Great trail. Amazing views from the top. Well covered most of the hike. Good elevation from the start.  It does get a bit busy but it’s a most do hike.', 'Great views from the peak!', 'We made it a couple of hundred yards away from the lookout and had to stop because we didn’t have poles or micro spikes.  Incredible views throughout the hike.  Can’t wait to do it again with the proper equipment.', 'Beautiful trail. The first half is a moderate uphill on the devil’s slide trail then you come to the junction to the PCT. The trail was covered in snow which made it difficult on the final accent to the peak so plan accordingly.', "Hiked to the look out 3/24/18. First half to Saddle Junction no snow,  but after that there was snow all the way to the peak.  Bring micro spikes, trekking poles, beanie & gloves unless you're a young(er) superstar! I saw many people who turned around because they didn't have the proper boots or traction (saw a girl wearing Vans slip on tennis shoes and no socks). This is my first time doing this hike and I loved it! The entire trail is so beautiful and picturesque, I was never bored!", 'Beautiful hike. I usually approach Tahquitz Peak from South Ridge Trail which IMHO is more challenging, especially the switchback push at the end. There was ice patches along the shady parts of trail — way before the saddle, and snow at the top. Micro spikes and pokes came in handy! A little windy here and there, otherwise was a gorgeous day. OH and one hour in I spotted a black bear paw track, about six inches in width. See pics!', 'Beautiful views and well kept trails!! A bit of ice at the top by the fire lookout but clear besides that.', 'Hiked this trail last Sunday, snow on the ground from beginning to end. Beautiful views and moderate elevation gain throughout. Hope to go again soon.', 'Beautiful views, not very crowded.', 'Hiked this trail up to the fire tower and was not disappointed.  Long but easy trail; last 10 minutes to tower pretty steep but well worth it.  Views are amazing and would definitely do it again.', 'Beautiful hike.  Currently has snow at the top, in case you were unaware of that like I was.  Weather was great in shorts and a t-shirt for the lower half, upper half was a little cold for that.  Great hike in SoCal!', 'Hike today with my 8 year old son... beautiful hike, easy to follow trail.  Beautiful view from the top.  It took a total of just over 4 hours round trip.  Weather in Idyllwild was mid 60s...  we hiked in short sleeves and were comfortable, even though most of paths were shaded.  Surprising not very crowded.  A great way to spend New Years Day!', "It's winter. But today I hiked to the Tahquitz fire lookout cabin via Devil's Slide out of Humber Park in shorts! And I wasn't the only one! Wonderful day! I have hiked to the same destination a few times before via south Ridge Trail. Today's route is definitely more trafficked--allows dogs whereas the other does not; also a lot shadier. Both are excellent. If you want a cooler route, take Devil's Slide; if you crave more sun, head up South Ridge. Happy hiking!", 'Hiked this today and I was the first and only one up before 10am.  I passed four other hikers on my way down.  Cold, windy day but made for a beautiful view at the lookout.', 'Awesome hike. Im a Bigfoot enthusiast and Tahquitz is an Indian word for Sasquatch or Mountain Ape.', 'it was a great hike definitely not the out of shape people, a significant elevation gain 95% of the elevation gain is on the way to the lookout, back down is really all downhill.', 'The hardest part was the devils slide part is uphill climb but my 7 year old did it we stopped at the junction or lunch then pushed to the peak the last half mile of the peak is tough and tight trail so if u have kids or pets be cautious.. we loved this hike and it was worth it!!!', 'Gorgeous views all around at the top! Outstandingly well-maintained and breathtaking trail. Apple’s Health app said 9 miles. Took me 5 hours, 3 going up and 2 going down. Took 3-4 5 minute breaks and many 1-2 minute breaks going up. I consider myself to be sorta-kinda-in-shape. Easy to get to, just take Ferndale all the way to the topmost parking lot if you can. Saddle Junction is beautiful by the way, and at the top you can talk to some cool volunteer fire look-out guys!', 'Great little hike. Make sure you have a parking pass for Humber park. That is where you will park and the trail head is. Amazing views of giant granite formations. Amazing tree coverage. Great getaway for tourists and San Diegans.', 'A very beautiful hike! The first 2.5 miles of Devil’s Slide Trail are a workout. Once you make it up to the junction, the rest of the trail is gentle and fun. You can climb the fire tower for stunning views and maybe even see all the way to Catalina. This is one of the best hikes in Idyllwild, so arrive early on summer weekends to find parking.', 'Super steep but super cool! Definitely coming back!', 'Great hike, 1st mile and last 1/2 has good elevation gain but not too bad.  Gorgeous views.  Busy trail but enough room for everyone.  Weather gets cooler as you reach elevation.', "great trail! the 1st and last mile or so have pretty good elevation climb. A Lot of the trail is shaded. definitely bring a light jacket you can take on and off. pick up your hiking pass at the ranger station. there's a stack of them available outside the doors, so you don't have to wait until 8 am when they open to grab one. they're free. adventure pass is $30 and you can get pretty much at any gas station. bring plenty of water and snacks. beautiful views to enjoy lunch from the top!", 'We got up early and hit the trail by 8 am! It was fantastic!! For this hike you need an ADVENTURE PASS! Get it in town before you go the trail head, you will also need a parking pass that you can get at any ranger station. Bring lots of water and enjoy the views!', 'Great Hike! Took my 9 and 12 year old and they did great. The initial mile and the last mile were the most challenging for everyone. Make sure you get your squirrel card if the lookout is open.', 'Great trail! Make sure to bring plenty of water. The fire watch station at the top is definitely worth the trip.', 'Nice steady climb. Saddle junction is large and a great place for a rest/snack. The fire lookout is awesome. Great views all around.', 'Me and my 6 year old son did this hike on August 9, 2017. Most of the trail was shaded it was a great hike. There was a small ranger station at the peak. A ranger invited us to come into the station and he gave my son a ranger certified card. My son was so excited!', 'went late july mid day.  was a nice hike.  Not an uncomfortable hike, but was ready to be down the hill the last mile or so.  Saw a rattlesnake cross the trail on our way back down shortly after summit.', 'Beautiful views all the way around! Definitely worth the climb to the top!', 'Incredible view at the top! Definitely worth the climb. Bring lots of water and sunscreen. Dogs are allowed on this trail but must be on a leash.', 'Awesome views. Worth the trip to the peak to see the fire lookout.', "So beautiful. Started at South Ridge then made my way from Tahquitz Peak to Humber Park via this trail. The Pacific Crest Trail portion of this hike is on the east ridge of the mountain ridge, offering much welcomed shade from the dense pine trees. Once you connect to Devil's Slide, be ready for hot afternoon sun, especially as you descend to the lower portion of the trail. No cell service in Humber Park so if you need a ride be sire to arrange in advance.", 'Really cool. Was my first time, but definitely looking forward to doing it again.', 'Excellent trail with stellar views.  Great meditation spot at the lookout tower.  Awesome Memorial Day hike.', 'Lovely trail! Challenging uphill but the views at the top are spectacular!', "Great trail - it's amazing how much the terrain and environment changes with the elevation gain. Started with sun, went through rain, sleet, snow and back to sun again. Be sure to stop and get a permit at the ranger station - they are out there checking. Very friendly but they always ask for your permit.", "Hiked this trail on May 2 2017.  No snow on the way up to Saddle Junction.  About 0.5 miles past Saddle Junction snow patches began to impede the trail, but it was still passable with some care (and no special equipment).  Another 0.75 miles and snow blocked the path forward (~8550').  Was just a few yards from the ridge overlooking the gorge across from the peak, though.  Great spot for a rest, a snack, and then return to Saddle Junction.", 'My favorite hike, lots of switchbacks and the last mile up is a challenge but worth it. Amazing view at the top.', 'We loved this hike. We hiked in mid April and had to hike trough some pretty thick ice and snow to reach the top. We got there and really enjoyed it. But it was definitely challenging. The scenery is stunning and and views along the way are unreal. The weather was perfect and we could see for miles from the top. We saw lots of squirrels, colourful birds and a mystery black animal climbing a tree!', 'Gorgeous hike, but this time of year ( Late November) you need to be aware of the potential snow/ice conditions. The last set of switchbacks up to the peak was too dangerous unless you had micro-spikes on your boots. Continuous melting/refreeze had turned the trail into an ice-rink and we had to turn around. As we came back down it was clear the many of the hikers coming up the slide had no idea that even at the saddle it was really quite cold, snowy and icy.', "Great day in Nov for a hike. Did this trail having never been to the area. Length was closer to 9m when all was said and done. The scenery is stunning and It's pretty much uphill the whole way. The second part of the climb is easier. Bring minimum 2 liters of water!Note, you must have a car day pass and a permit. Pass is $5 and the permit is free. You can get them from the ranger station in Idyllwild. I went to the parking lot at the head and had to go back. There were rangers on the trail asking for the permit. Well worth the time and energy! Can't wait to do another trail here...", "Pretty strenuous hike, once you get to the junction it kinda levels out but it's still a great work out! Amazing views at the top. Once your into the forest you can go to the right off the trail and basically hit amazing views off any point. Worth it but bring a sweater, once your past the junction it's freezing!", 'Unbelievable. No words needed.', 'This was my first time to hike the area and I was impressed at all the opportunities to explore. This hike was a training run to get up San Jacinto at a later time, and all went really well. There were a few very scenic spots, including one along the PCT that offered a view to the ridge of Tahquitz Peak and Lilly rock, down to the parking area, and the area around San Jacinto. When I got to the fire lookout, I was fortunate to go inside and see how they spot fires. The view was amazing. I had lunch at the summit and found a benchmark as well. It was a great day.

https://youtu.be/l33KEkjcwAY', "Beautiful scenery. It's a steep climb going up. Worth  the effort", 'Great Hike nice views and fairly simple to follow the trail.', 'This was a great hike.  Great conditioning going up.  Had a great lunch to the top where you can see meadows with ferns awesome.', 'Not too difficult and the lookout was way cool', "My third time on the Devil's Slide trail. My second time hiking from Saddle Junction along the PCT to Chinquapin Flat. My first time, finishing this hike off by continuing another half mile up the South Ridge Trail to the Tahquitz Peak Lookout. Knowing the temps would be high 90's, I brought 6 liters of water drank over three liters and shared the rest with others who thought one bottle would be enough. Don't underestimate the hike and the weather. Bring as much as you can carry, even if you don't drink it all. We had our first encounter with a baby rattle snake today. Maybe 10 or 12 inches long. Keep your eyes and ears open. Most times rattlers will sense you coming and avoid you. Most snake bites occur when we startle them. So check your area when taking breaks and sitting down. The trail is great! The first 2.6 miles on the Devil's Slide are challenging. The 1.5 miles along the PCT are pretty easy and relaxing. We had lunch at Chinquapin Plat before heading up the last .5 miles on South Ridge Trail, which is just as challenging as the DST but mostly due to the elevation gain. The views and history of the Lookout are so worth the challenge.", 'Great trail. A million people up there.', 'Always a great hike!', "Incredible views.  Did this last Saturday and we could see all the way to Catalina, Baja California and Mexico, though I wouldnt have known that if the ranger hadnt pointed them out.
Also joined the Ancient and Honorable Order of Squirrels.  :)  Ask the ranger about that one.
If you're a beginner, you can make it.  For experienced, it was pretty easy.  Nothing too steep at all.  Very gradual.  And before you know it, you turn a corner and see the fire lookout station.

I take a lot of pictures so going up it took about 2.5 hours.  Coming down was 1.5 hours.", 'Favorite so far. Go to the fire lookout and sign the logbook!!', "Great hike. Not many on the trail. The weather was in the 70's and the views from the lookout where beautiful. Could see from Salton Sea to Catalina island.", "Fantastic hike.  Started at Humber Park about 8:30 and was at the fire lookout on Tahquitz Peak by about 10:30.  The first 2 miles are switchbacks with a steady uphill grade, but leaving early meant I was in shade the entire way up.  Once up to Saddle Junction, take the trail to the right and you've got another couple of miles to the Peak.  Most of this stretch is easy hiking with gentle up and downs.  The last 1/2 mile or so is steep up the side of the granite peak.  The view at the top was incredible, especially on a day with Santa Ana winds - seems like you could see forever.  There were a couple of volunteers in the look out, and they were more than happy to let me up there to take a look around and sign the visitor's log.  The trip back down was a breeze, all down hill.  
Overall, a great hike with plenty of tree cover so lots of shade.  Also, hike on a weekday if you can swing it - I went on a Friday and saw nobody on the way up and only a few people on the way back down.  The volunteer in the fire look out said that I was the first visitor that day, and the day before only 2 hikers had stopped by.  
I'll definitely be hiking this trail again.", "Incredible hike, so pleasant and then all of a sudden, you're at the top! The lookout tower is awesome, very fun way to check out the scenery. I'd recommend starting early!", "This trail is rated as easy, but let me tell you, it is 4 miles of harsh uphill switchbacks.  It took us six hours (I had to keep stopping) but it was the best hike I've ever completed:).", 'My husband and I loved this hike. We were fortunate enough for the lookout to be open when we arrived so we got the grand tour.  Beautiful view!', 'Great! Cleared the head. Left parking lot at 7am, back at 1pm after a luxurious return-leg lunch at saddle junction. Did the loop to make it about 9 mi?', "Fantastic views! I would also recommend taking the Tahquitz Meadow Loop back around to Saddle Junction, there's a lovely meadow and waist high-ferns along the trail.", 'Outstanding Trail, approximately 9 miles long, mostly . Plenty of elevation gain. Not for small children.Requires lots of  water in the summer. You  need atleast 2.5 liters.', "I have to say I was blown away by the view that this trail gives! All up and then down, we took more breaks on the way down actually. This almost nonexistent winter left most of the trail clear of snow and ice. However the last 0.5 miles had thick ice on it and with one side being a drop off many folks didn't want to go over it. I proceeded to the observatory but my friend stayed behind due to the ice. It's probably only a ten minute climb from where it starts to get bad. Make sure you grab a permit before you go! We didn't get stopped but the ranger station is in town and it's free. Beautiful trail!", 'If you hike in the winter, wear moisture wicking fabric and dress in layers, as temperatures can change a lot throughout the day and elevations. To add some miles and make this hike a loop… I hiked from Humber Park up Devils Slide to the peak, then hiked down South Ridge. South Ridge will lead to a dirt road you cant miss. Take this to the Ernie Maxwell trail, which takes you back to Humber Park. However, Devils Slide is the best trail in my opinion. There is not much snow right now because of the drought. So go do it. This place reminds me of Yosemite because of the granite rock. Gorgeous place.', "Winter hike to Tahquitz Peak via Devils Slide Trail is no joke. While the first couple miles were mild and snow-free, once you hit the saddle you might want to put on your spikey's. The last traverse to the summit was pretty scary for this hiking novice, but the payoff is absolutely worth it. It was soooooo windy up there! The view from the fire lookout tower was incredible. Not sure if I'll be trying that one in the winter again, but I'd be very content with a couple summer trips in the future. :)", 'Wonderful weather today. Had a very late start due to a meetup that was cancelled and had to come up with a quick plan. Started at 1140and was out by 330pm. There was ice and snow on the last 0.3mi of the trail to the lookout tower. People were manning the tower today and I got to sign the register. The skies were  very clear but on the way down the trail seemed even icier. Great fun. Hiked in tank top and shorts through the ice and snow!!', 'This is my first time hiking this trail after the fires. At saddle junction there are caution tapes taping off restricted areas. The weather was cool, crisp and windy.  The fog kept rolling in but avoided me throughout the trip, The views were amazing. However, I did see the portion in the distance that was burned.  It made me wonder what the trail looks like when you head to Wellman Divide from Saddle Junction....restricted now. It was great to be up there again. Taquitz was awesome as usual but just being in these woods helped to relieve my mind that the fires ruined everything.  There is still a lot of beauty left!!', "We walked this the day after it re-opened after the wildfires came through.  We had previously hiked South Ridge and Deer Springs, so this was interesting because we were seeing a lot of the same things, just from a different vantage point.  While South Ridge has incredible views to the south (and some to the west) the entire hike up, and Deer Springs has great views to the east much of the hike up, Devil's slide is much more varied.  You are basically meandering up the valley between Suicide Rock and Tahquitz, going up a very good gradient without it ever being too steep.  The views are in multiple directions, depending on which way the trail is meandering at any given time.  Then, at around Saddle Junction, the forest becomes much more open, which is a nice change of pace.  Walking southwards on the PCT part of the trail, it opens up even more, with good views to the north (including the burned areas of San Jacinto) and of Mt San Jacinto itself.  Once at Tahquitz, the unobstructed views to the south are amazing.  I definitely liked this better than Deer Springs (which was very nice, don't get me wrong), but am unsure whether I liked it better than South Ridge.  Basically the tradeoff is multiple views and multiple vantage points, plus more varied habitat, on Devil's Slide, versus outstanding views (albeit in only one direction) the whole way up on South Ridge.  You can of course do both by making a loop and combining with the Ernie Maxwell trail - if doing that, I would recommend going up Devil's Slide and down South Ridge.", 'Great trail and amazing views. Water is pretty much dried up mid July but found small streams near Tahquitz valley so be sure to bring up your own water. Very busy on the way down Sunday.  ', "This trail is one of my alltime favourites. It is a steady climb to Saddle Junction with intermittent views of the valley below.  Rangers check for permits so don't forget to get yours at the station in Idyllwild.  Once at the saddle the trek to Taquitz peak is moderately difficult till the last strenuous climb to the lookout tower. When I went there last time I was the only person there for about 20minutes.  Me and eagles. Awesome!!
DO IT!!", 'Just did this hike again. This is still one of my absolute favorite hikes!', 'Did the hike early Saturday morning (9/8/12) and had the trails all to myself majority of the time. It was my first time here and I thought it was amazing! I connected a bunch of trails and hiked a nice loop. Talk about some beautiful views. Parking lot--Saddle Jctn--Skunk Cabbage--Tahquitz Meadow--Tahquitz Peak-- Saddle Jctn back to the parking lot. ', 'Hiked the trail on Wednesday (15 Aug) awesome ran into only two other hikers.  Departed Humber park and went up to PCT and hiked to the over look short of the look out.  It was incredible what a view one of my favorite hikes.  The weather was fantastic fairly cool most of the day.  The views are truly amazing I took my time and enjoyed the view and just took it easy enjoying a rare day off from work.  The trail is well marked with lots of shade.  Went up and came down the same day....was happy to finally see the car at the end!', 'rangers present on a Saturday.  fairly easy hike with excellent views.  i began hiking with intention of hiking red tahquitz peak, but that it is off limits it turns out.  hiked early morning, saw some deer, back at the parking lot at 9:15 am.  humber park parking lot was packed.  hundreds of people loitered the area.  very popular destination.', "Great hike, fantastic views.  Did this today Feb 25 2012.  Hiked up to the Junction then back down.  Trail had lots of snow and ice but passable if you use some care, I would recommend micros.  The rangers were checking permits most of the day, so be sure to get a pass and make everyone's day easier. ", ' I live down the road from the trailhead so I go here often to take a hike and have some lunch with a great view. I highly recommend it, the views are incredible.', "Trail was easy to follow.  Started around noon. Saw 2 snakes on devil's slide, one being a rattler.  As I got closer to Tahquitz Peak the view got better and better, but if it wasn't so hazy I would've had a better view of the surrounding cities and lakes.", '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Los Penasquitos Canyon (from Lopez Canyon) - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'birding', 'hiking', 'horseback riding', 'mountain biking', 'nature trips', 'trail running', 'walking', 'views', 'waterfall', 'muddy']
hike_description: Los Penasquitos Canyon (from Lopez Canyon) is a 11.3 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near San Diego, California that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.

user_texts: ['Went by today and parking lot was closed with sign that all trails closed. Hasn’t rained in a week so not sure why closed.', 'The waterfall is worth it. Pack for a picnic!', 'Great hike, pretty easy. Dogs enjoyed it as well.', 'This is a very nice trail for children. There isn’t any incline, and there’s great scenery and wildlife to entertain kids.', 'Very hot! Would be best early am hours. However it was a very nice work out.', "We started at the Sorrento Valley Rd Parking lot, crossed over to the North Trail at the Wagon Wheel Crossing and stayed on the North Trail until the Carson's Crossing when we returned back on the South Trail.  The waterfall wasn't much of a waterfall due to lack of rain recently, but the area was still pretty.  There is a lot of wildlife to see - all kinds of birds (even saw some hummingbirds in the trees at Carson's Crossing), lizards, butterflies, dragonflies, and scat from a bunch of different animals that reside in the Preserve.  There is some shade, but not much so be sure to bring lots of water, a hat, sunscreen, and clothing to shield you from the sun.  It is an easy hike with minimal inclines.  The trail is a mix of loose sand, packed sand, hard dirt, loose rocks.  There are a lot of unmarked trails connecting to the main trails so make sure to bring a map to keep track of where you are.  The bathroom at the parking area is a single portable toilet. Signs at the trailhead indicate the area has ticks, but the paths are quite wide in most places and easy to stay on the trail - doesn't hurt to use bug spray just in case. We went midday on a weekday and only saw a few other people (some on bikes and some walking) - however, I can see how this can be a busy trail during peak times.", 'Fun and easy hike', "great Trail for running. don't play your music too loud with  ear buds you'll get run over by bikers!", 'I really enjoyed the trail with my husband & 3 yr daughter. Very easy and scenic but was disappointed when I only saw a running stream of water instead of an actual waterfall as signs say. It had just rained a couple of days before so I thought for sure the “waterfall” would be flowing beautifully!', 'decent trail, easy walk to stream. this hike tends to be crowded around the stream with multiple routes to get there.', 'Desent flat hike, waterfall was more of a stream but good hike', 'Not great views. Didn’t make it to the waterfall but will go back to fo to the Canyon side!  Watch out for bikers! They go by really fast', 'It’s a beautiful trail next time I’ll go when it’s not so over cast', 'Beautiful trail .. the end is worth it', 'Pretty boring hike.', 'Easy trail, with beautiful scenery!  Takes you from near the 805 to almost the 15!', 'Very nice cenare I do not recommend biking this trail unless you a pro biker.', 'Good easy hike / walk. Nice water feature. Wouldn’t exactly call it a waterfall but still good. Trail had some good coverage and shading so we weren’t burning in the sun the entire time. Need to pay for parking ($3) if you park at the parking lot along Black Mountain Road.', 'Easy long walk/hike', 'the waterfall is what makes this trail so great!', 'Amazing waterfall in SD city limits', 'Thoroughly enjoyed trail running Lopez Canyon.', 'polol', 'Had some trouble finding parking with Yelp app. The address on AllTrails is accurate. The tree on GPS map is where the waterfall is at.', 'Went hiking here last weekend, lots of people on the trail mostly bikers make sure to be here early. Most of the trail is loose dirt and pebbles/rocks which makes it harder to get through. There is a few nice nature views although the "waterfall" half way through is just a creek. Its an okay hike easy/moderate because of the length... bring plenty of water!', "Easy trail, but lots of direct sun on main trail. I wouldn't say it had a waterfall though, more like water tumbling over rocks. The side trails were gorgeous, with lots of shade, especially near the stream. You can park on the side of the road or pay the parking fee in the main lot.", 'The sign at the beginning of the trail say that the waterfall is 2.7 miles in, but our GPS clocked it at 3.27. Not a lot of distance, but on a hot day like today it mattered. Nice easy trail, with nice views and water in several spots.', 'Great hike- worth the view at the end. The waterfall was great.', 'Best when the water is flowing good.', 'Nice area to explore, especially the waterfall after a rain.', 'went to the South Side it was more difficult than I thought make sure you take the trail and not the one towards the canyon because you have a choice to go left or right and we went the wrong way first (Right) and probably 2 miles out of our way it was pretty hot and the hike was pretty far three miles up and down Rocky trails we forgot to bring water which was a bad idea the waterfall was cooler than I thought it was going to be! busy with kids thro', 'Well maintained and interesting trail close to home. It can get busy on the weekend but the crowds can be avoided on the Northern end.', "Went the wrong way didn't find the water fall but very pretty will differently will go back to find the water fall", 'Easy trail to walk but it is long. would not try without sufficient amount of water to drink. Beautiful fling hills and valleys.', '', "Beautiful Place :) we ignored the closed trail signs ;) I wouldn't unless you like mud! Lol GREAT HIKE Rad Waterfall!", 'Beautiful trail with lots of variety.', 'Great trail and easy to hike.', "Love this trail. Not great exercise because it's fairly easy but the waterfalls are cool and the scenery is lovely! Great for trail running! (And to the person complaining about a pit bull bite to their puppy, that's not the trails fault and this is supposed to be a review of the trail... Hazards of being outside!)", 'Closed from rains', 'It is closed because of flooding!', 'My 12 week old puppy was bit by a pit bull in the face. Will never go here again. If I could give it negative stars I would.', 'Great location and hike. Lots of water flowing due to all the rain we had however one of the trails is closed past the waterfall.', 'Loved it! Even saw a bobcat !!', 'Such a fun experience and the waterfall is nice relaxing reward.', "It's great :)", 'Love this canyon. I Used to go here when I was a kid before it was developed as a park.', 'Nice! Easy to access and good for all levels. I am a novice mountain biker so I had to walk my bike up a few of the big hills. The waterfall is just shy of 3 miles in. Also beware the hills are rocky. We enjoyed the day.', 'I went in the 3 miles it take to reach the waterfall. The trail was well maintained, and more of a walk than hike. Regardless the surrounding habitats were gorgeous with some good bird watching and peaceful side trails.', 'Easy trail with a few spots for shade in between. Great variety in trail hopping with alternate paths. The waterfall is the real treat, take of your shoes and socks and cool down in the water. The rocks at the waterfall also offer some fun traversing.', "The trail is pretty long but there is a beautiful little waterfall that I myself liked a lot. I mostly fast walked this. It wasn't really difficult but when you complete it you feel pretty good. I did a 8.5 miles loop so after all that I felt pretty good. You can bring your dogs and older kids. I loved it! Good for beginners and if you want to challenge yourself just jog the trail.", 'Great scenery, great work out, always nice for taking pictures, there is always the option of going the long way down or cutting it short for 6 miles. Make sure you go early to avoid the heat in the summertime.', "Weather wasn't too bad, we went at 0800. Was a bit busy but with lots of friendly people. Maybe we went on a weird day but there was quite a bit of horse crap over the trails. It was alright. Probably wouldn't do it again but glad I went through it.", "Wasn't too difficult. I was expecting to be closer to the water and more trees to walk under. I went midday so it was very hot.", "Great for trail running! Not too steep so it doesn't throw your pace off too bad. It's hot though....", 'The trial was easy but long. It was a nice 2 hour walk in the late afternoon. No need a lot of water.', 'It was alright.', 'Easy but hot. The side trails offer more shade and also extend your journey a bit.', 'Great trail.', 'Waterfall is nice, though small.  Overall scenery is too dried and hot.', 'Easy but fun', 'Great trail, pretty scenery. The "waterfall" at the end wasn\'t a waterfall but just a running creek.', 'Loved it!', "This was really more an leisurely stroll than what I would consider a hike.   The 'waterfall' is a nice way point.  This trail is a bit hetic on weekends but worth the  time and effort.  Enjoy.", 'Great trail. Beautiful scenery.', 'super easy trail anyone can hike. nice stream the whole way. lots of shade.', "Not much elevation change, so wouldn't call it hiking. A totally different kind of terrain from Torrey Pines and pretty much nobody here on a weekday morning. Loved the open meadow-like spaces. Would come again, but not too often; would love to leisurely MTB here. Saw a snake in a hole close to the trail - not sure what kind, didn't try to get close enough :) Heard lots of bees in a couple places as well. Fantastic birdwatching opportunities too.", 'Very easy/flat - more of a nature walk. But the 12 mile distance makes up for the lack of difficulty. Gorgeous and serene.', "Took the south side of the trail coming from the miramar area not a bad hike waterfall was a joke though wasn't much there took another route back ended up adding 3.5 miles to our hike. Beware as the rattlesnakes are out and about had a 4ft one come across in front of us as we hiked back", 'Very easy hike. Great trail to get you and your pups out of the house. Bring lots of water!!', 'Great fun! Stay to the right on hotter days on your way out.', 'Today it was muddy and the posted maps are faded which makes it hard to determine where the crossings are. Hard to view the waterfall from the south side and would have liked to get over to the north side. Went west to east but wondered if it is possible to come from the east end.', "So Gustavo and I went on a hike this last weekend. We are venturing through the trails, taking pictures, and really just enjoying the morning. Well Gustavo and I seen a bunch of horseback riders and it was Gustavos first time seeing horses. Which was pretty cool because he was very calm, just sat there and watching them walk on by. Then later Gustavo and I seen a coyote. He was was hurt though and I think was dying. He looked as though he was attached. The ranger with the horseback riders called the wildlife animal ranger for them to come investigate. I felt bad and helpless for the coyote. I didn't know what to do. He got up and staggered his way through the trails. Then as Gustavo and I are hiking back. I get our butts lost and ended up adding like 2.2 miles to our what should have been 6.3 total mile hike. We had a good time though.", 'Very large area, and very nice. There is a whole lot of scenery. As far as mountain biking, there is a lot of flat land with intermittent hills. If you look around there are also some more challenging areas. I would recommend this area to anybody looking to just go out for a couple hours. Just be aware that it is pretty populated.', 'A long and lovely hike through Penasquitos canyon. Saw a lot of birds (a few hawks) and rabbits scurrying in the bushes. Creek and waterfall were both vibrant and gushing with water. Great for a mostly overcast day. Be sure to study the map and/or take it with you, there are lots of turnouts and not all are clearly marked. Saw some housing developments on the cliff but long stretches of pure nature. A true delight, and a good workout. Lots of long, level flat stretches good for running. Not as crowded as I expected for a Sunday -- though there were a fair amount of mountain bikers -- though it did seem to threaten rain, so it might have kept the crowds at bay.', 'Would have given 5 stars but a little overcrowded.  Very beautiful!  Probably a weekday would be best.', 'Nice', "It was nice. Did it in July so it was super hot. BEWARE!! Poison Oak all over the place. Silly dog ran off and must have run through some poison oak because it's Sept and I'm still getting over this nasty rash. All in all great easy trail with a pretty water fall and little ponds to play in. ", 'This is one of my favorite hikes, it is really close to the city, easy to get to, and not as crowded as iron mt. There is a year round stream running parallel to the trail with a tiny set of waterfalls halfway through and these really add to this hike.', 'Good loop trail with several creek crossings to allow a wide variety of trail lengths.  South side tends to be wider trail but with more rocks in places.  North side is single track in many places.  Trails are well-maintained and clean.  There is a "waterfall" about half way in the canyon….a small cascade that is nice for San Diego but not a waterfall.  Often there is garbage in the stream.  Lots of walkers, runners, mountain bikers (who mistakenly believe that they have the right-of-way), and horses.  For most of the trail, you can see the houses on either side of the canyon, but for parts it almost feels like you are in nature.  For the area, this is a nice refuge in the heart of suburbia.', 'Easy trail.  I found the south side more interesting than the north.  Lots of flowers were in bloom.', "Very clean trail was hopping for lots of water in the waterfall but with the drought we having there wasn't a lot but otherwise it was fun", "Good for both mountain biking and running.  There is a waterfall here as well...worth it during the hotter months.  It's not the most difficult as far as mountain biking, but if you decide to take the power line trail all the way up it's pretty challenging.", 'Very nice trail lots of shade areas I just wish that the trails that are keeping usBikers out lets us used them one point I got lost so I rode one of them and they are lot better lots of curbs and love them so let us share them too', 'Really fun loop.  Water fountains at the turn around spot.  Great place to get a 2 hour run in.', 'In an advanced mountain biker and Id rate this canyon 8 on the fun factor! Nice open space,small hills and lots to see! Come check it out....you wont be disappointed!', "Awesome trail. I'd definitely do it again. I had my dog with me and she loved it and within 5 minutes of being there we saw wild rabbits, deer, and someone on a horse. My dog loved seeing all of that.", "Let me start by saying I went over my handlebars going down hill, felt pretty good. Little combat roll down hill in gravel never killed anyone. Reminds me of being a kid.Left palm, right forearm, right shoulder, left calf and right knee all cut up. That said, this is a nice loop trail for running, walking, biking, horse back riding. I would like to come back and run the trail some point when I get the chance. If you hadn't guessed I biked the trail, defiantly recommend for you to wear your helmet! Theirs lots of trails to branch out off to and some overlooks and whatnot. Theirs a small little waterfall (more like a river) which to my surprise had water flowing, imagine that!", 'A good, long and easy hike. Not a lot of water in the waterfalls. You could come across rattlesnakes along the path.', 'Really easy trail, I recommend going through the minor trails, very beautiful scenery, the waterfall is awesome, great to take the kid for a walk.', "Great trail for biking. It's long enough to wear you out with the distance and plenty of short hills. Don't believe the hype about the waterfall. It's more of a trickle, very disappointing. \nMake sure your brakes are good. I hit a 90 degree turn fast and my brakes were too worn so I slammed into the hillside. Nothing but some bruises, but it still hurt. I've been here a few times. Unless it's raining or really hot there's no reason not to go. I started at the entrance off Black Mountain Rd. South of the 56/Ted Williams Pkwy and biked to the other end in Sorrento Valley. Thankfully there was a porta potty at that end.  :) *There's lots of walkers with little children so pay attention!", 'Nice, long, easy walk. Cute little "waterfall"', 'nice trail for an easy ride there are many off shooting trails that get a little more technical its nice first trail I rode in California', 'very beautiful trail,and very easy hike. my wife and i took our dachshund and we all loved it, very shady and the little waterfall makes it worth it. .I sugest you read Afoot and Afield is a book about trails in San Diego.', 'Really easy hike to do. Lots of "kodak moments" throughout the trail as well as the Ranch House and Garden open for viewing. There are several different routes to the waterfall along with many different creek crossing to vary your hiking trip. There is a lot of shade in the beginning of the hike but later on it is mostly open space, so bring lots of water and sunscreen. The waterfall was a lot better than I expected so that was a plus as well. No crazy hills to climb, so this is a great hike for people with varying skill levels. FYI I parked in the designated parking lot along Black Mountain Rd, so there is a $3 parking fee.', 'Went hiking today early afternoon. Barely any people until we got to the waterfall. Beautiful scenery and great views of birds. Will come back as much as possible. Make sure to wear proper hiking clothes. My feet are killing me!  ', "I really like Penasquitos for trail running.  The trails are all flat.  Some of them are in beautiful open areas on a dirt road and some are single track.  Some of the trails meander through shady areas which is great if it's really hot out.   Some of the single tracks do not allow bikes.  The trails run on both sides of the river.  There are 3 or 4 river crossings.  The waterfall is about in the center of the canyon reachable by either the east or west.  You have to pay $3 for parking in the east entrance.  It's nice to have a water source to take a break at and cool off.  Don't expect a huge waterfall unless it's been raining ;)  There is a ranch house to explore.", 'Pretty flat. Not too crowded, but 6 miles is the most you can really do for running without running through the same spot multiple times.', "Not busy during the week. This is a great place to trail run with some distance.  I'll be going here a lot. ", "Had a great tour of the Adobe by Docent Bob followed by a very scenic walk along the trail.  We didn't go to the falls due to limited time, but enjoyed the shaded scenery of the canyon.", 'Good, easy hike but it is long!  We started on the east side at the trail head/parking lot and hiked for about 1.5 hours but only got halfway to the waterfall.  I understand there are other places to start but the closest to the waterfall is 2 miles - just not doable with small children.', 'Very good trail for beginners. A lot to see. Gets really busy on the weekends towards mid/late afternoon. I went as soon as the park opened. Be advised to get to the waterfall, you will have to carry you bike down, as there is no place to bike it down. The further you pass the waterfall (about mile 3) you will see horse poop along the way. Be careful not to run over it. Plenty of opportunities to bike other trails. Would definitely come back!', 'It was a nice day for our hike, and a beautiful waterfall to top it all off. The dogs loved the water and had a good time swimming around with some of the local kids. The trail went through some shaded parts which was very pretty. The only thing with this trail is that there are a lot of bikers so we frequently had to step off the path to let them by. We are used to very quiet trails so this one seemed very busy to us. But besides that this was a great trail!', 'Great hike! My boyfriend and I found it beautiful and breezy enough to run at times! You feel some of the inclines in your legs the next day! Overall, calm and good hike! ', "I organized a group of about 50 friends from out church to go for a day hike here. The ages of this group ranged from about a year old (carried for much of the trip) to someone well into their 70's. We had a fantastic time! We started at the adjacent park and made a loop from the park, to the waterfall crossing and back. Total distance on this loop is about 6 miles: 3 from the park parking lot to the waterfall crossing, and 3 to get back. Due to the difference in ages/ fitness, some of us walked ahead, and other had a more leisurely stroll or stayed behind, just to admire the scenery. It took us about 4 hours for all of us to complete the loop. Afterwards we had a picnic at the park (I asked everyone to pack a lunch, and leave it at their cars). Everyone had a wonderful time, and have since asked me to organize another outing. I only have one word of warning: we did see rattlesnakes, but they were off trail.", "Fun ride! This was my first ride after purchasing a mountain bike. It was about 12-13 miles long and was definitely harder than 20 mile rides that I've done on a road bike. Mostly flat but there were a few tough hills (for me as a first time rider). Make sure to bring at least 2 bottles of water & a small snack.", '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Vasquez Rocks Trail  - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'kid friendly', 'birding', 'hiking', 'horseback riding', 'road biking', 'rock climbing', 'trail running', 'walking', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'over grown', 'rocky']
hike_description: Vasquez Rocks Trail  is a 2.9 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Santa Clarita, California that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
